HEADLINE: SENATE DEFLECTS NUMEROUS EFFORTS TO ALTER TAX BILL 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
With Republicans united, the Senate tonight rejected one attempt after another to change a bill that would give President Bush his top legislative priority, the first big tax cut in 20 years.
 The solid Republican support seemed to assure the bill's approval, but at midnight, the Senate still faced votes on dozens of possible amendments, and further votes were put off until Tuesday. A conference committee could begin as soon as the bill is passed to work out the differences between this bill and tax legislation passed by the House of Representatives. 
 The Republicans' goal is to have a bill ready for the president to sign into law by the end of the week.
"This is the week that President Bush's proposal will become law," said Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill. "I really do believe that by Friday we will have tax legislation." 
Under the Senate bill, most people who pay income taxes would have their taxes cut this year by $300 -- $600 for a couple -- and families with children at home would get an even larger reduction.
Beginning next year, tax rates would be reduced in stages, and by 2007, the top rate would be lowered to 36 percent from the current 39.6 percent. President Bush proposed that the top rate be 33 percent, and the House went along with that.
The Senate tax cut measure, which would reduce taxes by $1.35 trillion over 11 years, would be the largest enacted since 1981, Ronald Reagan's first year as president. 
"The great winner of the tax relief act is the American people," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader, took issue with those who maintained the country could not afford to lose so much revenue. "It's a very timid package," Mr. Nickles said. "It's about one-fourth of the surplus."
But many Democrats contended the bill was too heavily tilted toward tax breaks for the wealthy, would bring back an era of budget deficits and would drain money needed to pay Social Security and Medicare benefits to baby boomers when they retired.
"Shame on us, shame on us for pushing this debt onto our kids," declared Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota.
By restricting the amount of money the government will have to spend, the measure will frame federal policies for years. But despite the importance of the legislation, the debate in the Senate today was remarkably spiritless.
Under procedures adopted unanimously last week, senators began early this morning to offer and discuss amendments. Mostly, they delivered monologues. Rarely were more than two or three other senators in their seats. All votes were postponed until 6 p.m., and then the many amendments were voted on one after another, pushing the session late into the night.
Democratic proposals included shifting more of the tax relief to lower-income taxpayers, retaining the tax on large estates, narrowing the tax reduction so more money would be available for debt reduction and delaying tax cuts until a prescription drug benefit under Medicare was enacted.
A central Democratic amendment to lower the 15 percent tax bracket to 14 percent was rejected, 50 to 48. Two Democrats, Zell Miller of Georgia and Max Baucus of Montana, voted against the proposal. One Republican, John McCain of Arizona, voted for it.
Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, was absent, attending a graduation. As a matter of senatorial courtesy, Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, who stood on the opposite side of the legislation, had agreed in advance to withhold his vote so the outcome could not be affected by Mr. Stevens's absence.
One Republican amendment proposed lowering the capital gains tax, while another sought to extend the business tax credit for research and development.
A bipartisan group proposed allowing the tax reductions to go into effect each year only if specific debt-reduction goals were met.
But it was clear from the outset that all these amendments would be rejected, and that, perhaps, explained why the debate on them lacked passion.
Normally, at the end of debates on important bills, the party leaders give stirring speeches summing up the arguments. But tonight, the Republican leader, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, made a perfunctory statement, saying only that the bill was a "very significant tax relief act for working Americans."
Democratic leaders left the closing statement to Senator Jon Corzine of New Jersey, a freshman. 
"I think we are far overreaching relative to our financial situation," Mr. Corzine said. "It will potentially bring grave concern to marketplaces around the world."
The heart of the legislation would be an across-the-board reduction in income tax rates beginning this year with a lowering of the bottom rate to 10 percent from 15 percent on the first $6,000 for every individual and the first $12,000 for every couple.
Beginning next year, in addition to the reduction in the top tax rate, the other tax brackets above 15 percent would be reduced by 3 percentage points each.
Other important provisions would raise the tax credit for children, now $500 per child, to $1,000, lower taxes for married couples, increase the size of estates exempt from taxation and repeal the estate tax entirely in 2011 and allow deduction of up to $5,000 for college tuition payments.
The bill would also increase the amount of income exempt from the alternative minimum tax and give more favorable tax treatment to pension and retirement programs.
The bill is somewhat more favorable to taxpayers of modest means than the plan President Bush proposed or the measures passed by the House. One provision would allow low-income families to receive a cash payment if they did not earn enough to be able to claim a full tax credit for their children.
But the bulk of the tax savings would still go to the wealthiest. These people pay most of the taxes, and they are the only ones whose taxes were increased in the 1990's.
A study by Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research institute that has the only computer model in private hands capable of making such calculations, showed that the richest 1 percent of taxpayers, with incomes over about $375,000, would get 33 percent of the tax benefits and that the bottom 60 percent of taxpayers would get 15 percent of the benefits.
The Senate bill differs only on the margins from what the president proposed and what the House passed. The biggest difficulty in the conference committee is likely to be what to remove from the House bills so that the entire legislation fits into the $1.35 trillion allotted by the budget plan adopted two weeks ago.
In theory, senators and representatives in conferences are supposed to defend the measures their chamber approved. But that does not always happen, and Senator Lott, who will probably be a conferee, suggested at a news conference this morning that he leaned favorably toward what the House passed. 
"I would like to see some changes from the Senate position," he said.
On the other hand, Senators Grassley and Baucus put the House on notice that if the bill approved by the conference strayed too far from what the Senate passed, there was a risk that the moderate Democrats and Republicans who hold the balance of power in the Senate might vote against the final package and cause its defeat.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Senate's Version of the Tax Cut"The Senate tax bill would reduce taxes by $1.35 trillion from this year through 2011. It must be reconciled with somewhat different tax-cutting legislation passed by the House. The Senate bill's main provisions include the following: ECONOMIC STIMULUS: Allocates $100 billion for tax cuts this year and next year to give a boost to the flagging economy by putting more money in the pockets of consumers. The bill would give single people a tax cut of up to $300 this year, with married couples getting up to $600. REDUCING RATES: Would gradually cut personal income tax rates over the next five years. The top rate of 39.6 percent would fall in steps to 36 percent by 2007; the current 36 percent rate would decline to 33 percent; the 31 percent rate would be cut to 28 percent; the 28 percent rate would fall to 25 percent; would create a new 10 percent rate below the existing 15 percent. CHILD CREDIT: Would gradually double the child credit, to $1,000 from $500, over 10 years. Would allow workers with no federal income tax liability to claim part of the credit to help low-income working families. MARRIAGE PENALTY: Would help two-income couples by addressing the quirk in the tax code that creates a bigger tax bill for many people who file joint returns, but not until 2006. Starting then, it would gradually raise deductions and adjust the 15 percent bracket to deal with the problem. ESTATE TAX: Would gradually reduce estate tax rates and increase the amount of an estate's value exempt from federal taxation and then would repeal the tax entirely starting in 2011. OTHER PROVISIONS: Would increase the level of allowable contributions to retirement savings programs, and would allow deductions for college tuition, though this would be rescinded in 2006. (pg. A16)

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Staples Posts Flat Earnings; Plans Curbed 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Staples Inc., the office products retailer, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit was flat and forecast no earnings growth in the second quarter as it scaled back expansion in the United States to control costs.
 For the quarter that ended May 5, Staples said its net income was $39.5 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with profit from operations of $39.9 million, or 9 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
 The results matched analysts' expectations, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
First-quarter sales rose 4 percent, to $2.67 billion from $2.56 billion, while sales at stores open at least a year rose 1 percent.
In the quarter a year earlier, Staples had a gain of $4.3 million, or 1 cent a share, for the reversal of an earlier store-closing charge. That resulted in net income of $44.2 million, or 10 cents a share.
Staples said revenue at its e-commerce operations, Staples.com, rose 182 percent, to $213 million, in the first quarter and, for the first time, achieved an operating profit before corporate allocated general and administrative expenses.
Although the company, based in Framingham, Mass., said it expected second-quarter and full-year earnings to be in line with analysts' expectations, it said it was planning more conservatively for the remainder of the year, given the current state of the economy. Staples said it had further reduced its store expansion plans in the United States for the year and now expected to add only 100 stores, 10 fewer than originally planned.
Shares of Staples rose 79 cents, to $16.31.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate; 
Asking Rents for Stores Stay Level in Manhattan

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The rents that landlords are seeking for stores held steady in Manhattan, and increased in some districts, despite a weakening national economy, according to a survey of space availability and asking rents focusing on September 2000 and March 2001.
 The survey, by the Real Estate Board of New York, is the second conducted by the trade group and is intended to determine retail rental rates, which vary widely within the city. 
 Most of the larger brokerage companies keep elaborate statistics on the office space market, but statistics on stores have been less widely available and actual rental levels are the subject of speculation by both landlords and prospective tenants.
Brokers said the city remained an attractive location for foreign-based retailers to establish a brand image or a new store format because of the city's large number of visitors. But others say that the slowing economy is making some retailers more cautious and that they are not jumping into deals as they would have six months ago. 
"Retailers are willing to pay fair prices for expansion space," said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, a real estate brokerage. "But the auctions we saw in the past are just that, a thing of the past."
The data for the board's report was submitted by 15 brokerage companies and covers 1,860 store spaces available March 31 with 10.6 million square feet. Average asking rentals increased slightly from last Sept. 30 to $98 a square foot annually from $96.
But the number of stores available for rent declined from the 2,010 last Sept. 30, and the average size of stores for rent went down from 6,236 square feet at that time to 5,715 square feet at the end of March.
Retail rents tend to be higher in small but well-located spaces. The average annual asking rent for stores of less than 1,000 square feet increased to $149 a square foot from $119, while the rental rate for stores of more than 10,000 square feet declined, to $78 a square foot from $84.
The costliest retail locations remain where they have long been: along Fifth Avenue in the 50's, 57th Street between Fifth and Park Avenues, and Madison Avenue between 57th and 67th Streets. But even there, some adjustments have taken place.
The highest asking rent along Fifth Avenue between 50th and 59th Streets declined to $896 a square foot this spring from $1,100. But the top asking rent along 57th Street between Fifth and Park Avenues increased to $833 a square foot from $800 last fall. The upper end of the market along Madison Avenue increased as well, to $850 a square foot from $800.
Not all space rents at the peak level, of course, but the average rental levels along these premier shopping areas show why many of these stores are selling luxury goods, which have higher profit margins. The average asking rent along the key section of Madison Avenue was $575 a square foot this spring, up from $493.
On Fifth Avenue in the 50's, the average rate was $733 a square foot, up from $713, while on the 57th Street strip, the average asking rent was $579 a square foot, up slightly from the fall average of $574.
Some locations in changing neighborhoods, notably near Times Square, have undergone substantial changes. Space on 42nd Street between Sixth and Eighth Avenues can still be rented for as little as $75 a square foot, but the most desirable spaces on the street are now at $632 a square foot, up from $375 in the fall.
Retail rental rates in more residential neighborhoods tend to be considerably less expensive than along the glamour strips, because the stores' customers are largely New Yorkers instead of high-spending tourists. The average asking rent on Third Avenue between 60th and 72nd Streets, for instance, was $198 a square foot, up from $186.
On the West Side, the asking rents for stores on Broadway between 72nd and 86th Streets were an average of $205 a square foot, unchanged from last fall.
Two shopping areas south of Midtown reported opposite results. On Fifth Avenue between 14th and 23rd Streets in the Flatiron District, average asking rents fell to $167 a square foot from $171 last fall. But in booming SoHo, asking rents on Broadway between Houston to Broome Streets increased to an average of $145 a square foot from $129 last fall.
A large part of the retail space that is available in Manhattan is in Midtown, which is defined as 31st Street to 59th Street, river to river. There was about 4.4 million square feet on the market in March, down from 5.2 million square feet last fall.

HEADLINE: Web Sites Inconsistent On Health, Study Finds 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP J. HILTS 

 BODY:
A new study has found that most of the time, health information on the Internet is hard to find, hard to read and often incorrect or incomplete, even on the best sites.
 The study, described in today's Journal of the American Medical Association, is the broadest on the topic to date; it includes detailed questions on four diseases, rates the difficulty of finding information and the site's reading level, and assesses its accuracy and completeness. The study includes Spanish-language sites. 
 "If you are looking for information on breast cancer, for example, and you search the Internet, how easy is it to find a good place for it?" said the study's lead author, Dr. Gretchen K. Berland of the RAND Corporation, the nonprofit research organization that conducted the study. "And if you land on a site, what will you find when you get there?" 
"For the most part, people will be frustrated, especially if they are among the underserved populations," Dr. Berland said in a telephone interview.
The study found that "accessing health information using search engines and simple search terms is not efficient" and that sites did not reliably include important information on health problems.
The study was sponsored by a philanthropic group, the California Health Care Foundation, and carried out by researchers affiliated with RAND. 
The study showed that government and university sites did better than commercial ones, and it concluded that the Internet had the potential "to be a powerful resource for meeting some of the public's health information needs." But, it went on, "this requires Web sites that present well-organized and accurate information in a way that is understandable."
Dr. James D. Metz, editor in chief of the nonprofit Oncolink site that offers information on cancer and scored among the highest of the 25 sites reviewed, said it was difficult to maintain high-quality information on the site.
"Our content is totally written by physicians, nurses and social workers in their fields of expertise," Dr. Metz said. "Very few sites do that."
"Too many sites are just trying to sell something," he said, "and it is scary how they can make a bad site look good." 
The study involved Internet information on breast cancer, childhood asthma, depression and obesity. Using a combined measure of completeness and accuracy, the study found that on 18 English language sites, on average the sites offered complete and correct information on breast cancer 63 percent of the time; on childhood asthma, 36 percent of the time; on depression 44 percent; and on obesity, 37 percent.
The study found that consumers face trouble first in just finding sites with substantial information. Only one in five promising links actually turned up pages with substantial content, it said. Researchers found the reading level of the English sites was above the level of a freshman in college, which is higher than average American reading levels. Spanish sites in the study averaged 10th-grade level. 
But most notable was the study's review of the quality of information offered by health Web sites.
The study involved the six top-rated general health sites, and 12 sites dedicated to specific diseases. Expert panels of physicians and patient advocates selected questions that patients often asked on each subject.
Then, site searchers were trained to scour each Web site for information on a topic. The searchers were given 90 minutes to two hours, more than three times the amount of time consumers report spending when they look for medical information.
Finally, all the information found on each site was collected into notebooks and turned over to a second set of experts, who would score the material for completeness and accuracy. 
Completeness was measured by counting how often central questions were covered in some detail. Accuracy was measured by comparing the judgment of several panels of experts with what was found on the site.
Even though the study reviewed only top-rated sites, researchers still found that the sites gave complete and accurate information only 45 percent of the time, on average. 
On average, reviewers found that Web sites had some information that contradicted other information on the same site and the same topic 53 percent of the time. There was wide variation in whether sources for posted information were given. On average, 65 percent of the sites gave both pieces of source information -- authors and a date -- but the spread was large, from none to 95 percent across the Web sites.

HEADLINE: Foreign Graduates Ask, 'What Now?' 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. 

 BODY:
As an undergraduate at the University of Virginia here for the last four years, Rasha Shaath, a Palestinian, learned Hebrew. She thrived in classes that made her examine her views and the troubles of her region from many angles. 
 This summer, Ms. Shaath, 22, will move to her family's new home in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, where she will don the abayya, the Saudis' mandatory covering for women, and look for work, probably as a reporter. Ms. Shaath frets less about the veil than about landing a newspaper job in a country where men and women cannot work together. She fears, on some level, the loss of the person she has become here. 
 "I worry about not having the kind of interaction that will allow me to remember what I gained in my education and use it," said Ms. Shaath, who completed a bachelor's degree in history and Middle Eastern studies. 
She worries, too, that the critical reflexes she sharpened here may be misinterpreted as disloyalty back home. "That can get dangerous, if I allow myself to become too much of an outsider," Ms. Shaath said. 
At campuses across the United States, foreign students like Ms. Shaath are facing commencement not only as a new beginning but also with anxiety, tension and divided loyalties. Families in home countries beckon, while graduates juggle questions that their American classmates need never consider: Will the distant, perhaps less developed, economy they left have a place for them? How will they adapt after immersion in American college life? Is it safe to go home? Are they ready? 
The share of American undergraduate freshmen who are nonresident foreigners has tripled over the last 30 years, according to the annual freshman survey by the University of California at Los Angeles. The Institute of International Education estimates that students from abroad now represent 515,000 of the 14.5 million students attending institutions of higher education in the United States, an increase of nearly 5 percent over the last year alone. More than half the foreign students come from Asia; most earn degrees for careers in business, engineering and computer science. 
After spending the four years of transition to early adulthood away from their countries, with finances often limiting visits back, graduates can have trouble feeling at home anywhere, said Kathy Bellows, who oversees international students and scholars at Georgetown University. Graduation from college shakes an international student's sense of identity and place, Ms. Bellows said.
Though foreigners are courted by universities eager to broaden their profiles -- and for the full, out-of-state tuition they typically fork over -- the welcome mat often frays when they turn to the United States' job market as graduates. In order to extend their student visas for a year of "practical experience," foreigners must get a job in their field of study, and some companies flatly refuse their resumes. The graduates who hope to settle here permanently try to gauge a prospective employer's willingness to sponsor them for a long-term work visa. 
As a result, such students cannot take time off to explore the United States or relax after four years of college, said Kath-Ann Gerhardt, associate dean of international students and scholars at the University of California at Davis.
"Your final year as an undergraduate can be very stressful," Ms. Gerhardt said, "but it's an additional layer of concern that international students face."
Jelena Bosanoc of Belgrade felt the constraints of her situation most keenly in early May. On the day her parents were to leave Belgrade for Budapest, the nearest American embassy that would give them a visa to attend her graduation, her father suffered a fatal stroke. 
While her classmates planned extended post-graduation travels, Ms. Bosanoc, a Georgetown University senior, could not go home for her father's funeral. Her student visa would have expired in her absence, and her work visa for her new job at Goldman, Sachs was not yet done.
"I was ready to go home and beg the authorities to just let me back," Ms. Bosanoc said. "But my mom even said, 'This is not what your dad would want you to do.' "
Aycan Demirhan, a graduate from Istanbul, said two things preoccupied her during her years at Virginia: her family and her immigration status. She said she felt herself a prisoner of these twin worries, particularly when a catastrophic earthquake struck Turkey two years ago.
And when Samer Saadeh, a Beirut-born Virginia senior, took his diploma in early May, he draped the Lebanese flag over his black gown so relatives in Lebanon could pick him out from the sea of graduates on the university's live Web cast.
Alexandre Venot, a 23-year-old at Georgetown who is getting his degree in finance and management, likens the prospect of returning to his family in France to a reverse acculturation, the opposite of his adaptation to American life. He is searching for a job to extend his visa, and hopes for something that will offer moral, more than monetary, satisfaction. Vaguely, he thinks it may be time to reconnect with his homeland.
"I'm a very different person from when I left my home country," Mr. Venot said. "To make myself feel better, I say I'm a citizen of the world, but I don't feel comfortable anywhere. Maybe if I go to Spain and you ask me in three years, I'll say I feel Spanish." 
While some students hope to settle in the United States permanently, others plan to return home, but not yet. 
Ms. Demirhan, who studied psychology and economics, estimates that she needs a decade working in this country to secure a job back home at the vice-presidential level, crucial if she hopes to influence decisions in Turkey's tradition-bound, hierarchical culture. She will start work at Credit Suisse-First Boston in New York this summer, and figures "they'll have to see something really magical in me" to sponsor her for a work visa. 
Astari Daenuwy, an Indonesian student at the University of Virginia, also scoured job fairs and the Internet for an opening. Given her country's political and economic turmoil, she said, "If I go home, I can't really do anything with what I have now."
Recruiters from multinational consulting firms were delighted to learn that Ms. Daenuwy, whose English is fluent and unaccented, spoke Indonesian. Once she revealed she was Indonesian, however, their interest dimmed.
"But you do have friends in your major," she remembers one recruiter suggesting. "We'd love to hear from them." 
Her only offer came from the nonprofit U.S.-Indonesia Society, based in Washington. Ms. Daenuwy has until fall to persuade her new bosses to sponsor her for a six-year work visa, of which the Immigration and Naturalization Service issues only 195,000 a year. Aside from the considerable paperwork sponsorship entails, it also costs an employer more than $1,000 in government fees.
For Mr. Saadeh, whose family lives in Geneva, the senior-year job hunt proved disillusioning. The friendliness and sense of inclusion that opened him up as an undergraduate fell away, with recruiters from several companies declining resumes from international students. He eventually landed a job with Dell Computer, which, with the technology sector's downturn, fell through just before graduation.
Ms. Shaath, who hopes to attend graduate school in Chicago, at first expected to feel bitter about her parents' insistence that she spend a year with them in Jeddah. When she left for college, they feared she would fall in love with her independence and never return. Now, she says she wants to go home.
"I'm attached to my family and roots," Ms. Shaath said. "I think if I stayed on for graduate school now, I'd definitely lose a part of myself."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Astari Daenuwy of Indonesia, left, at graduation from the University of Virginia in May with Anne Magnan.; Rasha Shaath, left, whose family is in Saudi Arabia, and Samer Saadeh of Lebanon, graduated on Sunday from the University of Virginia. HEADLINE: Bush Is Putting Team in Place for a Full-Bore Assault on Regulation 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22 

 BODY:
Across an array of federal agencies, the Bush administration has begun to make good on its commitment of broad deregulation, promoting a policy transformation long sought by the business community and opposed by consumer, labor and environmental organizations.
 Well beyond the intersecting spheres of energy and the environment, where the shifting policies have been apparent for months and crystallized last week in the proposal for a relaxation of regulations to encourage energy development, the scaffolding of a new regulatory framework is taking shape. 
 It would affect antitrust enforcement, telecommunications, workplace rules, consumer protections, financial services and even how the military and other agencies buy goods and services from the private sector.
For instance, Mary Sheila Gall, the official selected to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, has a decade-long track record at the agency of voting against proposed safety rules because she has often said that injuries are caused not by faulty product designs but by negligent consumers. Her record has attracted widespread support from many manufacturers and strong criticism from Consumers Union and other similar groups. 
She has criticized the agency for promoting "a federal nanny state." Safety experts and industry executives predict that after she takes over, a number of proposals under consideration, like one requiring flame-resistant treatment of upholstered furniture and another regulating baby bath seats, will be dropped.
Timothy J. Muris, the nominee to head the Federal Trade Commission, has repeatedly said that the Clinton administration was insensitive to the economic benefits of large corporate mergers and too aggressive in bringing major monopoly cases and challenging a large airline for predatory pricing. Mr. Muris, a top antitrust official in the Reagan administration, complained at his Senate confirmation hearing last Wednesday that under the previous administration, "there were many large monopoly investigations at the Department of Justice sending a signal that I thought was inappropriate."
And John D. Graham, another Bush appointee for a senior regulatory post, has long maintained that the federal government has imposed too many onerous environmental, health and safety regulations on big business without properly calculating the financial costs of such regulations.
Dr. Graham, a Harvard professor whose research on risks has been sponsored by corporations with stakes in the outcome of regulatory debates, has maintained that exposure to low levels of dioxins, which the government classifies as a human carcinogen, may actually reduce cancer and that there is insufficient evidence to demonstrate any harmful effect of residual pesticides on food. He is expected to become the White House's senior budget official for reviewing almost every proposed federal regulation.
The approach being pursued by the Bush regulators involves a far more rigorous examination of the financial costs and benefits of regulation, one that experts predict will tip the balance of power from consumer, environmental and labor groups to businesses and will lead to a wholesale elimination of scores of rules that have prevented American companies from both growing and having more flexibility in making business decisions.
Supporters of the existing regulations say that the rules promote many benefits that are not easily quantifiable and are certain to be overlooked under such cost-benefit analyses, from protecting consumers from dangerous products to preserving the environment and limiting companies from dominating certain crucial industries like telecommunications. But the administration is sympathetic to companies that have been deeply critical of the financial costs of such rules.
"There are those who believe cost should be no object," said Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget director and a central player in the regulatory process. "They take the position that if an objective feels good, we should impose a regulation without regard to costs. That's not a very realistic approach."
While many of the Bush appointees are still awaiting confirmation, leaders of American businesses say they can already feel the different regulatory climate in Washington.
"Under Clinton, some of the regulatory agencies had a view that they didn't trust business and the government did a lot of things even if they had to go over the line," said Thomas J. Donohue, president and chief executive of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "The Bush guys have more of an understanding of the effect of regulation on the business community and on the economy. And they are doing it while there is an energy crisis on their hands and an economy that is not doing well."
But others say that the administration is simply repaying its campaign debts to its most important supporters.
"The big oak tree is bending all the way over," said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, a public advocacy group, and a senior safety regulator in the Carter administration. "Bush is going full bore to support his industry supporters. He wants to completely change the regulatory process to be one that supports the industry."
Not since the Reagan administration's wholesale reversals of regulatory policies have the scales tipped so abruptly, according to lobbyists for both sides in the long-running regulatory debate.
Just as during the so-called Reagan Revolution, the deregulatory renaissance is largely a reflection of the pro-business agenda that President Bush campaigned on. But the change is especially swift this time because Congress and the White House are controlled by the Republicans for the first time in nearly half a century. When the legislative and executive branches of government are controlled by different parties, the regulatory agencies typically take more moderate positions as they walk a line between Congress and the White House.
While Bill Clinton and his administration courted business from Silicon Valley to Wall Street, certain agencies in the 1990's were far more aggressive in their rules and enforcement than in the prior administration. This could be seen in actions ranging from the Microsoft antitrust case to enforcement of environmental regulations.
But now, many of those actions are under assault, and the shifting ground can be felt throughout the alphabet soup of Washington agencies:
*Michael K. Powell, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has been deeply skeptical of rules limiting the size of cable and broadcasting companies and of regulations that have made it hard for the regional Bell companies to enter the long-distance market without first opening their own local markets. "I do not believe deregulation is like a dessert that you serve after people have fed on their vegetables and is a reward for the creation of competition," he said earlier this year. "I believe that deregulation is instead a critical ingredient to facilitating competition, not something to be handed out after there is a substantial number of players in the market."
*Two of the three people nominated to serve as service secretaries in the Defense Department come from military contractors, where they have advocated a greater reliance on the marketplace and contracting out for services. The two, Gordon R. England of General Dynamics for the Navy and James G. Roche of Northrop Grumman for the Air Force -- along with other senior Pentagon officials -- have vowed to re-examine procurement practices with an eye toward accelerating the review of government contracts, reducing red tape and promoting outsourcing and the privatization of programs that should prove to be enormously beneficial to the business community.
*The president's energy policy, formulated by the White House and a group of agencies including the Interior and Energy Departments, offers conservation proposals in an effort to win over some environmental groups. But it proposes to deliver a virtual wish list of deregulatory changes to the oil, gas and nuclear industries, which had far less influence in the prior administration.
The case of Ms. Gall to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission is perhaps the strongest illustration of the policy shift. Following the tradition of other presidential nominees, Ms. Gall said through an aide that she would not comment on her record or regulatory views while her nomination was pending.
Since 1991, she has been one of three commissioners at the agency, which watches over some 15,000 products. Created in the 1970's, the commission was nearly eliminated in the Reagan administration, and after its budget was eviscerated and it was filled with relatively ineffective officials, frustrated consumer groups contemplated recommending that it be eliminated.
Under Ann W. Brown, who was appointed by President Clinton to head the agency in 1994, its profile rose considerably. Ms. Brown, a former top official at the Consumer Federation of America, opened investigations into products, and she proposed rules as a way to prod industries to formulate their own guidelines.
Over the same period, Ms. Gall has repeatedly voted against safety regulations and has criticized the agency's role in prodding industries to formulate their own standards, which often reduced injuries and deaths. She has voted against safety standards for baby walkers, crib slats, bunk beds and baby bath seats. After the agency prodded crayon makers to remove small amounts of an asbestos-like substance, she applauded the industry but criticized the commission for putting pressure on the companies.
"The commission strives to be a data-driven agency and one committed to sound science in its activities," she said at the time. "In this case, however, the commission requested reformulation in the absence of adequate data. This 'science' more closely resembled 'political' science than traditional scientific inquiry."
But safety experts say that criticism is unwarranted, and that Ms. Gall's philosophy, if put in force at the agency, will lead to a sharp setback for consumers. 
"The mission of the Consumer Product Safety Commission is to reduce or eliminate unreasonable risk of injury," said R. David Pittle, a former commissioner at the agency who is now the senior vice president and technical director of Consumers Union. "If kids year in or year out are killed by some product, the law does not say, 'Well, we have to tell the parents to do a better job.' That doesn't have much meaning to a parent who has lost a child because of a momentarily inadvertent lapse of attention."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John D. Graham is expected to become the top budget official for reviewing proposed regulations. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: Japan Finds Diplomacy Can Turn A Bit Unruly 

BYLINE:  By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 22 

 BODY:
Japan's new foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, a fiery reformer, has never been known for her diplomatic skills. And in her first weeks in office she has committed a number of gaffes that have made her critics question her ability to do the job. 
 Ms. Tanaka has unceremoniously canceled appointments with foreign dignitaries, including a meeting in Tokyo with Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage. She has been widely criticized for undermining the bureaucrats who have managed the foreign ministry for decades, though she herself lacks experience in international affairs. 
 Frustration over her behavior reached a high point last week when foreign ministry bureaucrats openly ridiculed her and she faced a grilling from opposition politicians in Parliament. Even some members of her own party, the Liberal Democratic, have assailed Ms. Tanaka's actions.
Ms. Tanaka is considered an ardent reformer, and as the daughter of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, one of the party's strongest leaders, she remains highly popular with the public. She is the first woman to hold the position of foreign minister. 
The criticism of her has been furious. Takuya Tasso of the Liberal Party accused Ms. Tanaka of lying when she said that she had scrapped the meeting with Mr. Armitage because she was "exhausted and in a panic" after a busy day of foreign policy briefings by the agency staff. "All Japanese people think the explanation of the foreign minister is a lie," Mr. Tasso said. "Chronic lying requires psychoanalysis."
United States and Japanese diplomats said Ms. Tanaka's refusal to meet with Mr. Armitage was especially unfortunate because the meeting had been arranged weeks ago and the deputy secretary was carrying a message from President Bush about his new security strategy. Moreover, the United States is Japan's main ally and Mr. Armitage will be involved in setting American policy in Asia, they said. 
Foreign Ministry officials said that in recent days Ms. Tanaka had also skipped scheduled appointments with a number of other foreign diplomats, including Igor Ivanov, Russia's foreign minister: Chris Patten, Europe's external relations commissioner; and Rodriguez Giavarini, Argentina's foreign minister.
And on Monday, another controversy involving Ms. Tanaka was kept alive when Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said he had not ruled out the possibility of issuing another visa to the former president of Taiwan, Lee Teng-hui.
Aside from the inherent sensitivity of the issue because of Chinese objections, the prime minister's comments apparently contradicted comments by Ms. Tanaka, who reportedly had told China that Tokyo would issue no more visas to Mr. Lee. 
"Madam Tanaka was the worst choice for foreign minister in modern Japanese history," Mr. Tasso said in an interview. "Following protocol and being polite are the most important aspects of Japanese culture since time immemorial and she has shattered that virtue in front of the whole world."
In a television interview, former Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori said of Ms. Tanaka: "I have the impression that she has been acting emotionally." The newspaper Yomiuri Shinbun criticized what it called Ms. Tanaka's "ego trip" in an editorial that concluded, "If things are allowed to continue in this vein, the government could find itself unable to carry out any diplomatic duties."
Much of the onslaught against Ms. Tanaka is being fueled by the powerful old guard of the Liberal Democratic Party of whom the new foreign minister has been a sharp critic. The ruling party elders, who have historically chosen the country's prime minister, were humiliated last month when Mr. Koizumi, a maverick, won the election, running on a platform of social and economic reforms. Mr. Koizumi has filled his cabinet with several radical reformers like Ms. Tanaka. 
But Ms. Tanaka's troubles are also a result of her deteriorating relations with the ministry's entrenched bureaucrats. 
Upon her arrival at the ministry, Ms. Tanaka vowed to shake up the ministry, a largely autonomous agency, and seize control from the bureaucrats. She immediately canceled transfer orders, toughened policy on Russia, and threatened to punish those responsible for an embezzlement scandal at the ministry. The result was a near revolt within her own agency in which senior bureaucrats, more accustomed to shepherding the foreign minister rather than taking orders, openly sparred with her in heated meetings at the ministry. She has been paying the price ever since.
At the parliament budget meeting, Ms. Tanaka refused to answer questions regarding the United States missile defense plan, saying the ministry staff had not briefed her on the issue despite repeated requests, suggesting that they had deliberately withheld information. But ministry executives publicly disputed the minister, providing dates and times when she had been briefed. 
By the end of last week, Ms. Tanaka had apologized, saying that she had received a report.
Political analysts said that Ms. Tanaka's missteps had embarrassed Japan and the Koizumi administration. They said that to be effective in her new post, Ms. Tanaka will have to mend fences with the ministry bureaucrats.
"She's a very intense person and probably a little too interested in getting a sound bite," said Kuniko Inoguchi, a professor of international studies at Sophia University. "But I think she was right to come out strong in the beginning because she is the first woman in that job and she had to demand respect."
Despite Ms. Tanaka's awkward debut at the Foreign Ministry, Morimoto Satoshi, a professor of political science at Takushoku University, said she was an appropriate choice for the post because she is capable of carrying out the type of drastic reforms that Mr. Koizumi has promised. 
The rift at the Foreign Ministry appears to have had little impact on Ms. Tanaka's popularity. Japanese newspapers and television reported that opposition leaders were flooded with angry calls and faxes protesting what many Japanese viewed as unfair attacks against the foreign minister. 
The Foreign Ministry has become unpopular with the public after an embezzlement scandal involving agency officials, who are regarded as elitist and arrogant by many Japanese.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Makiko Tanaka, Japan's new foreign minister, conferring this week with an unidentified lawmaker, right, and her aide, center, at a parliamentary hearing. She has been ruffling a few feathers in the Foreign Ministry. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
My Beautiful Mansionette

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
For most of the past year my wife and I lived in a rented house in central New Jersey -- a McMansion, also known as a mansionette. It was in a brand-new development, in what used to be a cornfield, that looks like a textbook illustration of turn-of-the-millennium urban sprawl. These days they aren't little boxes on a hillside, they're big boxes on flat ground. But they're all still made out of ticky-tacky, and they all look just the same. 
 Our neighbors, however, didn't all look just the same. Most of them were immigrants, and most were nonwhite; the largest contingent came from India. 
 Seeing this, some of my recent correspondents would doubtless have felt confirmed in their prejudices. You see, a few columns back I wrote a piece about urban sprawl and its attendant traffic congestion, which is becoming a very serious issue -- a lot more important to the lives of most people than the dollar or two per day they might eventually get from George W. Bush's tax cut. And a surprising number of the letters I received in response insisted, vehemently, that the real culprit behind urban sprawl was population growth, and that therefore it was all because of immigration. 
A quick search of the Internet reveals that my correspondents are not isolated individuals; they are part of a still small but growing movement. On casual observation I would say that the anti-immigration movement today is where the anti-globalization movement was a couple of years before Seattle: not yet large enough to be a political force to be reckoned with, but quite possibly on its way to achieving critical mass. And complaints about the alleged linkage between immigration and urban sprawl is a popular theme. 
Like so much of what the anti-globalization activists say, these complaints are mostly but not entirely off base. The grain of truth in the argument is that other things being the same, a growing population means more houses, more cars and hence more sprawl. But population growth is only a secondary contributing factor to a disastrous pattern of land use driven by skewed incentives that encourage people to spread out in a low-density sprawl that in turn forces them to spend more and more of their time in cars. What's really impressive to me is the way that medium-size metropolitan areas, like Atlanta or Houston, have managed to mismanage their development so completely that they have worse traffic congestion than metropolitan New York, which has five times their population. (I know, I know, I sound like the kind of person Dick Cheney loves to hate. But as it happens I do own an S.U.V.)
So why the vehemence? Psychoanalyzing a political movement guarantees a fresh wave of hate mail, but my best guess is that the passion of my correspondents is ultimately fueled by cultural unease. The changes one sees in central New Jersey are the same as what one sees everywhere in this country: farms and traditional towns submerged by a rising tide of malls, highways and McMansions. And since some of the faces behind the wheel or the fake Palladian window are brown, it's all too natural to blame them for the trend.
Obviously I don't feel the same way; I am one of those people who feel that immigration is a good thing -- most of all for the immigrants, but good for America too. To some extent this position rests on mundane economic arguments. Foreign-born talent has been crucial in this country's technology boom, and plays a large role in many less glamorous industries too. (For some reason all the gas stations around here seem to be run by Sikhs.) And one can make a good case that demography -- the perils of a low birth rate -- is a key factor in the economic malaise of Japan and some European countries; America's openness to immigration is one of the things protecting us from that fate.
And I have my own cultural prejudices. Isn't the immigrant experience part of what this country is all about? Without immigrant families climbing the social ladder, what would become of the American dream? 
But never mind the rational arguments. Over the horizon new and possibly quite nasty political storms are brewing. If you think people get angry and irrational when arguing about taxes, wait till you see them argue about immigration.

HEADLINE: Deficit Estimate In New Jersey Now Reaching $1.6 Billion 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 22 

 BODY:
Just a year ago, New Jersey was reveling in the budgetary equivalent of a winning Powerball ticket: a huge windfall of tax revenue allowed state officials to draft a budget with a 10 percent spending increase and a record $870 million surplus. But with just six weeks to go before the next budget must be adopted, the state has gone from counting its spoils to pinching its pennies.
 Nonpartisan fiscal analysts are now predicting a $1.6 billion shortfall in next year's budget, up from the $1 billion deficit that they were predicting just seven weeks ago. The projections raise the likelihood that Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and the Republican-controlled State Legislature will have to make drastic spending cuts in the heat of the Republican primary campaign for governor. 
 While no one at the State House is predicting a recession, the nationwide economic slowdown is clearly being felt in New Jersey. State taxes collected in March and April declined more than 2 percent from last year, and the unemployment rate rose to 4.2 percent in April from 3.8 percent the month before. While there is little doubt that the budget can be balanced, there is a new air of uncertainty. What if stocks drop again? What if more jobs are lost, or energy prices continue to rise? 
The anxiety that state officials are starting to feel was evident at a routine budget hearing this morning, when the acting treasurer refused to provide lawmakers with revised revenue projections, saying he needed more time. It was a departure from practice, drawing harsh criticism from Democrats and even raising the eyebrows of Leonard Lance, the Republican chairman of the Assembly Budget Committee.
The budget process cannot proceed until the executive branch certifies revenue projections, so, as a result of the delay, the Legislature will have a month at best to rework the $23.2 billion budget, which may need to be cut by as much as 5.5 percent.
In his testimony, the acting state treasurer, Peter R. Lawrance, did not discount evidence that this year's tax revenues were falling far short of expectations. But he said the current state of the economy was so unpredictable that officials needed more time to develop accurate estimates, particularly of the capital gains taxes that the state has increasingly come to rely on.
"There is little doubt that we will be lowering our revenues from earlier forecasts," Mr. Lawrance told the committee. "But we will not know to what extent until Treasury staff and our consultants complete the evaluations."
Mr. Lawrance expressed confidence that the New Jersey economy remained strong and said the changing forecasts "should not scare and frighten people in need of state services."
Still, Mr. Lawrance's acknowledgment that revenues will fall short all but guarantees six tense weeks between now and July 1, the deadline set in the State Constitution for adopting a balanced budget. And it means Republicans in Trenton will be scrambling to cut spending while former Representative Bob Franks and Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City are battling for the party's nomination for governor. The primary vote is on June 26. 
Today, Mr. Lance, the budget committee chairman, did not scold Mr. Lawrance for not providing revenue estimates, but he was not happy. "Traditionally, middle of May is the time when Treasury tells the Legislature its estimates for the coming year," he reminded the treasurer. He rejected Mr. Lawrance's offer to provide new numbers by mid-June, requesting instead that they be presented to the committee, along with a revised budget, by June 1.
Mr. Lance urged the administration to impose "an immediate freeze on all discretionary spending and on all hiring in every department in state government." He said he looked forward to helping the administration cut spending. "I do not believe there is any sentiment anywhere to raise taxes," he said. 
But Assemblywoman Barbara Buono, the senior Democrat on the budget committee, was not as forgiving. "Quite frankly, I think it's an abomination," she said of Mr. Lawrance's refusal to supply estimates. "I can't find that there is any excuse." 
Ms. Buono accused Mr. Lawrance of abdicating his responsibilities as treasurer and said he was hampering the Legislature's participation in the budget process. "How can we review our options if you put no data, no calculations before us?" she asked. "You reassure us that we are going to have a balanced budget. When are you going to let the Legislature in on it?"
Mr. Lawrance's appearance at today's hearing was preceded by testimony from David J. Rosen, the chief of the finance section of the Office of Legislative Services, a nonpartisan agency that analyzes the budget. Mr. Rosen testified that the shortfall for next year, projected in April to be $1 billion, was now estimated to be $1.6 billion. 
Mr. Rosen and Alan R. Kooney, the legislative budget and finance officer, said that tax revenues had dropped off much sooner than they expected. They expressed particular concern about a decline in capital gains tax revenue, which they estimate will be down 25 percent from last year and reduce state revenues by about $400 million. The decline could be steeper if the stock markets do not perform better, they said. 
Mr. Lawrance said he did not agree with that estimate for the capital gains tax. In his testimony he cited conflicting projections on capital gains taxes by different economists. In next year's budget, as it now stands, the state has projected an increase in capital gains tax revenue of 3.5 percent. 
As a cost-saving measure, Mr. Lawrance said, the state has barred spending on new office equipment.
He stressed that there was no cause for worry. "As has been stated by many economists, it is their belief and ours that New Jersey's economy remains fundamentally strong," he testified. "And any economic downturn will be more shallow and of shorter duration here than elsewhere."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Britain: Profit At Airline 

BYLINE:  By Alan Cowell (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Reversing its first annual loss as a publicly traded company last year, British Airways reported a full-year profit of $:114 million ($164 million). It said it had reduced the number of cheap-seat passengers to focus on business class fliers paying top prices. 
The turnaround came despite the economic slowdown in the United States and Britain's outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, which deterred some travelers. Shares of British Airways rose 6 percent, to 377 pence ($5.43). The company also said it expected its supersonic Concorde flights to the United States to resume in late summer. The airplanes have been grounded since the crash last July of an Air France Concorde near Paris in which more than 100 people died. Alan Cowell (NYT)

HEADLINE: Korean Chip Maker Moves to Raise Cash 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, May 22 

 BODY:
Hynix Semiconductor is opening a global capital-raising campaign with an unusual selling point: its leading shareholders agreed today to surrender all their shares to the creditor institutions to which Hynix owes more than $4 billion.
 The company disclosed the forfeiture of shares held by three other Hyundai companies and by the Hyundai Group's chairman, Chung Mong Hun, to demonstrate that it is indeed leaving the Hyundai orbit. It is trying to raise cash and clean up debt as part of a $3.8 billion self-rescue plan. 
 Hynix's president, Park Chong Sup, opened the 25-city roadshow, with stops in North America, Europe and Asia, on Monday by promising to spell out for investors how "fundamental changes within Hynix" were yielding improvements "that reach into every area of our operations and activities."
The biggest change was the surrender of a combined 19.3 percent of the company's equity by Hyundai Merchant Marine, Hyundai Heavy Industries, Hyundai Elevator and Mr. Chung, a son of the Hyundai group founder, Chung Ju Yung. The deal freed the three Hyundai companies of responsibility for debts in excess of $1 billion that they had backed on Hynix's behalf. 
Mr. Park, a longtime executive at Hyundai Electronics, as the company was known before it began breaking away from the group, has reportedly laid out for investors a plan to spend some $7 billion on new and refurbished plants and on research and development in a drive to catch up with Samsung Electronics in production of memory chips. Hynix, long the No. 2 producer behind Samsung, has lately been overtaken by Micron Technology as well.
Success for Hynix depends on whether it can persuade investors to buy $1 billion in new equity, in the form of global depository receipts, plus some $300 million in high-yield bonds, before the end of June when the company completes its separation from the Hyundai Group.
The government-controlled Korea Development Bank has already bought more than $600 million worth of Hynix bonds this year, and another government-controlled institution, the Seoul Guarantee Insurance Company, backs a further $500 million in bonds that were purchased by local investment trust companies, two moves that have drawn criticism overseas, especially in the United States, as veiled subsidies to the company, a contention the government denies.

HEADLINE: Target's Net Rises 6.3% As It Expands To New Areas 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, May 22 

 BODY:
The Target Corporation said today that profit in its most recent quarter rose 6.3 percent as it pushed its expansion outside the Midwest and into big markets like New Jersey and Texas.
 Net income rose to $254 million, or 28 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter, compared with $239 million, or 26 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
Sales in the quarter, which ended May 5, rose 7.7 percent, to $8.35 billion. 
 The results matched analysts' expectations, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
The opening of 70 discount stores in the last year helped lift sales 11 percent at the Target chain, a smaller rival to Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the Kmart Corporation. Exclusive brands like Mossimo clothing and Michael Graves home goods attracted shoppers even as the slowing economy led many consumers to curb spending.
Target stores "differentiate themselves from a product standpoint," said Mark Miller, an analyst at William Blair & Company. "It gives them more of a buffer as opposed to some competitors who just compete on price."
Profit growth at Target, which is based in Minneapolis, was tempered by sales declines at the company's Mervyn's and Marshall Field's department stores. 
Sales at stores open at least a year rose 1.7 percent. That included a 2.8 percent gain at Target, a 1.6 percent decline at Mervyn's and a 4.5 percent drop at Marshall Field's.
Target's earnings forecasts are "consistent" with analysts' expectations of 30 cents a share for the second quarter and $1.55 a share for the full year, Doug Scovanner, the company's chief financial officer, said on a conference call.
Shares of Target rose $1.14 to $38.89.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Nasdaq Edges Higher While Blue Chips Drop Slightly

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors gravitated toward technology stocks again yesterday, sending the Nasdaq composite index slightly higher for a sixth consecutive session.
 Blue chips faltered, however, on a mix of company-specific news and profit taking and an expected pullback from the big advance that sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 464.95 points, or 4.3 percent, over the previous four sessions. 
 "I think the investment public is really falling back in love with technology and telecom and it's been a long, long time since that's been the case," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "It's not surprising though. If this economy is going to turn around, and it's showing signs that it is, the companies that are going to do the best, the fastest are going to be in the technology sector. It's a market leader." 
 The Nasdaq composite index closed up 8.26 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,313.85.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 80.68 points, or 0.7 percent, to 11,257.24, giving back the gains on Monday that sent it to its highest close since Jan. 20, 2000, when it reached 11,351.30.
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 3.45 points, or nearly 0.3 percent, to 1,309.38.
 Technology stocks struggled. Gainers included Microsoft, up $1.52 at $70.31, and Cisco Systems, up 61 cents at $23.48. But some other high-profile technology stocks fell, including Oracle, down 52 cents at $17.58.
 Blue chips were likewise choppy, reflecting profit taking from the big run-up last week. Among retailers, Home Depot slipped 39 cents, to $52.99, while Target was up $1.14 at $38.89 on better-than-expected earnings.
 Many stocks made moves based on individual companies' announcements rather than investors' overall worries about the economy or weak earnings reports, which have controlled trading activity in recent weeks.
 AOL Time Warner rose 64 cents, to $57.24; it announced that its America Online unit was increasing the monthly price of its unlimited use plan by about 9 percent, to $23.90.
 Investors punished Merck, which dropped $2.30, to $75.10, on concerns about the safety of its drug Vioxx and also that of Celebrex, made by Pharmacia and co-marketed by Pfizer. Pharmacia fell 52 cents, to $49.50, and Pfizer lost 72 cents, to $44.04.
 Analysts have been expecting investors, who still have concerns about when corporate profits will improve, to pull back and take profits from the market.
 After all, Wall Street has been rallying since early April, primarily in response to the five interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year. Money that was on the sidelines for months while the economy struggled has been coming back into the market, and some retreat was inevitable as investors took profits and adjusted their portfolios.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell yesterday on concern that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates for a sixth time this year, inciting enough growth to quicken inflation.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 2/32, to a price of 97 2/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.39 percent from 5.38 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 11/32, to 94 13/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.77 percent from 5.75 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Airline Based At Kennedy Expands West 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The slow pace of development at Kennedy Airport by the Port Authority is pushing JetBlue Airways, the fast-growing low-fare airline, to expand near Los Angeles.
 JetBlue plans to announce today that beginning on Aug. 29, it will fly twice a day between Long Beach Airport and Kennedy, and it will add 25 daily departures from California over the next two years to as many as 14 other cities, including Boston, Washington, Denver and Salt Lake City. 
 The move represents an important shift in strategy for JetBlue, which began operations last year with a plan to base its operations solely at Kennedy. It now has 38 flights a day from the airport to 14 destinations. But JetBlue says that it needs to keep growing to lower its operating costs, and that it will run out of gate space by the end of the year. It already has 14 Airbus jets, and expects to have 21 by the end of the year. 
The shift will also most likely step up criticism of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the airport, for not accommodating what is widely considered to be the airline industry's most successful start-up company in a generation.
When JetBlue announced its plans to fly from Kennedy in 1999, the Port Authority was reluctant to lease a terminal to an untested entrant. JetBlue ended up subleasing six gates at Kennedy's Terminal 6 from United Airlines while lobbying the agency with increasing urgency for permission to take over the terminal.
"We move a little more quickly than they do," said David Neeleman, JetBlue's chief executive. "We are just getting kind of boxed in. We need some place to put the planes."
Most cities lobby heavily for increased air service, especially from low-fare carriers, because it creates jobs and increases economic growth. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been an outspoken critic of the agency for its management of both Kennedy and La Guardia Airports.
Steve Coleman, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said yesterday that the agency was working with JetBlue to try to accommodate its growth but that nothing had been decided yet.
Mr. Neeleman said that he thought JetBlue would ultimately get its own terminal at Kennedy, and that it was committed to expanding its operations at the airport over the long term. "We still want to grow New York, but the growth rate will have to slow for a while," he said.
He said in an interview that Long Beach Airport had many of the same attributes that had attracted him to Kennedy. Its five runways are underused and are surrounded by a huge population base, of 6.5 million people.
The airport is situated between Los Angeles International Airport to the north and John Wayne Airport in Orange County to the south. But while both of those airports are operating at or above capacity, Long Beach is served only by American Airlines and America West Airlines, and each has only a few flights a day.
The airport also has the advantage of inexpensive landing fees, cheap and accessible parking and a convenient Art Deco terminal.
But it is surrounded by residential communities that are extremely sensitive to noise. In the early 1980's, the Long Beach City Council passed an ordinance limiting airlines to 18 daily departures. The law touched off more than a decade of litigation. Finally, in the mid-1990's, a judge ruled that the city could limit carriers to a total of 41 daily departures.
Commercial and cargo airlines are now making only 14 daily departures. Last week, the airport awarded the remaining 27 to JetBlue. The same day, the Long Beach City Council extended the period during which airlines must use the slots or forfeit them to 24 months from 6 months.
"The community is going to be very concerned," said Rob Webb, a city councilman whose district is directly under the airport's incoming flight path. But he said that under the court order, the council could not stop an airline from operating within the restriction.
JetBlue faced similar opposition from some residents near Kennedy Airport. Its new aircraft are much quieter than the older planes used by many start-up carriers. That helped persuade Mr. Webb to vote for the slot extension.
"If we have to have 41 flights, I want to see the most responsible and neighborhood-friendly 41 flights," he said.
The question is whether JetBlue can succeed at Long Beach, where several other start-up carriers like WinAir, Jet America and Sun Jet International have failed.
Modeled on the low-fare king, Southwest Airlines, JetBlue offers one-way transcontinental fares as low as $129 from Kennedy. It also serves several cities in Florida and upstate New York. Its aircraft offer one-class service with live satellite television at every one of its leather seats, and the airline prides itself on its friendly service.
Mr. Neeleman said that the airline was profitable after just six months, and that it would generate $330 million to $340 million in sales this year. It was financed with $130 million from several institutions, led by funds controlled by the financier George Soros. The original backers recently invested an additional $30 million at a significantly higher valuation, Mr. Neeleman said.
He said he understood the Port Authority's reluctance to give Jet-Blue the lease to a terminal at Kennedy before the airline had proved itself. But he said JetBlue now deserved more control over its destiny. 
"We think we have been really good for New York," he added. "We have done everything we said we would do in terms of service, noise and jobs. We just want to be appreciated for what we have done. I think the Port knows that, and it is going to work out well in the end."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
AOL Raising Monthly Rate 9%; a Rival May Follow Suit

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
America Online said yesterday that it would increase the price of its flagship online service by 9 percent, to $23.90 a month, in a striking show of confidence that its customers would remain loyal as its price rises further above those of its rivals.
 EarthLink, the distant No. 2 Internet service provider, charges $19.95 a month. And MSN from Microsoft charges $21.95, although it offers various rebates and deals that can bring the effective price to half that level. 
 America Online, which is now a unit of AOL Time Warner, presents itself as more than an Internet access provider, offering content, software and chat rooms that other service providers do not. And something in that proposition seems to resonate with users, as AOL has maintained an enormous lead over rivals. 
In February 1998, AOL increased its price $2, to $21.95. It told analysts at the time that it expected to lose about one month's worth of growth. Yet the increase did not seem to set the company back at all.
"When we did a price increase three years ago," said Barry Schuler, chairman of the America Online unit, "there was a short-term pause, then we went into the fastest period of growth in our history." 
AOL says that since its previous increase it has invested $3.5 billion adding telephone lines and network capacity. And its customers spend 50 percent more time online -- now 70 minutes a day -- than they did.
AOL Time Warner's chairman, Stephen M. Case, told investors in January that a price increase was "in the cards" for some point in the future. But some analysts expected that AOL would soften the blow by adding features to the service, like music downloading, when the price rose.
Mr. Schuler said yesterday that was not necessary. "People know us as a premium brand," he said.
Competitors agreed that in general, Internet users are not that price-sensitive and that AOL's move would not slow it down much.
Garry Betty, the chief executive of EarthLink, said that perhaps 10 percent to 15 percent of the market was interested in free or low-cost Internet service, and that those typically were not AOL customers. EarthLink's $2-a-month price advantage compared with AOL, he said, is far less important to its subscribers than its technology is.
Free Internet service providers, which hope to make money selling advertising, have had a tough time. Many have failed and the remaining ones have limited the number of free hours they offer.
Mr. Betty said that EarthLink, which has yet to make a profit, would consider raising its prices, as well. "We are happy about their move," he said. "It's a great response from a market leader that bespeaks the value that people get from the Internet and the need of providers to make money."
Microsoft said it had no plans to raise prices now.
AOL has 23 million subscribers in the United States, and about 80 percent of those pay the $21.95 rate for unlimited use. The rest have cheaper plans -- $4.95 a month for three hours or $9.95 for AOL's content but not Internet access -- or have been given free subscriptions with a new computer. Those plans are not affected by the price increase.
Assuming that AOL's subscriber base remains largely unchanged, the increase means that the company will take in about $430 million a year more in revenue. Analysts estimate that AOL will continue to grow at a record pace. Morgan Stanley, for instance, predicts that domestic subscriptions will increase to 25 million by the end of this year.
Even in the face of a deteriorating economy that is hurting nearly every other media company, AOL Time Warner has stuck to its revenue projection of $40 billion this year, up from $36 billion in 2000 for the old AOL and Time Warner combined. It projects pretax operating earnings of $11 billion, up from $8.2 billion.
The company says it could meet those targets without the AOL price increase, but analysts say the increase cannot hurt. "At the end of the day, it gives you higher confidence that they will make their targets," said Paul W. Noglows of J. P. Morgan. 
Unlike nearly every other Internet company, AOL -- without Time Warner -- is quite profitable. Its pretax operating earnings in the first quarter were $684 million on revenue of $2.1 billion.
In trading yesterday, AOL Time Warner's shares rose 64 cents, to $57.24.
