HEADLINE: Trading on Their Names; 
Turning Government Experience Into Corporate Advice

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
The promotional materials say it all: William S. Cohen, the former defense secretary, is shown chatting with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, sharing a smile with Nelson Mandela, standing shoulder to shoulder with President Jiang Zemin of China and in a "grip and grin" pose with President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, resplendent in his African robes and dark sunglasses. 
 The brochure is to announce the Cohen Group, a new consulting firm, which is trying to sell nothing so much as Mr. Cohen and his relationships around the globe. After meeting with world leaders in his 18 years as a Republican senator from Maine and his 4 years in the Clinton cabinet, Mr. Cohen is bringing his wealth of contacts and experience to bear for American corporations -- for a price. 
 Hoping to follow in the footsteps of Henry A. Kissinger, who started a consulting firm and made millions, and former President George Bush, who is a senior adviser to the Carlyle Group, a Washington investment firm, Mr. Cohen is selling his insights, door-opening skills and star power in a new twist on Washington's revolving door between government service and private gain. 
It is not lobbying exactly, at least as lobbying is defined by government ethics rules that preclude Mr. Cohen and other former federal officials from calling on departments where they once worked. There is no chance of that. What Mr. Cohen is doing is trading on his government connections to provide strategic advice to corporations in the private sector, where the government ethics rules do not apply and where the ante is higher.
As business becomes more global and the stakes rise, Mr. Cohen and several other former government officials have come up with innovative ways to market their influence and knowledge: telling companies whom to meet with in foreign countries, explaining which way the political and economic winds of other countries might be blowing and, often, accompanying corporate executives abroad to help open doors and make deals happen. For lack of a better term, it is called international strategic consulting.
Other senior aides to President Bill Clinton are doing the same, including his former national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; a former chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty III; the former ambassador to the United Nations, Richard C. Holbrooke; and the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, William E. Kennard.
"When you are in government, you get to meet hundreds, if not thousands of people at top levels of business and government, all over the world," said Peter G. Peterson, who was commerce secretary under President Richard M. Nixon and is now chairman of the Blackstone Group, a Wall Street investment firm. "People tend to have seen you in very important government negotiations. You often get access and credibility that may sometimes be difficult to get if you have only been in business."
Mr. Cohen, who started his firm with three other Pentagon officials two days after leaving office in January, said he was already dealing with "major major" business leaders. 
"They may be chief executives," he said, "but they may not be attuned to cultural issues, or how to approach the decision makers or even who the real decision makers are. They need advice on what to do."
In its first 100 days, the Cohen Group has been brought in to help an American manufacturer untangle problems in getting payments from its operations in Macedonia, is working with an aviation company seeking a Chinese partner, is helping another manufacturer close a deal in Oman and is advising a telecommmunications company on projects in Brazil and Chile.
While the Cohen Group says that confidentiality agreements preclude it from disclosing the names of its clients, the company, which operates out of a Washington office filled with photos of Mr. Cohen on Air Force One and with other Clinton officials, aims to have about 15 clients on retainer -- at fees that could range from $250,000 a year to, potentially, more than $1 million.
The granddaddy of this line of business is Mr. Kissinger, who started his advisory firm in 1982 and quickly lined up blue-chip clients like the American Express Company, I.B.M. and the American International Group, all of which paid handsomely for the former secretary of state's advice and representation. More recently, Mr. McLarty, who was Mr. Clinton's chief of staff early in his first term, joined him to create Kissinger McLarty Associates, adding clients like Exxon Mobil, United Parcel Service and Delta Air Lines.
"Companies want to minimize risk and maximize opportunities," Mr. McLarty said. "For instance, if a particular energy company has a desire to invest in a particular country, they want to be positioned correctly with the decision-making body. They want to affirm their credibility and put it in the most favorable light. They want to do that with the right tone and make sure that mistakes are not made."
James D. Robinson III, who traveled with Mr. Kissinger in Japan when Mr. Robinson was chief executive of American Express, put it more succinctly. "The more high horsepower you have," he said, "the more it helps you compete."
But where some see this as smart business, others see it differently.
"It's globalized influence peddling and lobbying," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit research group in Washington. "They are getting rich from the public trusts they held and are making money from their celebrity, not just in Washington, where it is the traditional thing to do, but internationally. These are senior advisers who have worked for years with the president and are well known. They have incredible cachet all over the world and are basically taking that to the bank."
In the case of Mr. Cohen, not only is he working for himself but he has entered into an array of strategic alliances, as he calls them, with other firms -- becoming the center of a hub-and-spoke system of business connections. He has strategic alliances with McDermott, Will & Emery, the nation's 10th-largest law firm; Fleishman-Hillard, a public relations firm; and Thayer Capital Partners, a private equity group, which is headed by Fred Malek, a former aide to Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
Mr. Cohen is also looking to add an investment bank and a hedge fund to provide one-stop shopping. In each of these affiliations, the idea is for the firms to work jointly on projects and to steer business to one another.
McDermott has retained the Cohen Group to offer advice to McDermott clients and to help with marketing. Next month, Mr. Cohen will hold a Silicon Valley seminar for potential clients in which he and Floyd Kvamme, a longtime venture capitalist who is advising President Bush on technology issues, will speak on "Navigating Washington -- and the World." 
Last week, 80 potential McDermott clients in Washington met with Mr. Cohen and his guest, Senator Susan Collins, a Maine Republican who once worked for Mr. Cohen in the Senate, to discuss opportunities in the military contracting business.
To keep his contacts and image fresh, Mr. Cohen appears regularly on political talk shows -- he was especially active during the Chinese spy plane crisis -- and since leaving the Pentagon he has hopped the globe to meet defense ministers from Poland to Oman and Sweden to Kuwait. He also joined the boards of Nasdaq, Global Crossing, Cendant and Head Sports.
"Bill Cohen can call on a head of state or a former minister," said Timothy J. Waters, managing partner at McDermott. "They will take a call from Cohen, and they won't take one from one of our partners. At least we can get an audience to make a point for our clients."
The arrangement has already paid off. "It's only been 100 days," Mr. Waters said, "but we've picked up new clients because of their awareness of our relationship with Bill."
Fleishman-Hillard, the public relations firm, pays Mr. Cohen for being on its advisory board and lets him use Fleishman's offices around the world. In return, Mr. Cohen will recommend Fleishman to his clients, and vice versa.
Last February, Mr. Cohen appeared on a panel in Washington dissecting the election for potential Fleishman clients. At Thayer Capital, Mr. Cohen is vice chairman of the firm's advisory board and will try to find investment opportunities and raise money. In return, Mr. Cohen will be able to invest in Thayer deals.
"We're looking for opportunities that will be mutually productive," said Mr. Malek of the Thayer Group.
Just down the street from Mr. Cohen's business in Washington is the office of Mr. Berger, the former national security adviser. He has just founded Stonebridge International, which has a strategic alliance with Lehman Brothers on Wall Street and with Hogan & Hartson, the Washington law firm where Mr. Berger once worked.
Mr. Holbrooke, a Wall Streeter turned diplomat, and James A. Johnson, former chief executive of Fannie Mae, the quasi-public finance agency, recently joined Perseus L.L.C., a merchant bank and private equity fund, as vice chairmen. In Washington, Mr. Kennard, the former F.C.C. chairman, joined the Carlyle Group as a managing director in its telecommunications practice. He was elected a director of The New York Times Company on May 15.
Mr. Berger, who is being joined by the former United States ambassador to Brazil, Anthony S. Harrington, is lining up about 15 clients on retainer, among them Duke Energy, and is being paid as an international consultant to Hogan & Hartson. He is also a paid senior adviser to Lehman Brothers and will get a fee from business that he does with Lehman.
"I have sat at the center of things for the last eight years," Mr. Berger said in an interview. "I have seen where economic and political developments are going and am familiar with the leaders and how they make decisions. To me, this is a continuation of what I've been doing in my career, which is to open markets and develop business."
Besides, to these former officials, after the pressure of working in the Clinton administration, business seems tamer. Mr. Cohen said the high-intensity 18-hour days in government made his work in starting a business seem like a slowing down.
"You are not dealing with life-and- death decisions, but commercial ones," he said. "You are not going to be woken up in the middle of the night and told that marines have been killed or that we bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade. Except for all the commercial travel, this is a lot easier."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 31, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on May 23 with an article about former public officials who have have gone into the business of providing advice to executives omitted a post once held by Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative under the first President George Bush. She was also secretary of housing and urban development under President Gerald Ford.

HEADLINE: Plan for Lifting Iraqi Controls Is Delayed 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 22 

 BODY:
Russia threw an unexpected roadblock today in the path of an American and British proposal to allow free trade in civilian goods with Iraq while tightening controls on military imports.
 On the first day of Security Council debate on the plan, Sergey Lavrov, the Russian ambassador, produced a counterproposal that would put off a decision for six months. China and France also cautioned against haste, threatening to derail or stall Council action well beyond the June 3 deadline set by Britain, the sponsor of the resolution, and the United States. 
 By that date, the Council must extend -- or revamp -- the program that allows Iraq to sell unlimited quantities of oil to pay for the needs of its civilian population, who are living under sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990. 
The proposal to lift controls on the import of civilian goods, and to make travel to Iraq easier, was intended to rob President Saddam Hussein of the excuse that foreigners are to blame for the suffering of ordinary Iraqis. A major objection to the proposal appears to be over a list of prohibited imports, which the United States is compiling. Apart from arms, Washington wants to restrict imports of certain technologies, communications equipment and some other goods.
Western diplomats hope that the Russian move is just an opening bid in what will be long and tough negotiations.
Mr. Lavrov said after the Council meeting that he was not rejecting the British and American proposal. "On the contrary," he said. "We want a serious -- and I stress a serious -- and constructive discussion of the U.K. draft, but we feel even at this stage that this will involve more time than is left before June 4," the date the next phase of the "oil for food" program would begin. 
"We've seen the proposal by the United Kingdom to have what the U.K. representative himself called a new concept, a radically new regime, and we have quite a number of questions, starting with a list, which we are invited to endorse and which is not yet made available." 
The French, who have apparently seen an early version of the list and decided that it was too broad, say it would be foolish to push ahead without consensus on the Security Council, or at least among the five permanent members -- Britain, Russia, China, France and the United States -- because a divided Council is weak in the face of Iraqi defiance. Also, any of those members, if isolated, could veto a resolution. 
Ambassador Shen Guofang, China's deputy representative, said he had sent the American and British proposal, which he described as "quite complicated," back to Beijing for review. "We need more time to study the resolution," he said, adding that it would be handed to technical experts while officials consulted with other governments. 
"But I doubt we can reach any consensus shortly," he said. He predicted that the current oil sales program would be continued in its present form while discussions go on, seeming to support the Russian stand. 
James B. Cunningham, the acting American representative on the Security Council, said after the meeting today that the United States was refining the list of suspect items and that he saw little reason for delay. "The concept and thrust is clear," he said. "It should be negotiable before the end of this phase." 
The next two weeks will be critical for the Iraq proposal, one of the Bush administration's first initiatives here. But the administration is still operating without a permanent representative at the United Nations and has not explained why it has not sent its nomination of John Negroponte to the Senate for confirmation. Other positions at the American Mission are also waiting to be filled. 
Many diplomats say that unless the White House and State Department are willing to engage in high-level negotiating on behalf of this Iraq resolution, the United States may face another setback here only a few weeks after losing seats on the United Nations Human Rights Commission and International Narcotics Control Board. 
While the British-American plan for Iraq would remove any remaining restrictions on trade in consumer goods and material for rebuilding public services, it would retain control of Iraqi oil profits through United Nations-administered escrow accounts. Iraq must draw on those for purchases. Some of that money is set aside for war reparations, for the Kurds in the north and for United Nations expenses. 
In general, sanctions imposed after Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait, and reaffirmed in 1991 after the gulf war, cannot be suspended or fully lifted until the Iraqis allow arms inspectors to return. 
The last inspectors in Iraq were withdrawn by the United Nations Special Commission in December 1998, ahead of American and British bombing. After a year of stalemate, during which Iraq did not permit the return of inspectors, a new system, the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission, was created by the Security Council. Iraq has barred its inspectors also. 
This week, Iraqi officials said they would not cooperate with a new "oil for food" program either. Western diplomats say Iraq's acceptance or rejection is irrelevant to the Council's action. But in Baghdad on Monday, Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz threatened to suspend the "oil for food" program entirely and to stop pumping oil. 
Secretary General Kofi Annan, who met with the Security Council today to discuss the Middle East, said he hoped that would not happen. "If Iraq were to stop the program or refuse to participate in the program, the Secretariat will have no means of providing assistance to the Iraqi people," he said. "We use the resources from the sale of the oil to do that." 
Mr. Annan said he hoped that the program would continue, since the effort was intended to help the Iraqi people. "But if Iraq were to turn off the taps," he said, "then we'd be in a very serous situation." Iraq has exported more than $40 billion in oil since the current program began in 1996. Yet it continues to stall in ordering needed supplies, according to a report covering the last six months and submitted to the Security Council by Mr. Annan on May 18. 
"Much to my regret," he wrote, as of May 14 "the office of the Iraq program had not received a single application in the sectors of health, education, water and sanitation and oil spare parts." Orders for housing, electricity, transportation, communications, food handling and agriculture fell below targets. 
On the other hand, the report said that nearly 18 percent of the total value of contracts sent to the sanctions committee for review had been blocked by Council members. 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 25, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about efforts at the United Nations to block the new British-American proposal on regulating trade with Iraq referred incorrectly to the nomination of John Negroponte as American ambassador to the organization. The White House has indeed acted; it sent the nomination to the Senate on May 14.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
Moving the United Nations, But Keeping the Benefits

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
AS it does every now and then, New York City settled yesterday on a foreign policy that does not quite match the one shaped by Washington, which fancies itself as speaking for Americans on international affairs.
 Taiwan is a country, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suggested after meeting in Midtown with the visiting Taiwanese president, Chen Shui-bian. The only problem, as the mayor acknowledged, is that the United States has not recognized Taiwan as a country for more than two decades. 
 What are you going to do? Long before Mr. Giuliani arrived on the scene, New York mayors saw no reason to fall reflexively in lock step with the foreign policy muck-a-mucks in Washington. Some things are too important to leave to the professionals. 
That independent streak on international matters brings us to the sermon of the day. It deals with the United Nations, a source of irritation as well as pride for New Yorkers.
Right now, Americans are not exactly brimming with affection for that organization, given the heave-ho that they got this month from the United Nations Human Rights Commission. New York could lead the charge for America by encouraging the United Nations to do something that some, including a mayor or two, have suggested for a long time: 
Move.
Not out of the country, or even to another American city. This move would be rather modest, taking the United Nations from its perch along the East River and relocating it on Governors Island, the unused former military base in New York Harbor.
That way, red-meat American patriots could claim to have sent the United Nations a powerful message, by isolating it more than it is now on the far eastern reaches of Manhattan. At the same time, the city would not have to forgo the substantial benefits that the diplomats provide.
It is the conceit of New Yorkers that the diplos need us more than we need them, that the foreigners do nothing all day but pop into overpriced restaurants and look for places to double-park. Conveniently overlooked in the stereotyping is the fact that the United Nations helps fill our pockets. It generates, by the city's own estimates, more than $3 billion a year in economic activity.
With a shift to Governors Island, that money can be preserved (most of it anyway -- some East Side restaurants would lose lunch traffic). And there would be important pluses, as Carol Goldberg of Syosset, N.Y., pointed out in a letter to this newspaper last September, when the United Nations was holding its "millennium summit."
Traffic jams would be eased on the East Side, she said. When there are huge gatherings, arriving world leaders could be flown directly by helicopter from the airports to the United Nations complex.
Security, always a worry, would be more manageable on Governors Island. And instead of staring at the Pepsi-Cola sign in Long Island City, as they do now, delegates and visitors would enjoy "inspiring views," in Ms. Goldberg's words, of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. 
NOR is any of this a radical thought. As far back as the 1940's, Governors Island was Mayor William O'Dwyer's site recommendation for the nascent world organization.
Maybe it's time. The alternative seems to be endless squabbling among local, state and federal authorities over what to do with the island. Besides, the United Nations headquarters is run-down.
Its roofs leak. It lacks a decent sprinkler system. Asbestos must be removed. Space is inadequate. "Clearly, we've been living on borrowed time," said Joseph E. Connor, the under secretary general for management, who estimated that getting the place in shape would cost nearly $1 billion.
With that much money at stake, why not start from scratch on Governors Island? Granted, no one at the United Nations is clamoring to move. "It's a matter of being content where we are, with a building that's instantly recognized all over the world," Mr. Connor said.
But Mr. Giuliani is not without persuasive powers. A few years ago, he managed to get some of the worst diplomatic offenders to start obeying New York's traffic rules. Perhaps he could apply his talents to this issue. As an incentive for him, the name could be changed to Mayors Island.
He'd probably like that.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Calls Taiwan a 'Country' During Leader's Visit 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met yesterday morning with the president of Taiwan, referred afterward to the island of 22 million people as a "remarkable country," then scoffed at Chinese reporters who heatedly asked if the mayor planned to recognize Taiwan as its own nation. 
 "Well, I don't get to recognize countries," an exasperated Mr. Giuliani said at a City Hall news conference after his meeting with the Taiwanese leader, Chen Shui-bian, at the Waldorf Towers. "I'm not the State Department." He added, "And the State Department said it was O.K. to visit with him. So, you can now go out and make a big deal out of it in some distorted way if you want. That's your job." 
 Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, Sunny Mindel, said later that the mayor's reference to Taiwan as a country was "a manner of speaking" and not a political statement at odds with the United States policy of recognizing only one Chinese government. A State Department official shrugged off the mayor's remarks. "Rudy Giuliani doesn't represent U.S. policy," said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Although the United States does not recognize Taiwan as a country, critics of China, among them many Republicans, often refer to it as one.
Mr. Giuliani's comments, and Mr. Chen's visit to New York City, come at a delicate time in relations between Washington and Beijing.
Last month President Bush seemed to upgrade relations with Taiwan when he said that the United States would do "whatever it takes" to defend it, but he also said later that Taiwan should not declare independence or provoke an attack by China. His administration later gave Mr. Chen, over angry Chinese opposition, permission to stop briefly in the United States on his way to and from Latin America.
But the official position of the United States government is that the visit is unofficial, even though more than two dozen members of Congress took an Air Force jet from Andrews Air Force base outside Washington on Monday evening to have dinner with Mr. Chen at the Waldorf Towers. "He certainly seemed to be enjoying the fact that he had freedom of movement and that he was being treated like a world leader," said Representative Peter King of Long Island, a Republican, who was there. "Unlike the last time, when he was treated like he was under house arrest."
Mr. King was referring to Mr. Chen's last pass through the United States, in August, when the Clinton administration sequestered him in his hotel room in Los Angeles and discouraged members of Congress from visiting him.
Still, Mr. Chen moved about the city yesterday like a world leader who was under an order of silence, which he was in effect. He held no news conferences and made no public statements. Even Mr. Giuliani was whisked into an 8 a.m. meeting with Mr. Chen without speaking to reporters who stood in a rain-drenched clump on the sidewalk.
Mr. Chen was then driven to the New York Stock Exchange, where his limousine sped by reporters waiting outside the main entrance and turned a corner to let the president in the side door. Mr. Chen was given a tour of the old and new trading floors by Richard A. Grasso, the exchange's chairman, who did not return a call seeking comment. Later in the day, Mr. Chen toured the Jacqueline Kennedy exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but not with Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director, who was said to be in internal meetings.
"This has never been portrayed as an official visit," said Harold Holzer, the museum's spokesman.
Mr. Giuliani, who noted in his news conference that he was friendly with him from Mr. Chen's days as mayor of Taipei, said much of the meeting was devoted to discussions of expanding economic relationships between Taiwan and New York.
"Taiwan is a remarkable country when you consider the size of the country, the population, and what it's able to produce and the economy it's been able to build and grow," Mr. Giuliani said. He added that Taiwan was "a great and strong ally of the United States, and an outpost of democracy."
China's anger at Mr. Chen's visit is likely to be heightened by another event today, a scheduled meeting between President Bush and the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader. China controls Tibet and resents any official recognition of the Dalai Lama or his cause. Mr. Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said yesterday that "the president considers the Dalai Lama an important spiritual and religious leader and looks forward to his visit."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan, outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he toured the Jacqueline Kennedy exhibition yesterday. (Matt Moyer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dogged Fight by Senate Democrats Delays Tax Cut Bill 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22 

 BODY:
Lacking the votes to block the $1.35 trillion tax cut moving through Congress, Democrats in the Senate delayed its passage today to make their argument one final time that the plan was fiscally irresponsible and excessively tilted to the wealthy.
 Democrats offered dozens of amendments, each of which went down to defeat, gumming up what Republicans had hoped would be a quick path to passage for the tax measure. 
 By the end of the day, Republicans were increasingly pessimistic about reaching their goal of completing work on the bill and sending it to President Bush for his signature by the end of the week.
For Republicans, the job will only become more complicated if Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, switches parties on Wednesday. 
After working through amendments until just before midnight on Monday, weary senators trooped on and off the Senate floor for votes on Democratic amendments until the chamber adjourned this evening. While intended in part to make a political point about the differences in priorities between the parties, the amendments also seemed designed simply to frustrate the Republicans and Mr. Bush.
On that score, the Democrats succeeded. By insisting on votes on amendments through the evening, Democrats forced Republicans to miss a Republican National Committee gala fund-raising dinner with President Bush.
"I want the Congress to pass tax relief now," Mr. Bush told reporters at the White House. "Congress ought to stop delay and move forward."
Democratic leaders were unapologetic.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said, "These issues are too important to say we ought to, just for the convenience of the Senate or the convenience of somebody, try to finish up because it's a neat way to do it by Memorial Day."
The Democratic amendments sought to pare parts of the tax cut, especially those primarily aiding upper-income people, and to provide more money for health care, education and tax provisions that would benefit lower-income people.
But Democrats repeatedly came up short. A proposal by Mr. Daschle to replace the $1.35 trillion tax cut with a $900 billion plan was defeated, with 58 votes against it and 41 in favor. Nine Democrats voted against Mr. Daschle's plan, suggesting that they would join nearly all of the Senate's 50 Republicans to pass the $1.35 trillion plan.
Mr. Daschle offered another amendment to reduce the top tax rate to 38.6 percent from 39.6 percent rather than to the 36 percent in the bill, and to use the savings to expand the 15 percent tax bracket. The vote on that amendment was 50 to 50. Under Senate rules an amendment is defeated on a tie vote. 
Republicans said Democrats were playing politics with the economy by holding up passage of the bill, which contains $100 billion in tax cuts for this year and next that Republicans say would help ward off a recession.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said it was "important to get this tax relief package done as soon as possible, without trying to just put a day or a week on it, because it is going to be good for job security and for the economy."
Even before voting on the bill, Republicans were at work on the next stage of their effort, working out differences between the Senate and House versions. After the chambers reconcile their tax bills, they will vote on a final bill that would then be sent to the White House. 
"I think that we know pretty much where the conference may be able to go," Mr. Lott. 
Republicans in the House would like the top income tax rate to come down closer to the 33 percent proposed by Mr. Bush. They would also like to scale back or eliminate a provision in the Senate bill that would allow low-income workers who do not pay any federal income taxes to receive part of the child credit. Under both the House and Senate versions, the child credit would gradually double, to $1,000.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said the House negotiators would be flexible about reducing the top rate if the final bill included provisions permitting upper-income taxpayers to claim more deductions and credits. 
The delays were clearly creating tension on both sides of the aisle. Senators spoke openly of the strain of the long series of votes on some of their frailer colleagues. 
Late Monday night, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, offered to allow Senator Strom Thurmond, the 98-year-old Republican from South Carolina, to go home; Mr. Biden said he would offset Mr. Thurmond's absence by not casting his own vote, but the Senate adjourned soon afterward.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Senators Christopher J. Dodd, Byron L. Dorgan, Tom Daschle and Hillary Rodham Clinton, above, left to right, made the case against the tax cut measure for the Democrats yesterday. Meanwhile, the Republicans, represented in their own Capitol Hill news conference by Senators Larry E. Craig, Charles E. Grassley, Rick Santorum and Kay Bailey Hutchison, defended the $1.35 trillion tax bill. (Photographs by Susana Raab for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush vs. the American Landscape 

BYLINE:  By Robert Redford; Robert Redford, the actor and director, is a board member of the Natural Resources Defense Council.

DATELINE: NASHVILLE 

 BODY:
Listening to President Bush's speech on energy last week left me yearning for a straight story. His rhetoric seemed intended either to frighten or to lull one into a false sense of security. It didn't help that as he presented an energy plan -- developed with help from lobbyists for oil, coal, gas, mining and nuclear power -- the president buttoned up his speech by asking all of us to stop bickering, to set a new tone and listen to each other. Since Vice President Dick Cheney refused even to meet with environmental groups, it seems a rather curious, if not disingenuous, request.
 Mr. Bush made it sound so simple. Build tens of thousands of miles of new pipelines, hundreds of oil and gas wells, and more than a thousand new power plants, and it will again be "morning in America." He claims it can be done with little impact. Drilling in the Arctic, off our beaches or anywhere determined to be "necessary" is a harmless matter, he says, thanks to new technologies that render the whole enterprise environmentally friendly. This is simply untrue. 
 Mr. Cheney has been making a point of telling anyone who will listen that the federal government hasn't granted a new nuclear power permit in 20 years. Nobody has applied for one. Three Mile Island served as a cautionary tale that even the most aggressive corporate energy interests could not ignore. Until now. The president's support for nuclear power is boldly presented with nary a nod to inherent risks associated with nuclear waste, nuclear weapons material or power plant accidents.
A look behind the rhetoric reveals that at the heart of the Bush energy plan are proposals to weaken longstanding environmental safeguards. Americans fought hard over the last three decades for these protections. But the Bush plan holds the corporate energy lobby in higher esteem than ordinary Americans who breathe the air, drink the water and overwhelmingly support protecting our wilderness. Coal and oil companies, despite record profits, now seek enormous new taxpayer subsidies and relief from environmental safeguards as payback for their campaign support.
Drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is but a piece of a plan that makes oil and gas exploration and development fair game on nearly all of our public lands, even extraordinary places that were awarded protection as national monuments by the previous administration. The Upper Missouri Breaks in Montana, Grand Staircase-Escalante monument in Utah, and Vermillion Basin in northwestern Colorado may all become subject to exploitation. It's nonsense to think new oil and gas exploration and development won't destroy these incomparable wild places.
Why not tighten fuel economy standards instead? This alone could, over the next 50 years, free up 15 times as much oil as could be produced by drilling in the Arctic, and it would benefit consumers much faster. The administration wants merely to "study" this option. More study? Well, we know what that means. For electricity, simply supporting the higher air conditioner efficiency standards proposed by the previousadministration would save 13,000 megawatts during periods of peak demand in 2020, equivalent to the output of dozens of power plants.
Thirty years ago, corporate America danced across the nation dumping toxic waste into our rivers, spewing chemicals into our air and ravaging pristine public lands, all in the name of progress. In response to the horrific environmental damage of the postwar era, a broad coalition of Americans began working to represent public health, safety and environmental concerns in all levels of government. Now we face an administration trying to unravel this work.
Unfortunately, we have the examples of Three Mile Island and Chernobyl, the Exxon Valdez accident and innumerable studies proving pollution's ill effect on public health to demonstrate that the stakes could hardly be higher. Solid science clearly shows that global warming exists and that the administration's drill, dig and burn approach will only make it worse. I continue to hope for a reasonable dialogue that actually includes the environmental community, but the administration's posture suggests that is unlikely. If he does not make environmental concerns central to his energy policy, President Bush may well leave the next generation with nothing but ashes to stand in.

HEADLINE: The Chinese See 1-2 Punch in Asian Visits 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 22 

 BODY:
It is just a coincidence, of course, that President Bush will have a well-publicized "private meeting" with the Dalai Lama on, of all days, May 23. 
 The meeting was condemned today by Chinese officials, who have spent the last week extolling May 23 as an important anniversary in the "liberation" of Tibet. They have also been shrilly denouncing the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader, as a wicked proponent of serfdom and a "scum" who wants to split the motherland. 
 A government spokesman urged American leaders to "stop interfering in China's internal affairs" by permitting official meetings with the Dalai Lama, and warned of "harm to Chinese-American relations" from further coddling of a separatist. 
The scheduled White House meeting follows another act this week that China saw as a deliberate jab in the eye -- the Bush administration's decision to allow a high-profile three-day stopover in New York by Taiwan's president, Chen Shui-bian, including an unprecedented dinner meeting on Monday night with about 20 members of Congress. 
Under the original 1970's agreement by which the United States recognized the leadership in Beijing as the sole government of China, Washington is supposed to avoid high official contacts with Taiwanese leaders. At the Foreign Ministry today, the same spokesman who condemned the Dalai Lama's welcome had equally harsh words for the Chen visit, charging that it violates bilateral agreements and has "inflamed the arrogance of the independence forces on Taiwan." 
The White House announced Monday that Mr. Bush would meet the Dalai Lama in a private capacity, because he is a "Nobel laureate and a world-renowned spiritual leader." 
While President Clinton also met the Dalai Lama, Mr. Clinton only did so in a brief, supposedly unscheduled encounter as the Dalai Lama visited others. With the trumpeted meeting on Wednesday, the Bush administration, in Chinese eyes, is worsening its crime. 
Wednesday is also the anniversary of the ill-fated 1951 agreement between Chinese Communists and beleaguered Tibetan leaders. China now commemorates that agreement, which followed the Communist army's victory over Tibetan forces, as "the peaceful liberation of Tibet," while the Dalai Lama and his supporters say it was signed at gunpoint and soon invalidated by China's heavy-handed tactics. 
China long asserted some form of sovereignty over the Tibetan plateau but its actual control varied through the centuries. Under the so-called 17-point agreement signed in Beijing on May 23, 1951, with a Tibetan leader, the young Communist government officially incorporated Tibet into the new nation and asserted its right to send in troops. But it also promised to allow the region autonomy in social and religious affairs. 
The two sides differ on what caused the deepening conflicts in the years that followed, but in 1959, as the Chinese suppressed a major uprising by Tibetans in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, the 14th Dalai Lama fled to exile in India and repudiated the 1951 agreement as having been coerced. 
After that, China abandoned elements of the agreement, imposing Communist administration on the region. Then, especially in the decade of Mao's Cultural Revolution, 1966 to 1976, the Tibetan religion was suppressed, with many monks imprisoned or killed and temples destroyed. 
In the last two decades of "reform and opening up," China has allowed a controlled revival of Tibetan religion and even aided the rebuilding of monasteries, though it has also continually waged war on popular allegiance to the Dalai Lama, and tensions remain high. 
China now trumpets the 1951 agreement as validating its rule over Tibet and the economic and cultural changes it has wrought, notes the Tibetan Information Network, a London-based group that supports the Dalai Lama.
In conjunction with public ceremonies planned in Lhasa, Chinese and Tibetans throughout the country this week have been subjected to an especially intense propaganda campaign intended to discredit the exiled leader and to glorify the achievements under Communist rule. 
"Betrayers of the motherland and the scum of the nation are not welcome at the temple and the Dalai Lama is one of them," a lama at the Zhaxi Lhunbo lamasery, one of six major temples of the Dalai's own sect, is quoted as saying in a typical article suggesting that Tibetans have rejected the Dalai's leadership. Chinese authorities have removed any lamas who overtly support the Dalai Lama. 
Articles have blamed Tibet's poverty on "the jeopardizing activities of the Dalai Lama clique and anti-China forces in the West." But they have also described enormous economic progress in recent years, asserting that the region has maintained an economic growth rate of 12.9 percent for the last six years and that only 2.7 percent of Tibet's people now live below the poverty line, a line China sets at $72 a year a person. 
A May 14 article in the Liberation Army Daily waxed about the cruelty and backwardness of Tibet before the Communist liberation and had this to say about the exiled leader: "Facts have amply proven that the Dalai is the chief representative of the feudal serf-owning class in Tibet, the chief ringleader of the national separatists inside and outside the border and the loyal tool of the Western anti-China forces." 
In yet another step that has annoyed Chinese leaders, Mr. Bush has appointed the highest-level official yet to serve as coordinator for Tibetan issues, a position created by Congress to promote dialogue between Beijing and the Dalai Lama and to work to protect Tibetan identity. 
Paula J. Dobriansky, the new under secretary of state for global affairs, will also be the Tibet coordinator, the administration recently announced.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Power Gains in Status After Lobbying 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22 

 BODY:
As the White House was putting together the energy plan that President Bush released last week, there had been almost no talk of nuclear power as a component of the nation's energy strategy. The nuclear industry thought this was a glaring omission, and a handful of top nuclear industry officials decided they needed to take their case to the administration. 
 In mid-March, a cadre of seven nuclear power executives sought and won an hourlong meeting in the White House with Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's top political adviser. Also attending were Lawrence B. Lindsey, the president's top economic adviser, Andrew Lundquist, the executive director of Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force, and others involved in devising the energy plan. 
 "We said, Look, we are an important player on this energy team and here are our vital statistics, and we think that you should start talking about nuclear when you talk about increasing the nation's supply," Christian H. Poindexter, chairman of the Constellation Energy Group, recalled today.
And then a surprising thing happened.
"It was shortly after that, as a matter of fact I think the next night, when the vice president was being interviewed on television, he began to talk about nuclear power for the first time," Mr. Poindexter said.
Mr. Cheney first discussed nuclear power as an alternative to dirtier fossil fuels in a March 21 interview on CNBC. "If you want to do something about carbon dioxide emissions," he said, "then you ought to build nuclear power plants because they don't emit any carbon dioxide, they don't emit greenhouse gases." 
Mr. Cheney had missed the meeting with nuclear executives because he was on Capitol Hill, talking to members of Congress who themselves were pushing nuclear energy.
In a quick chain reaction, Mr. Cheney put the long-maligned nuclear power industry back on the political map. In the energy plan released last week, the administration breathed new life into the industry, declaring nuclear technology, which provides 20 percent of the nation's electricity, much safer than it was 20 years ago.
Today, Mr. Cheney appeared before 350 nuclear industry executives meeting in Washington -- 100 more than showed up at last year's annual meeting of the Nuclear Energy Institute -- and told them the administration wanted to encourage the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to expedite applications for new reactors, relicense existing plants and "increase the resources devoted to safety and enforcement as we prepare to increase nuclear generating capacity in the future." He said the administration also wanted to renew the Price-Anderson Act, which limits nuclear plant operators' liability in case of an accident.
Mr. Poindexter is still incredulous. "In my wildest dreams, when I was over at the White House in March, I couldn't imagine them getting so behind us," he said.
He was skeptical for good reason. Few industries have enjoyed the kind of renaissance that nuclear power may be poised to undergo. Accidents at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania and Chernobyl in Ukraine seemed to seal the industry's fate as too dangerous, too uncontrollable and too expensive to win back a frightened public or secure the financial backing of Wall Street.
The last nuclear power plant to enter operation was ordered in 1973. There still is no solution to the vexing problem of nuclear waste storage. And while recent polling shows that Americans more lopsidedly oppose dirtier fossil fuels than they oppose nuclear power, they still do not want to live near nuclear power plants.
For those wary of a nuclear revival, these problems are no less real today than they were two decades ago.
"The Bush administration should at most be looking to proceed with what the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was planning -- an orderly phase-out of existing power plants," said Paul L. Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute and co-director of the Senate investigation into the 1979 accident at Three Mile Island. "Instead, they're talking about a new rebirth, and it frankly just doesn't make sense."
The Union of Concerned Scientists, using data from the industry itself, says that aging plants have experienced eight forced shutdowns in the last 16 months.
And Mr. Leventhal said that replacing coal with nuclear power would not appreciably diminish global warming because most of the pollutants that cause global warming come from cars and trucks. 
Another problem, and one that Mr. Cheney fully acknowledges, is the lack of a national repository for the storage of nuclear waste. In his speech today, the vice president warned that the lack of a storage site could be a deal killer. Without a site, he said, "eventually the contribution we can count on from the nuclear industry will, in fact, decline."
The storage problem will not be solved at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, if Nevada politicians and the gambling industry have anything to say about it. Senators Harry Reid, a Democrat, and John Ensign, a Republican, have made opposition to nuclear waste dumping in their state their priority.
"Until they get the waste problem solved," Mr. Reid said, "nothing's going to happen on nuclear power." 
Peter Bradford, a former member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, who now teaches energy policy at Yale, said that apart from the safety issues, nuclear power was economically problematic.
"The types of long-term investment necessary to sustain nuclear energy are going to prove very hard to find in this kind of volatile marketplace," Mr. Bradford said.
Still, there are cheerleaders. One is Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who heads the Energy and Commerce Committee. He spoke today at the Nuclear Energy Institute's annual meeting and summed up the surprise that others feel at the recent turn of events.
"As we gather here in Washington," Mr. Tauzin said, "who would have thunk that we'd be discussing the possibility of nuclear construction in this country?"

HEADLINE: For One Web Site, Some Explaining to Do 

BYLINE:  By LISA GUERNSEY 

DATELINE: CARY, N.C. 

 BODY:
MARSHALL BRAIN cannot sit still. When he sits in meetings for his company HowStuffWorks, his left leg pulses restlessly. When he talks, his hands are always busy -- twisting a rubber band, playing with pocket pliers or massaging a Swiss Army knife he has kept for 20 years. Its red paint has worn to a shiny silver. 
 But at least one project stops Mr. Brain, 40, from fidgeting: the act of taking something apart. On a recent Thursday he appeared almost serene as he took a power screwdriver in hand, removed the plastic casing from a wheeled toy robot and gazed at the gears and circuit boards inside. 
 "Look," Mr. Brain said, running his hands over the robot's wheels. "It's actually four-wheel drive."
Fortunately for Mr. Brain, a growing audience shares his curiosity. Three years ago, Mr. Brain created the HowStuffWorks Web site (www.howstuffworks.com), which explains, in depth, the inner workings of almost anything. This month, for example, the site's topics include "How Roller Coasters Work," "How Four-Wheel-Drive Systems Work," "How Night Vision Works" and a popular recent addition, "How Human Reproduction Works." 
More than 500,000 people a month visit the site, according to Jupiter Media Metrix, and in the past two years, the site has won awards from education and technology groups. Educators may have their pick of smaller Web sites to use in class, said Gerry Wheeler, executive director of the National Association of Science Teachers, but "they don't have the quality control or sustainability that HowStuffWorks does." 
Mr. Brain, who never tires of explaining that, yes, Brain is his real surname, is something of a role model among Web masters, someone who built a home page out of a personal passion only to find a worldwide audience interested in his work. A former computer programmer, he started the Web site as a part-time project in 1998, writing his first article from the kitchen table at his farmhouse in Zebulon, N.C., occasionally gazing out the window at his chicken coop. His first article, "How Car Engines Work," is still one of the Web site's most popular. 
"When I was 16, one of the things that fascinated me most was engines," Mr. Brain said. He once watched his neighbor take a car engine apart, work on it, and then put it back together. "I thought he was a genius," he said. 
Now, as the Web has become more commercially driven, Mr. Brain's Web site continues to be a symbol of the times. He built the site as a free, educational resource but soon realized that it would never be able to grow or pay for equipment to handle the traffic without a source of revenue. In 1999, he turned the site into a for-profit company, became its chief executive, found private investors, hired 35 employees and leased space in an office park here. 
So far, he has tried multiple strategies to make money -- including an online toy store (which he called a flop), banner advertising (which has not been terribly lucrative, either) and a company-sponsored student magazine (two issues of which have been published so far, and which Mr. Brain thinks may hold the most promise). He is also starting to license radio and television programs based on his Web site's content.
HowStuffWorks could be the subject of a yet-to-be-finished feature of its own: How a Dot-Com Works. It is a puzzle that Mr. Brain has not entirely solved, and on the day he dissected the toy robot, he acknowledged that it was on his mind. It had been a good week. An article called "How Lock Picking Works" had surpassed the popularity of the piece on the car engine. (The title spurred debate among his staff members, but the editors decided the catchy title was worth the risk.) The site's operations were running smoothly and its six writers -- including Mr. Brain -- appeared to be hitting their stride. But a business meeting the next day would bring the real test. The subject was whether the company could attract a new group of investors even as the stock market was sinking.
"Will the positive momentum carry through until Friday?" Mr. Brain asked rhetorically, driving his pick-up truck to the farm he shares with his wife, Leigh, and two children. He calls himself an optimist -- a "glass-half-full kind of person" -- but he had already figured out what would happen in a worst-case scenario. "The site goes back to one guy, working part time," he said, matter-of-factly. 
Less than a decade ago, Mr. Brain was a computer-science instructor at North Carolina State University and a software programmer who wrote technical books on the side. In 1997, he wrote and published "The Teenager's Guide to the Real World," to address some of the things he said he wished he had known in high school, where as a slightly geeky teenager he struggled to fit in. His mission in all his writing, he said, is to put technical concepts into terms that can easily be digested by general readers, a technique he has employed more fully on the HowStuffWorks site. 
"It is written in a way that most people understand," said Scott Barber, a seventh-grade science teacher at Roehm Middle School in Berea, Ohio, who calls the Web site "a gold mine." One day last December, for example, Mr. Barber used an article titled "How CD's Work" as a springboard for in-class projects. "It was a magical day in the classroom," he said. 
Mr. Brain seems as if he would be comfortable in a classroom, too -- as a student. On this Thursday, he is wearing jeans and white tennis shoes as he strides past cubicles, strewn with motor parts, loose screws and batteries, where writing projects are in progress. As he talks with his employees, he seems more comfortable asking questions than giving answers. To write an article on how cells work two years ago, he bought a half-dozen biology books, including a 1,300-page college textbook, and chewed over the diagrams for weeks. 
"It took me six months to write that article," Mr. Brain said. "It turns out that we don't know a thing about how cells work." 
More unknowns lie ahead for Mr. Brain. Although the Friday meeting brought good news -- interest from another potential investor -- the future still looks shaky for content-based Web sites, especially those that are free. But complaining about the downturn in the economy -- or anything else, for that matter -- would not be Mr. Brain's style. This is a man who had the foresight to buy the domain name HowStuffDoesntWork but who has said he had no plans to use it. "It would end up as a place that has negative energy," he said. 
Clearly, Mr. Brain is more interested in things that do work. As he turned the toy robot over in his mind, another question started to bother him. "Why do they need five circuit boards in this thing?" he asked.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?; 
Sheer, Summery Curtains For the Gossamer Budget

BYLINE:  By MARIANNE ROHRLICH 

 BODY:
 Susan Kirshenbaum, a headhunter in New York, needed almost a hundred yards of fabric to drape over the windows in her Long Island beach house. "I wanted curtains sheer enough to let some light in, but opaque enough for privacy," she said. 
"And they had to be fluid and blow in the wind." On top of that, she had a very low budget. Humble drapery-lining fabric, either pure cotton or a cotton and polyester blend, met all her requirements. "Lining is perfect for a summery look that is economical," said Stan Fradin, president of Rockland Mills, a manufacturer of the fabric. Treated so it won't fade or discolor, it can be made water-repellent. Some weights will block light and provide some temperature control. Lining is as good for pinch-pleated draperies as for cafe curtains or flat panels. It's available in many colors as well as white, and costs from $3 to $6.50 a yard at Joe's Fabrics Warehouse, 102 Orchard Street (Delancey Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

HEADLINE: Making the Most Of a Gift Horse; 
In a Housing Project's Free-Computer Experiment, Wariness Yields to Motivation: It's 'for the Kids'

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE 

 BODY:
THE mother closed in with the mouse. Her small children crowded by her at the keyboard, their faces aglow from the screen as she clicked on to the attempt at making their grand electronic leap beyond the housing project.
 "This is how you do it, Mom," Kalif, her 5-year-old, authoritatively interrupted Charnita Johnson. But she needed no help, moving through her options with a fierce determination as her 3-month-old, Michael, slept through it all against her breast. 
 The screen shifted kaleidoscopically through a world of possibilities as the unemployed 24-year-old mother made steady progress in one of the more unusual public housing adventures in the country: an experiment to provide poor people like Ms. Johnson not just mastery of mouse and keyboard, but computers of their own. "For the kids," she emphasized as the evening lesson proceeded at the Edgar Allan Poe Homes. 
A good deal was at stake in the class in the project's new Townes at the Terraces complex. Residents were midway through a 20-hour basic course that is the prerequisite for receiving a Dell computer each, fully installed in their apartments. The complex was built with high-speed Internet connections for creation of an electronic village to let residents chat locally or reach out ambitiously to the world. 
"Come on, we can do it," Steven Johnson, the 34-year-old computer instructor at the Poe project, implored as he led Ms. Johnson, no relation, and the rest of his evening class to the crest of a singular experience: the minting of their own e-mail addresses.
Ms. Johnson leaned into the screen, telling Kalif to shush, her face an open study of mixed emotions -- the doubt that her e-mail address could ever happen, the resolve that it must.
The computer came back at her with a gentle crackle of guidance, and Charnita Johnson soon faced her first epiphany on the Internet: There is more than one Charnita in that supposedly alien digital world. She seemed fascinated by this news. She instantly plunged back into the search for an address of her own. 
Soon, click, crackle and she had it: Charnita with a signature wrinkle or two -- an underscore, a J, and there she was. Before her own eyes, she was inviting attention beyond the project.
She beamed handsomely. She pointed at the announcement of her address on the classroom Compaq. But two of her three children, along with a niece, were already responding to her gaze of triumph with a round of cheering. Baby Michael snoozed steadily. He missed a moment that amounted to a commencement party for Ms. Johnson, and perhaps for Michael, too.
"I'm doing it for the certificate," Ms. Johnson said, referring to the certificate of computer literacy that entitles her to the home setup in the prototype program at Poe Homes. The program is intended to boost some of the nation's poorest people into the rich universe of opportunity represented by computers generally and the Internet in particular.
"You know how it is with the kids, and how they need the computer for their future," the mother said. "I just decided I'm going to get this," she added, gently rocking with her baby, still gripping the mouse.
The computer program began with a fanfare when the highly wired Townes complex opened in 1999, as federal and city officials vowed to "close the digital divide" between rich and poor. The task has not been as easy as giving away computers sounds. Only 75 of the 202 households signed up at first; with this odd gift horse at the door glinting esoterically, wariness surfaced.
"In public housing, there's typically some element of distrust and strained relations between the housing authority and the residents," said Jeremiah Griffith, chief operating officer of the Noah Group, a private community services organization running the program. "We spent the first 10 or 11 months trying to address that, and it hasn't been an easy process."
Residents typically wanted to know whether they would lose their place in public housing if the computer broke down. Some wanted to know, conversely, if they had to take the computer to keep their apartment. 
Others did not want to be bothered, said Constance Mayfield, executive director of the program. "In a community like this, even though people are apprised of services, many are not accustomed" to taking advantage of them, Ms. Mayfield said, noting that this was just the sort of problem being sought out in the experiment.
The $1.7 million program, called Hope VI, is being run by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Housing Authority of Baltimore City. Administrators are trying to remedy findings that blacks and Hispanics are far less likely than whites to explore the Internet and that this trend is even stronger in the lower income groups. A Commerce Department study found that in families earning $15,000 to $35,000 annually, 17 percent of whites used the Internet often as opposed to 8 percent of blacks.
In the last six years, the federal housing agency has established about 800 computer learning centers of varying sorts in conjunction with the private sector. Most are in privately owned apartment complexes and offer computer lessons aimed at careers. But Poe is offering a flagship program in providing free machines -- they are actually supplied as an appliance and do not become the residents' property -- in a specially wired public housing setting. 
"It's a generational thing, too," Ms. Mayfield said. "Some kids already are being taught computers in school and so they want them at home. But they have to convince their parents to take the classes."
Eventually, officials went door to door reassuring and enlisting applicants. A survey of residents indicated that greater salesmanship was required, prompting housing authority officials to press harder and focus on some early success stories as word-of-mouth tales to prime demand. 
And over the last few months, attitudes have changed. "Since Christmas it started going much better," Ms. Mayfield said. Residents began wanting the computers as presents for their children. Officials were grateful for this motive. But they held firm to the condition that an adult householder had to have 10 days' training, two hours a day, or there would be no computer to put under the tree.
"I was just stumbling all over the keys," recalled Geraldine Janet Pulley, who said she took the course despite herself. "It was like studying Latin."
Her problem was recognized by Stephanie Roberson, the program director as well as an instructor, as a common one among computer novices. "She was intimidated," Ms. Roberson said. "She thought she was going to hurt the computer."
The lessons are designed to instill a sense of mastery in the residents. Ms. Pulley, a former schoolteacher who had to retire after suffering a stroke, said she eventually got the knack, and a fresh career.
"I learned to laugh," Ms. Pulley said, looking down upon the computer keyboard at the Poe Homes office, where she was recently hired to run a program called Rentroll that tracks rent payments and maintenance needs at 300 apartments. "All of a sudden I was fine. I started to feel good about myself. I was determined not to let this thing defeat me."
Noah Group administrators still have more than 70 boxed computers sitting in their office, waiting for eligible residents who hesitate for a variety of reasons, including onerous commuting and job conditions that can leave them too exhausted for studying. Class hours, accordingly, have been made much more flexible with more inviting schedules for both adults and children. Babies, once forbidden from the adult classes, are now welcomed at sessions, where they punctuate the clicking and tapping with healthy yowls. Mr. Johnson, a new father himself, seems to handle them as just another easily solved glitch at the office. 
For all the admitted start-up problems, the range of activities on a recent day included the half-dozen women taking Mr. Johnson's evening course in the Poe Learning Center, an old power plant converted to classroom space. Upstairs, a group of far more advanced teenagers were happily working overtime as students in the Cisco Networking Academy, a nine-month course sponsored by Cisco Systems, the giant Internet company, designed to net them careers in technology. These students had already built their own computers in this after-school academy and were branching into larger possibilities.
"Routers and switchers," 17-year-old Eugene Hamilton confidently explained, tinkering away as Mr. Johnson went downstairs to begin the literacy course.
"Always something new here, every day," added James Parson, also 17. Both said finding such computer possibilities had changed their lives and their career options. 
"This is a once-in-a-lifetime thing for most of us," Eugene Hamilton said. "We're getting free advanced training that would easily cost thousands of dollars anywhere else." 
The course has led to scores of jobs in the computer industry at $30,000 a year and more, Ms. Roberson said. "That's quite a temptation for an 18-year-old from around here." 
Even so, she insists on taking the students on field trips to Bowie State University and other centers of higher computer education. She and Mr. Johnson urge the Cisco trainees to weigh the inviting job offers against going on to college. College, they emphasize, presents an even larger opportunity to create their own businesses that could offer even more computer jobs to ambitious young people like themselves. 
Down the street from the learning center, Deana Woodard turned her wheelchair to the computer nook in her new Vine Street apartment in the Townes houses. A printed prayer hung over the computer that seemed especially appropriate: "Lord, help me to remember that nothing is going to happen to me today that you and I can't handle." 
Or, for that matter, Ms. Roberson, who stopped by to see how Ms. Woodard's exploration of the Internet was progressing.
"I like to look into the different recipes," said Ms. Woodard, a 57-year-old retired school chef who clicked around a site blossoming with toothsome crab recipes. "It's beautiful," she said of her computer. "I don't think I can do without it."
Ms. Roberson patted her on the back as she typed and clicked.
"I'm not an old hand, but I'll be one soon," Ms. Woodard promised.
At the learning center's basic course, the evening was building toward the magical moment of creating e-mail identities for Mr. Johnson's students. He moved from one computer student to the next, cajoling, insisting, encouraging. "We can do it," he said. "I've got the most common name on the planet. Millions of us, and my address is strictly mine." 
Eugene Hamilton came down from the Cisco room and whispered to his teacher, "I just bugged the whole system." Mr. Johnson, his mind suddenly racing from the problems of e-mail addresses to the advanced unhinging of routers and switchers, quietly stared, a study in digital patience before the cockiness of youth.
Before the teacher could say a word, the student flashed a smile and declared: "Nah, just kidding. We're going great upstairs."
Clearly unruffled, Mr. Johnson turned back to Charnita Johnson's quest for her e-mail address.
"You want to put him down for a while?" he asked the mother of baby Michael.
But Charnita Johnson excitedly declined, exhibiting a kind of symbiotic balance between offspring and mouse as she extracted her new address from the world beyond the project.

HEADLINE: Euro Drops On Release Of New Data On Economy 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 23 

 BODY:
The European economy showed troubling new signs today of slower growth and faster inflation, a toxic mix that helped drive down the value of the euro to its lowest level this year against the dollar.
 The bad news came from both Germany and France, Europe's two biggest economies; they reinforced the impression that the 12-nation euro zone is much less insulated from the American slowdown than many leaders had asserted. Global demand for European goods is significantly weaker than most experts had predicted just a few months ago, while energy prices are much higher. 
 Germany reported today that economic growth in the first quarter slowed to an annual rate of 1.6 percent, dragged down by a steep decline in investment for machinery and equipment and anemic growth in exports and private consumption. At the same time, data from five German states suggested that consumer prices were climbing at more than 3 percent a year -- much faster than the upper limit set by the European Central Bank. 
France, meanwhile, reported today that its comparatively robust economy had slipped as well, growing at an annualized rate of about 2 percent in the first quarter. Though inflation in France is slower than in most other European countries, it seems to be gathering speed.
Signs of trouble have been showing up elsewhere in Europe as well. The Netherlands, among Europe's growth leaders for much of the last decade, reported a few days ago that its economy virtually stopped expanding in the first quarter, and in neighboring Belgium, where business sentiment often presages developments in the euro zone as a whole, confidence fell to its lowest level in two years.
The mix of trends has made it difficult for the European Central Bank to respond. Unlike the United States Federal Reserve, which has concentrated on combating any slowdown by reducing interest rates five times this year, the European bank has been torn between fears of rising prices and of slumping growth. Two weeks ago, the bank briefly set aside inflation worries and reduced interest rates for the first time this year; today it returned to its previous pattern and left rates unchanged.
All of this amounted to more bad news for the euro, which plumbed new lows for the year against both the dollar and the Japanese yen. Chronically weak since its inception in January 1999, the euro lost nearly a penny in value today, to 85.7 cents in European trading; it began life worth $1.17.
The biggest surprise today was the weakness in French growth, recorded at just 0.5 percent in the first quarter. France spent most of last year growing and adding jobs at its most robust pace in years. Most forecasters expected 3 percent growth this year, even allowing for the effects of an American slowdown. 
The new figures show French consumers continuing to spend at a healthy rate, reflecting the job growth and the tax cuts adopted last year. But exports slipped slightly, and investment in machines and equipment fell significantly. 
"Realism has taken the upper hand in Europe," said Eric Vergnaud, an economist at BNP Paribas in Paris. Though Mr. Vergnaud still sees a chance that France can manage a respectable growth rate of about 2.5 percent for the year, he acknowledged that the outlook had deteriorated. "It is time to realize that Europe is not an island," he said. "Things are slowing down, but the slowdown is much more modest than in the United States."
Not necessarily so in Germany, which accounts for one-third of the euro zone's total economic activity. Economists sharply reduced their forecasts for Germany just a few months ago, and many are now doing so again. BNP Paribas expects only 1.5 percent to 1.8 percent growth; Deutsche Bank sees 1.6 percent. "Even this number requires a substantial rebound" in the second half of 2001, Deutsche Bank said today in commenting on the latest data. "The risks remain largely skewed to the downside."
The lurking threat of inflation complicates the equation. Early figures from five of Germany's constituent states suggested that consumer prices here were climbing at an annual rate of 3.5 percent, mainly because of persistent increases in gasoline and food. The biggest reason is the renewed climb in oil prices, which eased slightly late last year but have risen since mid-March.
