HEADLINE: Russia Sees Payoff in Storing Nuclear Wastes From Other Nations 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 25 

 BODY:
Despite some strong opposition from the public at home and by the government in the United States, Russia is preparing to open its borders to become the largest international repository for radioactive nuclear wastes.
 With strong backing from President Vladimir V. Putin, the Ministry of Atomic Energy is expected to get a new legal mandate from Parliament next month to offer permanent storage for the highly toxic spent nuclear fuel that has been piling up in temporary storage basins at power plants around the world. 
 Moscow estimates that it can earn $21 billion in the next two decades by accepting 20,000 tons from 15 countries Russia has identified that would send used reactor cores by ship and train to new installations in Siberia, one of which is nearing completion.
The program would represent a far-reaching development in the international nuclear power industry, as governments in Germany, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are in the midst of national debates over how to dispose of highly radioactive reactor fuel cores. Spent fuel assemblies, filled with toxic byproducts of the nuclear fission that occurs inside reactor cores, must either be buried in secure geologic formations for thousands of years, or reprocessed to recycle the plutonium and uranium in them as new fuel. 
But the reprocessing of nuclear fuel has become one of the most delicate issues of the nuclear safety debate because it separates plutonium and uranium in forms that might be stolen or diverted to illicit nuclear weapons programs. Russia, France and Britain reprocess fuel for civilian reactor programs, and Germany and Japan ship spent fuel to England and France for reprocessing, but the issue of permanent storage for most of the world's spent nuclear fuels and their wastes remains an open question.
The United States abandoned reprocessing technologies in the Ford and Carter administrations, citing proliferation dangers in creating a "plutonium economy," higher costs and environmental concerns. The United States is still evaluating whether it can safely store spent fuel and wastes from 104 American reactors at Yucca Mountain in Nevada.
A key element in the Russian proposal is to accept the world's spent fuel, charging up to $1,600 per 2.2 pounds to hold it in perpetuity, but also preserving the option to reprocess and resell it should national policies and economics lead to safer reactor designs and new fuel configurations.
Russian officials say they hope to use profits from the new industry to help pay for an extensive environmental cleanup program here and to promote the development of more efficient reactors that would use plutonium-based fuels in a form designed to prevent their diversion for weapons use.
Russia faces enormous cleanup tasks from Soviet-era radiation accidents and illicit dumping at sea by the Soviet and Russian navies. At the same time, the country has trouble meeting the demand for electricity and has five nuclear plants in various stages of completion to bolster the 29 existing plants. 
At the heart of Russia's proposal, officials here say, is an attempt to seize a large share of the future market for nuclear energy at a time when industrialized nations are facing increasing demand for electricity and growing concerns about global warming.
"Russia will demonstrate to the world that its technological potential is high, and it will pave the way to new projects," said Aleksandr Rumyantsev, the country's new minister of atomic energy.
Valentin B. Ivanov, the deputy minister, said in an interview this week that Russia was not sure what shape the nuclear industry would take, but that by garnering a significant share of the nuclear fuels market, it could secure a place for itself as an international supplier of nuclear technology.
The Russian initiative comes at a time when the Bush administration has cut funds for joint projects with Russia to reduce plutonium stockpiles, close Soviet-era bomb-making installations and provide financing to Russian nuclear scientists formerly employed in weapons production. At the same time, President Bush has ordered a broad review of nuclear power in the United States, including an examination of safer reactor designs and nuclear fuels resistant to diversion.
The Russian proposal faces immediate obstacles because the United States controls the movement, through licensing agreements, of nuclear fuels now powering most of the reactors operating overseas.
Nonetheless, Russian officials say they hope to reach an agreement with the Bush administration to enter this business. And Washington is expected to come under some pressure to cooperate from governments that have not resolved what to do with their spent nuclear fuel. Some is stored in high-risk earthquake zones, like Taiwan, which has six American-built nuclear reactors and will soon have two more.
Japan has 53 operating reactors and is in the midst of a national debate over how to store its nuclear wastes. In Europe, there are more than 150 nuclear reactors, and France generates 76 percent of its electrical power with nuclear energy.
Though American companies like Westinghouse and General Electric have sold nuclear reactors around the world, the United States government has made no commitment to assume responsibility for the long-term storage of spent fuel and its wastes. Washington does retain veto power over where that fuel can be transported.
During the Clinton administration, Washington encouraged Russia to remove a ban on importing spent fuels. By removing the ban, American officials calculated, Russia could help solve the coming crisis over the long-term disposal of toxic wastes, most of them from reactors sold by American companies.
A group of influential Americans, including a former director of central intelligence, William H. Webster, helped to create the Nonproliferation Trust, a private company that has worked to win support and financing for a permanent repository in Russia for 10,000 tons of spent fuel from reactors operating outside the United States. 
Despite those efforts, an agreement has been stymied by American concerns over proliferation, Russia's nuclear cooperation with Iran, and Moscow's ambition to make use of spent fuels. 
Thomas B. Cochran, a longtime environmental activist who promoted the idea of building a Russian repository as a consultant to the Nonproliferation Trust, said Russian officials were unwilling to accept a moratorium on reprocessing spent fuel. For this reason, he said, the new Russian plan will be "dead on arrival on this side of the Atlantic." 
Russian officials disagree. They said this week that as soon as they won legislative approval, they would seek to acquire from foreign customers several thousands tons of spent fuel whose movement does not require United States approval. An installation that can hold the first 3,000 tons of fuel is nearing completion in the closed nuclear city Krasnoyarsk-26 in central Siberia.
"We will act in parallel," said Mr. Ivanov, the deputy atomic energy minister. He added that "we understand that without an agreement with the United States, it is impossible to use the spent fuel" of many countries. But at the same time, he said, "we know that approximately 10 percent of spent fuel exists outside the U.S. umbrella, and we have received information from some governments that they will start negotiations with us if we get this legislation."
Mr. Ivanov, a physicist and reactor designer, said the United States and Russia could decide to work together on a world standard for proliferation-resistant nuclear fuels and reactors, or they can work separately. In any case, it appears that the two nations now face contentious negotiations on competitive strategies for future energy technologies. 
From the outset, a major obstacle will be Russia's plans to supply as many as five nuclear reactors to Iran, creating an atomic energy industry in a country that is believed to support terrorism and seeking to develop nuclear weapons in secret.
Rose Gottemoeller, a former Department of Energy official who supervised nonproliferation programs involving Russia in the Clinton administration. said: "The Bush administration could just continue to stiff-arm Russia on the spent fuel storage issue, saying, 'No way, no how' because it can't keep its own nuclear material safe, so why encourage more."
"But there is a new game in town," she said, noting Mr. Bush's interest in re-examining overall nuclear energy policy.
"The administration will at least want to examine this storage idea with the Russians in order to get them to come to the table and get our Iran questions resolved," she said, adding that new technologies in Russia also may warrant study. 
Still, there is high-level resistance in Washington to any strategy that would add to Russia's inventory of nuclear fuels and wastes when major issues of radioactive contamination in parts of Russia remain outstanding, along with security concerns over the safe storage of weapons-grade uranium and plutonium.
Kathleen Crane, a geophysicist from Hunter College in New York who mapped radioactive contamination in Russia from 1993 to 1997, said she had long been opposed to allowing spent fuel to be stored in Russia.
But, she said, "nuclear waste is going to be imported by Russia whatever we do, and instead of just letting it happen, we and the rest of the world should take an active role in trying to control it." 
Though they acknowledge a grim Soviet legacy that includes the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in Ukraine and other serious accidents, Russian officials seem determined to take this new legislative step -- despite polls that show that the public overwhelmingly opposes it -- if only to position Russia to profit from an industry that, worldwide, may be discovering a new momentum.
Russian officials say they have conducted experiments on a new type of fast breeder reactor, long thought to be too dangerous because its fuel "breeds" more plutonium, creating proliferation risks when that plutonium is recovered in reprocessing.
In coming months, a Russian research reactor will begin testing a new fast reactor fuel that combines plutonium and uranium in a form that cannot be used for nuclear weapons and that does not require traditional reprocessing, said Anatoly S. Polyakov, deputy director of the Bochvar Research Institute here. 
"We have a lot to offer," he said, "but the only way for cooperation with the United States is that it be mutually beneficial."

HEADLINE: In Mexico, Grim Resolve After Deaths 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER

DATELINE: MERIDA, Mexico, May 25 

 BODY:
So many have lost their lives crossing into the promised land that some in Mexico were simply numbed by news of the deaths of 14 more migrants abandoned in the Arizona desert. 
 President Vicente Fox and his ministers were not. No issue has been more emotional for Mr. Fox than the fate of Mexican migrants, and the deaths in the desert this week show how frustrating it has been for him to find a solution. 
 Ever since he took office nearly six months ago, Mr. Fox has been urging the United States to work with him to find ways to protect the lives of migrants without breaking American laws. While both sides have spoken earnestly about dealing with illegal immigration -- or migration, as the United States now calls it at the instigation of Mexico -- it is far from clear how they can meet that goal. 
Mr. Fox has repeatedly hailed as heroes the hundreds of thousands of Mexicans who go to the United States seeking work. He said today that he wanted the United States to grant legal status to as many Mexican migrants as possible so "they don't have to live in the shadows and don't have to live from hand to mouth."
After meeting four of the survivors in their hospital beds in the Yuma Regional Medical Center in Arizona, Juan Hernandez, whom Mr. Fox appointed to the new post of minister for migrant affairs, said in a telephone interview that there was much both countries had to do to prevent more Mexicans from suffering such a fate.
"One of them, a young woman, said she had been tempted by the wealth of the richest country on earth," he said. "Now, we have a great obligation to create opportunities in Mexico so that people are not obliged to leave to find work. But the truth is, people are dying. And these are the new pioneers of America, where everyone is the son or daughter or grandchild of immigrants."
With the possible exception of drug smuggling, migration is the most complicated issue between the United States and Mexico. Millions of people seeking work have illegally crossed over -- about 150,000 last year -- along the nearly 2,000-mile border. Thousands have died trying, now at a rate of roughly one a day.
Enrique Berruga, Mexico's under secretary of foreign affairs, said in an interview that the four issues the two nations needed to resolve were the documentation of immigrants already in the United States, the guest worker program, increasing the number of visas issued, and the ways that border security is enforced. Tough American border enforcement in populated areas has led desperate migrants to seek increasingly isolated and dangerous routes, like the one used by the Mexicans who died in the Arizona desert. 
Mexican officials have even considered issuing survival kits to migrants that would include rehydration salts and food. But they say they cannot tell the United States how to enforce its laws.
Officials of the two countries may find common ground, though, in new guest worker programs. Mr. Fox proposes to increase the number of seasonal farm workers permitted to enter the United States to 250,000 a year, from 40,000 today. This idea has been supported by many farm-state politicians in the United States, and some labor unions.
It is one idea that has emerged from high-level meetings between Mexican and American officials that began with President Bush's visit to Mexico in February and will resume in San Antonio on June 6. 
The contrasts between the two nations' economics and demographics are stark. Those born in Mexico's baby boom are in their 20's and 30's and are eager to find better-paying jobs, Mr. Hernandez said. The minimum daily wage in Mexico is less than the minimum hourly wage in the United States.
In southern Guerrero state, where three of the victims lived, there is very little work outside the tourist enclave of Acapulco. In rural Veracruz, where the remainder of the dead lived, small towns barely sustain themselves. 
Mr. Hernandez promised that Mexico would work with the United States to prevent more deaths.
"We are talking much more closely than ever before," he said. "And we are not going to close our eyes anymore."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
1st-Quarter G.D.P. Rose At a Sluggish 1.3% Pace
For the first time since 1995, the economy grew by less than 2 percent for two consecutive quarters, the government reported.
 The gross domestic product, a measure of the output of goods and services, rose at an annual pace of 1.3 percent in the first quarter, slower than the 2 percent expected but up from the 1 percent pace in the fourth quarter. C3. 

Hong Kong's economy felt the effects of the global slowdown in the first quarter of 2001, growing 2.5 percent, compared with 14.1 percent in the quarter last year. C2.

Negotiators Agree on a Tax Cut Deal
Congressional negotiators have agreed on all aspects of the biggest tax cut in 20 years, and final votes were scheduled for today in the House and Senate. The plan to reduce taxes by $1.35 trillion will lower taxes for married couples, will expand the tax credit for children and will eventually repeal the estate tax. A1.

Senator Demands Energy Hearings
Senator Dianne Feinstein of California called for hearings into possible improprieties between members of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and private energy interests. Ms. Feinstein said the commission had not acted to protect California residents from companies that were reaping undue profits through spiraling energy costs. A11.

The chairman of the El Paso Corporation shed some light in testimony before an administrative judge on a transaction that California officials say was used to drive up natural gas prices in the state. C4.

Russia to Collect Nuclear Waste
Despite strong opposition from the public at home and by the United States government, Russia is preparing to become the largest international repository for radioactive nuclear wastes. Moscow estimates that it can earn $21 billion over the next two decades by accepting 20,000 tons from 15 nations. A1.

Inquiry Into General Dynamics Deal
Antitrust enforcers at the Justice Department are taking a closer look at General Dynamics' proposed acquisition of Newport News Shipbuilding. Newport News is the subject of rival bids from General Dynamics and Northrop Grumman. Northrop and its supporters in Washington have argued that the General Dynamics proposal would create a monopoly in nuclear shipbuilding. C3.

Enron's Dispute in India Intensifies
Talks meant to settle a dispute between Enron and Indian federal and state government officials over months of unpaid power bills fell apart this week. Then, the state-run utility at the center of the dispute -- the sole customer for electricity generated by the Enron-controlled Dabhol Power Company, above -- served notice that it would challenge the validity of the contract between Dabhol and the utility and seek to have it canceled. C2.

A Dispute Over the 'Survivor' Show
A former contestant on the CBS television show "Survivor" contends the program's producer, Mark Burnett, improperly persuaded fellow contestants to eliminate her from the program -- and a chance to win its $1 million top prize. He has denied the charge. C14.

Italy Acts to Thwart Takeover Bid
Italy's outgoing center-left government has acted to thwart a takeover of Montedison, a conglomerate with holdings from power generating to sugar processing, by Electricite de France, which has acquired as much as 20 percent of Montedison shares. C2.

Markets Closed Memorial Day
United States financial markets, government offices and banks will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Financial markets will be open in other countries.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A2-7

Russia Planning to Accept Nuclear Waste From Others
Russia is preparing to open its borders to become the largest repository for nuclear wastes. President Vladimir V. Putin has strongly backed the plan. Moscow estimates it can earn $21 billion over two decades by accepting 20,000 tons from 15 nations, money it says it will use to clean up the environment. A1

Freeing Sierra Leone's Children
More than 400 child soldiers were released by the Revolutionary United Front, the rebel group that has terrorized Sierra Leone for the last decade by kidnapping children and chopping off people's arms. A3

Jerusalem in Mourning
Jerusalemites struggled to deal with what some described as crisis overload after at least 24 people died when a wedding hall collapsed. A6

Powell Criticizes Zimbabwean
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, in assessing the state of Africa, called on President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to "submit to the law and the will of the people" in a fair presidential election next year instead of clinging to power. A3

Fencing In the Taliban

Biggest Tax Cut in 20 YearsIs Facing Final Votes Today

Senate Shift in High Gear
The Democrats who are expected to lead the Senate's 15 committees are busy shaping the year ahead after their party takes control of the Senate for the first time since 1994. A1

Bush Advises Free Thinking
A day after President Bush discovered that a touch of political risk-taking cost him control of the United States Senate, he told graduates of the United States Naval Academy that they need the freedom to roam in new directions even if "some of your ideas may fail." The speech was drafted before the White House discovered Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont was defecting. A9

Immigrant rights groups said the deaths of 14 Mexicans in the desert near Yuma, Ariz., have caused them to consider stronger challenges to what they call hostile United States border policy. Doctors said the condition of the 12 Mexican immigrants who survived was improving. A10

HEADLINE: CONGRESS AGREES ON FINAL DETAILS FOR TAX-CUT BILL 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25 

 BODY:
Congressional negotiators agreed today on all aspects of the biggest tax cut in 20 years, and final votes are scheduled for Saturday in the House and Senate.
 Under the legislation, everyone who filed an income tax return this year will receive a rebate check from the government by the end of September -- $300 for individuals and $600 for couples. 
 Tax brackets except for the 15 percent bracket are to drop by 1 percentage point on July 1. The top tax rate, now 39.6 percent, will fall in stages to 35 percent in 2006. The other rates above the 15 percent rate will also fall in stages and will be 3 percentage points lower in 2006 than they are now. 
Beginning next year, taxes for married couples will fall, and the tax credit for children will be expanded.
The size of estates exempt from the estate tax are scheduled to be increased next year and several times over the next decade, with repeal of the estate tax set for 2010.
Altogether, taxes are to be reduced by $1.35 trillion, slightly less than the $1.6 trillion President Bush proposed over 10 years. But the lower number was met by assuming that all the tax cuts would expire in 2010, and unlike the president's proposal and the bills passed by the Senate and the House, no revenue loss was shown for 2011.
The tax bill the House-Senate conference committee approved tonight was written in three days of almost round-the-clock negotiations among Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa and Representative Bill Thomas of California, both Republicans, and Senators Max Baucus of Montana and John B. Breaux of Louisiana, both Democrats.
"As a result of this landmark tax relief agreement, the American taxpayers will have more money in their pockets to save and invest and the economy will receive a much needed shot in the arm," President Bush said in a statement issued by the White House. "I commend the members of the House and Senate, Republican and Democrat alike, who made this happen. Tax relief is a centerpiece of our American agenda and I look forward to signing it into law."
Democratic leaders sharply criticized the bill, particularly the elements that would hide the loss of revenue by showing that the tax cuts would expire before 2011.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the top Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, was officially a conferee on the legislation but was excluded from the final negotiations. 
Tonight, he accused Republicans of "packing it with every kind of gimmick and sleight of hand I have ever seen."
"It's one big fraud on the American people," Mr. Rangel said.
Lawmakers said there was little doubt the House and Senate would approve the legislation when they vote on Saturday, thus sending the measure to the president to be signed into law.
The bill was Mr. Bush's top legislative priority, but its approval comes at the end of a calamitous week for him politically, because Democrats took over control of the Senate.
Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, who caused the change in party control when he said on Thursday that he would leave the Republican Party and become an independent, did not appear in public today. 
But Mr. Jeffords issued a statement denying that Democrats, who now have a 50-49 majority in the Senate, had promised him the chairmanship of the Environment and Public Works Committee.
"My decision," he said, "was to leave the Republican Party. It was not based on aspirations for something else."
Other senators said they fully expected Mr. Jeffords to assume that chairmanship when they return next month from a week's recess. Mr. Jeffords promised Mr. Bush that he would not leave the party until the final votes on the tax bill so that Republicans could maintain a majority on the conference committee.
Republican leaders, shaken by the turn of events, held several meetings today.
One result was that Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania was given a seat at the leadership table to represent the views of moderate Republicans.
In his announcement on Thursday, Mr. Jeffords said he was leaving the party because his views on issues like education and the environment were ignored by the conservatives who dominate the party in Congress.
"We had one of our biggest victories in the tax bill and one of our biggest disappointments in Senator Jeffords leaving the party," said Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the Republican whip.
Mr. Nickles said he hoped Congress would approve more tax-cut legislation this year, including a reduction in the capital-gains tax, but he conceded that this would "be a little more difficult with the change of leadership."
Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate Democratic leader, said, "By increasing its cost and worsening its tilt toward the very wealthy, Republicans have made this bill more fiscally irresponsible, less fair. 
"Once again middle-class working families get left behind." 
Republican lawmakers were thrilled by the outcome. "This is the best day for working men and women since the Reagan tax cuts," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. It was made possible, Mr. Gramm said, because Mr. Bush made cutting taxes "the defining issue of his first term as president."
The Senate approved its version of the tax bill on Wednesday. The House approved several tax bills this spring, and the job of the conference committee was to work out the differences and produce one bill for the president's signature.
Mr. Bush has been urging the lawmakers all week to wrap up their work so he could sign a bill by Memorial Day. An administration official said the timing was important so that the Treasury could begin processing rebate checks.
A Treasury official said that taxpayers would receive a letter in July telling them to expect a rebate check. The checks would begin going out in July, she said, and all taxpayers should have them by September.
Only sketchy details of the final agreement were available tonight. But they showed that the tax credit for each child, now $500, would be increased to $600 this year and, in stages, to $1,000 in 2010.
A part of this credit is to be refunded to parents who earn at least $10,000 a year but have too little income to owe taxes.
The refundability provision, sponsored by Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, was strenuously opposed by many other Republicans. But moderate senators from both parties insisted on it, making it a condition of their voting for the final legislation.
Negotiators said that the refundability matter and the size of the top rate were the most difficult issues to resolve. The top rate is now paid by fewer than 1 percent of taxpayers and is owed only on income of more than $297,350.
Among the legislation's other provisions are these:
*The maximum annual contributions to tax-free retirement plans like 401(k) plans and individual retirement accounts will be increased, and tax breaks will be offered to encourage employers to have more favorable pension benefits.
*Limits on deductions and personal exemptions that upper-income taxpayers can claim will be repealed in stages beginning in 2006.
*The amount of income subject to the alternative minimum tax will be increased.
*The earned-income tax credit for low-income workers will be expanded.
The rebate checks this year will result from lowering the tax rate to 10 percent from 15 percent on the first $6,000 of every individual's income and the first $12,000 of a couple's income. These figures will be raised to $7,000 and $14,000 in 2008.
Married couples will get another tax cut starting next year because the size of the standard deduction will be made double that for single people, and more income for couples will be subject to the 15 percent rate, instead of 25 percent.

Other rates drop gradually by 2006 from 36 percent to 33 percent; 31 percent to 28 percent and 28 percent to 25 percent. The 15 percent rate remains the same. HEADLINE: At Home Abroad; 
A Political Surprise

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
A funny thing happened on the way to the British election June 7. When the Conservatives let it be known that they would cut taxes if they won, there was a sharp backlash. It turned out that in Britain today, tax cuts are political poison.
 What a contrast to the United States. There Congress has just approved enormous tax cuts, the centerpiece of George W. Bush's campaign for president. 
 The difference goes deep, really to the political cultures of the two countries. Britons of all stripes want better public services: schools, hospitals, railroads, police. The Bush tax cuts mean that public services will be starved of federal funds for the indefinite future -- yet most Americans seem not to care, or are unaware of those painful consequences. 
The plan to cut taxes was first disclosed by a Conservative shadow minister, Oliver Letwin. The reaction was so negative that Mr. Letwin hid from the press for several days. Tax reduction, someone quipped, was a policy that dared not speak its name.
When a group of business leaders wrote a letter in support of the Conservative Party, they included in the draft a paragraph praising President Bush and his tax cuts. Party officials deleted that paragraph before they published the letter. 
The British are plainly discontented with the level of public services. Schools have come under stinging criticism. Waiting time for operations in the National Health Service averages six months. Britons are more European in their outlook than they used to be, and they know that conditions are better across the Channel. France spends 9 percent of its gross domestic product on health care, compared with Britain's 6.5 percent. 
In the election campaign the Labor prime minister, Tony Blair, charges day after day that "Tory tax cuts" would hurt public services. He says Labor will add 20,000 nurses and 10,000 doctors to the Health Service, the Tories none.
There is some skepticism about Mr. Blair's promises -- understandably, given his government's record in the last four years. Pledges to bolster the Health Service, for example, have not produced solutions for its serious shortcomings.
The sharpest public irritation is probably over the state of the railroads, on which Britons depend far more than Americans. There have been fatal accidents, and tracks need major repairs. 
The Blair government inherited a disastrous Conservative plan that split up the nationalized rail system and sold off the pieces to private companies. Yet now Labor proposes to repeat the disaster on the London subway system. When a reporter asked about that at the party press conference the other day, Mr. Blair and the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, simply dissembled. 
Labor can promise to spend more on public services without arousing fear of inflation because of Mr. Brown's conservative fiscal record. As Bill Clinton turned Democratic policy from deficits to balanced budgets, so has Mr. Brown here. And the result has been similar: a healthy economy and low unemployment. 
"We have delivered the economic stability," Mr. Blair said this week, "that allows us now to increase investment in our public services." 
For anyone who knew the Labor Party in the old days, with its talk of Socialism and weakness toward inflationary union demands, today's emphasis on fiscal soundness is astounding. Even the call for better public services is couched in financial language: more "investment" rather than more "spending."
The new Labor look certainly seems to work politically. The polls forecast another Labor landslide. The Conservative leader, William Hague, has approval ratings in the 20's or lower. 
This week the Tories brought in Margaret Thatcher. Lady Thatcher made a savagely anti-European speech, but it was a dud. The Evening Standard called her "an increasingly batty old woman, whose spectre might be used to terrorize recalcitrant children but whose views are quite irrelevant to modern Britain." 
Mr. Hague's last card is to denounce the possibility of Britain joining the European common currency, the euro. He says Mr. Blair wants to "ditch the pound." Perhaps Mr. Blair does; he will decide in the next two years. Polls show a majority against adopting the euro. But that is not what is on the voters' minds now. They are playing on Tony Blair's wicket, public services.

HEADLINE: Beliefs; 
The president, the veteran labor priest and the makings of a 'Catholic strategy.'

BYLINE:  By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
When Msgr. George G. Higgins, speaking at Sunday's graduation ceremony at the University of Notre Dame, declared that contrary to his usual practice, he wanted to make a few extempore remarks, not a few people on the platform stiffened. 
 Only a few moments before, President Bush had received an honorary degree from the university and delivered the commencement address. 
 It was a superbly crafted address, clear, eloquent and filled, like some of his other speeches, with sentiments about both personal and governmental responsibility to combat poverty that could have won as much agreement on the left of the political spectrum as on the right. 
But coming in conjunction with the impending tax cut, a new energy plan, a set of conservative executive and judicial appointments and other pieces of a White House agenda that looked far less bipartisan, the commencement talk was widely interpreted not as a plan for action but as part of a conscious strategy to woo Roman Catholic supporters. 
Monsignor Higgins, on the other hand, was at the podium being honored for decades of work on behalf of organized labor and economic rights, activities not closely associated with the current administration. He was receiving the Notre Dame's Laetare Medal, given for more than a century to outstanding Catholics. 
So was Monsignor Higgins about to challenge the president? That was hardly the style of a man who for decades had been a key staff member and adviser for the American Catholic bishops and a veteran of Washington proprieties. 
What he wanted to say was a brief, extemporaneous tribute to a classmate from the Chicago seminary, Msgr. John J. Egan, another stalwart of Catholic struggles for social justice and civil rights. Monsignor Egan, whom The Chicago Tribune called "the conscience of Chicago," had died the day before. 
One New York priest who visited Monsignor Egan a few weeks ago found him "organizing until his last breath" -- in weakened condition, on oxygen, but delighted to have just passed on the leadership of one of his campaigns to protect poor people. 
"I was never involved at the hands-on level like he was," Monsignor Higgins said self-deprecatingly in a later telephone interview. "I was more bureaucratic, if you will, somewhat more bookish." 
Bookish hardly captures the extent of Monsignor Higgins's voracious reading, a habit instilled in him by his postal clerk father, whom he has described as "a blue-collar intellectual." Indeed, among the more poignant things about a visit to Monsignor Higgins's pleasant rooms in a residence for priests near the Catholic University of America in Washington are the now-empty bookshelves, bearing only scattered volumes and tapes of lectures on many topics. 
Deteriorating eyesight has forced the 85-year-old priest to give to Catholic University the library he had accumulated, a step he wrote about movingly in the weekly column he has been writing for Catholic papers since 1945. But despite his eye problems and difficulties in walking that remain after hip replacements, it is impossible to get him to complain, and almost equally impossible to lure him into reminiscences about his eventful life. 
He expresses great satisfaction in the progress of Catholic-Jewish relations, a concern he has followed closely since the Second Vatican Council in the mid-1960's. He talks about his work with Cesar Chavez and the organization of farm workers in California -- and his contacts with Solidarity in Poland. 
He laments the declining number of priests. He worries that the Catholic bishops are so preoccupied with looking over their shoulders for signs of approval or disapproval from Rome that they are kept from acting. 
But he does not mention having been honored at an international Catholic-Jewish conference two weeks earlier or the Medal of Freedom he received at the White House last August, and he dodges any big pronouncements. It is all shrewd observation, common sense and good humor. "My life has been very day to day," he says simply. 
After the Notre Dame event, it was similarly hard to draw any comment from him about President Bush's speech. He limited himself to saying that it was well received.
By all reports, it had been. But there were also polite signs of dissent. Some graduates and faculty members wore white armbands. One student, Daniel Moriarty, turned his back, knelt and said the rosary during the president's talk. 
The protester was no freshly radicalized undergraduate, but a 30-year-old former lay missionary in Bolivia now completing a graduate degree in peace studies. The president's speech "was all well and good," Mr. Moriarty said in a telephone conversation, but "a lot of that is compassionate rhetoric." 
Monsignor Higgins may not have been able to see Mr. Moriarty's gesture, but he did mention, with some satisfaction, one sentence in the valedictory address. The valedictorian, Carolyn Weir, had "deftly worked into a sentence references questioning both abortion and the death sentence," Monsignor Higgins said. 
Indeed, she had -- and the sentence provoked resounding applause.
Anyone, Republican or Democrat, trying to design a politically effective "Catholic strategy" or simply wanting to take the measure of American Catholicism had better know something about people like Monsignor Higgins and Monsignor Egan -- and had better be able to parse that valedictorian's sentence.
