SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3954 words

HEADLINE: Got Water? 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: LITTLE FALLS 

 BODY:
AS the dry spring of 1999 stretched into a hot summer, streams and lakes shriveled in the sun, and officials faced a difficult choice.
 Rivers slowly sank, turning murky with silt. The sturdy Passaic River, which supplies water to about 800,000 people, became too dirty to drink. As fresh water dwindled, the Passaic filled with waste from the sewer plants that line its banks. Water companies could not clean the Passaic without adding fresh supplies from nearby reservoirs. 
 But the reservoir operators had their own problems. They, too, were losing water and having trouble meeting demands. At a meeting with the water companies, state regulators said they had reached a crisis and needed to cut back on reservoir use to protect the supply. 
"My response to the Division of Water Resources was, 'What are we going to do when I exceed the maximum contaminant levels?' " Phillip E. Roosa, chief of water quality for the Passaic Valley Water Commission, said in a recent interview. "We all sat in that room and said, 'What are we going to do?' "
In the end, state regulators had little choice. They kept the reservoir water flowing and hoped for rain. A few weeks later, their prayers were answered when a hurricane buffeted the state.
"We were fortunate," Mr. Roosa said.
The state dodged the bullet. But the problems on the Passaic in the summer of 1999 demonstrated the difficulty of managing the public water supply in a state as crowded as New Jersey. While water supplies are adequate for most parts of the state now, environmentalists and planners say that many regions -- from shore towns to the northern and western suburbs -- are in danger of using up their water.
Lack of rainfall caused worries earlier this spring. A dry spell in April and early May led several towns in northern New Jersey to impose water restrictions, and the state banned campfires because of the danger of forest fires.
Until last week's downpour added one to two inches of rain to most parts of the state, stream levels were extremely low. David A. Stedfast of the United States Geological Survey said that before the rain, about a fourth of the stations monitoring streams in the state were showing record lows for this time of the year.
"These are gauges with 30 years or more of data," Mr. Stedfast said. It is pretty unusual."
David A. Robinson, the state climatologist, said it was too early to predict whether the dry spell could turn into a full-fledged drought. 
While April was very dry, Mr. Robinson said, rainfall was abundant in March and December. Last week's downpour also cut into the deficit, although Mr. Robinson said the water level was still below average.
He noted that dry spells were not unusual, and that one or two more heavy rains could quickly bring things back to normal.
"The ground water is in pretty good shape and the reservoirs are normal," he said.
In the long term, however, many state water experts are concerned. George S. Hawkins, chairman of the New Jersey Council of Watershed Associations, put the situation in the state this way: "There is a day of reckoning that is not far off, and perhaps is already here, over the water supply. More water is being used, less water is recharging the system."
The master plan for the state's water supply -- produced every six years by the Department of Environmental Protection -- warns that the state is slowly running out of drinking water. The latest plan, issued in 1996, predicted that by 2040 New Jersey would have a deficit of about 29 million gallons per day.
To be sure, that does not mean that every part of the state will run low on water. In fact, the plan predicts that many areas, like the Raritan River Valley, will have surpluses well beyond 2040. What the plan says is that deficits from dry areas, like along the Cape May coast, will outstrip surpluses from other parts of the state.
At best, the water plan is only an estimate, and many people do not agree with its predictions. Among the critics is Robert Tudor, deputy commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, who thinks that the plan underestimated the savings through conservation and better management.
"There will be no statewide deficit," Mr. Tudor said. "We have already taken steps to avoid that."
Mr. Tudor said the 1996 plan was based on data from the 1980's, which made assumptions that were not borne out. He said the state was working on a new plan that would be finished in two years. 
Still, many people who deal with water supply on a local level feel Mr. Tudor is overconfident.
"How can the state say we are not at a deficit?" said Ella F. Filippone, executive administrator of the Passaic River Coalition. "We have just been through two droughts."
Ms. Filippone, who is also a member of the state Water Supply Advisory Council, said the water supply along the Passaic was adequate on an average yearly basis, but during periods with little rain the river level dropped rapidly and dangerously. She said the state needed better methods to deal with the dry periods, which occur every three to five years in the Passaic River basin.
"The Passaic River basin has been stressed," she said. "During times of drought, the flow of the Passaic River is 100 percent treated effluent."
Joseph A. Bella, executive director of the Passaic Valley Water Commission, said demand from such northern cities as Passaic or Clifton had been flat, but that the need for water for the growing suburbs to the north had been increasing.
"It looks to me like we are going to be reaching peak capacity sooner than they expect," Mr. Bella said. "The problem is -- is it in 10 years, or is it next year?"
MR. TUDOR acknowledges that some areas of the state are already having problems with the water supply. Along the shore, for instance, Cape May County has had saltwater creeping into underground aquifers for years. At the southern tip of the peninsula, Cape May City has already built a desalinization plant for its water supply. 
The Department of Environmental Protection recently ordered a halt to large housing developments in parts of Gloucester County because of strains on ground water in the southwestern part of the state. And the state is conducting a study on the effect that development could have on supplies in the Highlands, which are headwaters for many of New Jersey's rivers.
"There are a couple of places in New Jersey where we have to keep our eye on the ball," Mr. Tudor said. 
Yet environmentalists insist that the rapid growth of the suburbs will make it increasingly hard for state regulators to protect the water supply.
"What lies at the bottom of all the water quality and water supply issues in New Jersey is growth, and we do not deal with growth well," said Tim Dillingham, policy director for the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, a nonprofit preservationist group. "Everyone in New Jersey is downstream of someone else."
A look at Hopewell Township, for instance, is instructive. The population of Hopewell, once a collection of farms and sparse homes in Mercer County, grew almost 40 percent from 1990 to 2000. Two years ago, during an attempt to change its zoning rules to slow development, the town paid for a study of the water supply that surprised even the most ardent opponents of development.
"We are out of water," said Kathleen Bird, a member of the township committee and the planning board. Ms. Bird said if development continued unchecked, the town could have problems during a sustained drought.
Like many towns in the western part of New Jersey, Hopewell -- which uses 83 million gallons of water each year -- relies on small wells for drinking water. But according to the town's study, development has already claimed the available ground water, and any further use will begin to eat into the safety margin.
"It was certainly a wake-up call for Hopewell Township," said Mayor Mary Lou Ferrara. "We can't continue without paying the piper at some point."
Matthew Mulhall, the geologist who performed the study, said, "If we had a drought similar to the one in the 1960's, Hopewell would be using their water to the maximum."
Moreover, Mr. Mulhall said that he had performed studies for other towns including Bethlehem, Union and Lebanon, with similar results.
"Towns that are dependant on ground water are finding that often their water resources are reaching their available capacity," Mr. Mulhall said. "It is geology-related. It is also related to the number of people pulling water from the wells."
It is simple enough in concept. Problems occur when too many people try to use the same limited supply of water. But what is more difficult is determining who gets the water, and how much.
Town leaders in East Amwell, in Hunterdon County, are struggling with such a decision. The town spent years trying to preserve farms and open space from development, so when a local accountant approached the planning board with a proposal to build a small private golf course he was greeted with open arms.
"It was a land use that would protect open space," said Diane P. Griffith, vice chairwoman of the town planning board. "We were persuaded it would be better than sprawl."
But golf courses are notorious water users. Some town residents, including members of the board of health, objected to allowing golfers to siphon millions of gallons from the town aquifers.
Joel Moore, the developer, said he planned to spend $1.4 million on a high-efficiency irrigation system to preserve water, and had set aside more than seven acres for a pond to help supply water for the greens. 
"We have done our homework for water use," Mr. Moore said. He said the course was designed to use far less well water than most golf courses, estimating his system would need to draw about 27 million gallons a year from the ground water, as against more than 50 million for other 18-hole courses.
"New Jersey is very sensitive and aware of the water issue now, more than they have ever been," he said.
For now, the state Department of Environmental Protection is reviewing Mr. Moore's application, which is required of any development expected to use a large amount of water.
Tracy Carluccio, chairwoman of the town's board of health, said Mr. Moore had applied for a permit to use 54 million gallons of water a year.
"We think that is far too much," Ms. Carluccio said, adding that 15 million to 25 million gallons per year would be "much more in line with what the town's water supply could handle."
In addition, Ms. Carluccio said the ground water beneath East Amwell was limited by geography. Like much of western New Jersey, the town lies on bedrock, which does not hold large amounts of underground water.
IN other areas of the state, water supplies are already limiting growth on a large scale. Stephen M. Sweeney, the freeholder director in Gloucester County, said the lack of water was already threatening to choke development in his county. That would be a serious matter anywhere, but particularly in South Jersey, which has been struggling economically for a years.
Mr. Sweeney said commuters from Philadelphia and Wilmington were increasingly attracted to the area by the open space and relatively easy commute. But he said limited ground water had already prompted state regulators to block some large housing developments. 
"Water is going to control what is happening here," Mr. Sweeney said. "If I don't have water, I can't relocate businesses. If I don't have water, I can't create jobs."
For now, Mr. Sweeney said that the four counties in southwestern New Jersey -- Salem, Gloucester, Cumberland and Camden -- have set up a committee to review such options as expanding water service from the New Jersey American Water Company's treatment plant on the Delaware River to locations farther inland.
"We are going to try to work with the state to come up with some solutions," he said.
On the other side of the state, shore communities have been dealing with limited water supplies for years. As towns have drawn more and more ground water from aquifers, salt water has crept in from the ocean. Last year the Department of Environmental Protection provoked a great deal of criticism after it curtailed development in Cape May County by limiting sewer permits to existing town centers.
As in other parts of the shore -- where tourism brings in more than $10 billion a year to New Jersey -- state regulators have tried to strike a delicate balance in Cape May. While the area is environmentally sensitive and prone to problems with the water supply, it is also a tremendous engine of commerce.
Cape May City, a small town known for its Victorian architecture, took radical steps to protect its survival. Faced with saltwater creeping into the drinking supply, the city built a $5 million desalinization plant that does not use sea water -- a much more costly proposition -- but removes the salt from water in the city's contaminated wells.
With water levels dwindling, and the city's economy dependent on throngs of thirsty tourists, "we had no choice," said Luciano V. Corea, the administrator of Cape May City.
Mr. Corea said water use in Cape May City was driven by the summer vacation crowds. With a year-round population of 4,500 people, the city is the destination of more than a million visitors each year. The water rates, which are more than twice as high as in other parts of the state, reflect the influx -- the water company reduces the rate in the winter and increases it during the summer. Whether they realize it or not, the tourists are footing the bill for the extra treatment.
Public officials in the Cape May County are concerned that the salt in the ground water could move farther north, forcing other towns to adopt similar measures. Assemblyman Jack C. Gibson, a Republican from Cape May, has submitted a bill that would provide money for the state to examine other sources of water for the county. He said he believed that a string of deep wells in the northern part of the county along Route 9 could provide enough water for future development, provided the building was in line with the state development plan.
"This is not a study to find the means to get greater sprawl," Mr. Gibson said. "This is just to meet normal populations and those projected based on the state plan."
Economic growth is not the only concern. Environmentalists say the depletion of ground water along the Jersey Shore has already had a noticeable effect from Cape May to Monmouth County. 
People like Angela C. Andersen, who leads tours for the American Littoral Society, have during the last several years noticed lower stream levels and changes in the way marine plants grow. 
"We started seeing the grass dying off earlier, and things like that," Mrs. Andersen said. "A couple of our field trips were canceled because there was not enough water in the rivers."
Robert A. Scro, director of the Barnegat Bay Estuary Program, said stream flows had been noticeably lower across Ocean County as a result of increased development. The story was the same in all areas that depend largely on well water: new homeowners draw more ground water to drink and water lawns, and streets and parking lots prevent rainfall from recharging underground aquifers. He said the lower amount of water in the streams hurt the plants and animals that lived in the streams and in the bay.
"You have an increase in the concentration of pollutants that may be in those streams and you have an increase in salinity," Mr. Scro said. "It is a combination of negative effects when you reduce the ground water."
STATE regulators and environmentalists agree that the link between the quality of the water in the state's lakes and rivers and the available water supply is inseparable. 
Indeed, the Passaic River provides one of the most striking examples.
"New Jersey, more than any other state, has to use river flow on a daily basis for drinking water," said Jeff Tittel, executive director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club. "Everything is interrelated in New Jersey. That is why it is so critically important to clean up our rivers, because our water supply depends on it. The dirtier it gets, the more trouble we run into."
For years, the Passaic was considered one of the dirtiest rivers in the United States, the result of hundreds of years of industrial discharges. In the 1970's and 80's, the state cut back on industrial discharges into the river and oversaw the improvement of 31 sewer plants that discharge into the river and its tributaries.
The state's efforts cured most of the Passaic's ills, primarily because untreated sewage and industrial waste no longer flowed into the river in large amounts. But it did not eradicate all of the river's problems.
Although the sewer plants removed most of the contaminants from the sewage before it entered the river, they did not remove all of the pollution. The treated sewage still contained such chemicals as nitrates and phosphorous; in high concentrations, nitrates can pose a health hazard.
Usually, the chemicals are diluted by river water and do not cause serious problems. But in dry periods, when most of the water in the Passaic is treated sewage, the concentrations can reach alarmingly high levels.
That is precisely what happened in the summer of 1999.
As the Passaic River sank, the concentration of nitrates increased. In concentrations greater than 10 parts per million, nitrates can make young children seriously ill. The nitrates slowly climbed, and water plant operators like Mr. Roosa, of the Passaic Valley Water Commission, were forced to use clean reservoir water to dilute the river water and reduce the nitrates to a safe level.
At the same time, the other chemical in the sewer outflow -- phosphorous -- was making life difficult for reservoir operators. Dean Noll, a retired engineer for the North Jersey District Water Supply, said high concentrations of phosphorous caused heavy growths of algae, which clogged the reservoir intake pipes. In addition, Mr. Noll said that algae forced the reservoir operators to flush out the pipes, reducing the amount of water they could send to the plants.
Hurricane Floyd provided a temporary solution to both problems. But environmentalists say the real trouble has not gone away, and will resurface the next time the Passaic River runs low.
Ms. Filippone, of the Passaic River Coalition, said the state had the technology to deal with the nitrate problem, though state regulators had not taken action to force a solution.
"The number we don't want to reach in nitrogen is 10, and we have gotten as high as 9.5," said Ms. Fillipone. "How close do you want to get? This is a major public health issue."
Mr. Tudor, the deputy commissioner, said the state was working on a solution. In fact, the water companies have already proposed a method to decrease both nitrates and phosphorous in the river.
Mr. Roosa said the method would require a more complex operating procedure at some of the sewer plants that discharge into the Passaic. But he said it was a solution that could begin immediately. 
Two sewer plants have already tried the new procedure, and one plant operator has written a report on it. According to the report, the plant reported a 60 percent drop in nitrate pollution and a substantial decrease in phosphorous. In an unexpected benefit, the operator reported, the plant also saved money on its electric bill.
"If four major plants on the watershed were to implement the process we could achieve our goal," Mr. Roosa said.
But there is a catch. Sewer plant operators say the new method is much trickier than operating a plant under normal conditions. Even a slight mistake could result in an illegal discharge of waste from a sewer plant -- and in substantial fines for the sewer plant operator.
Pat J. Matarazzo, superintendent of the Verona Wastewater Plant, said most of the sewer plants on the river were never designed to use the new method. Mr. Matarazzo, who is writing a report on the technique for the state, said the operators would like regulators to forgive any accidental pollution that occurs if the plants switch to the new method.
"You are asking these plants to run their process on the knife edge," he said. "If we get into an upset here, we would like a little grace."
Still, state regulators have not decided whether they will require the new method, or whether they can allow for a grace period for sewer plants.
"The pilot study shows it was very effective," Mr. Tudor said, adding that his department would review the report and, if practical, make changes.
In fact, the Department of Environmental Protection is conducting several studies into public water supplies around the state. Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco is pushing 16 bills that will either directly affect the water supply or provide money to investigate solutions.
One bill, which has passed the State Senate, would better identify pending droughts in sections of the state. The acting governor has also called for regulators to investigate methods of connecting regional water systems to allow operators to shift water from one area to another during regional droughts. In combination with the geological survey, the state is also conducting studies of the large aquifers that lie underneath the southern part of the state, and the effect of growth on the Highlands. 
Of course, the largest single study will be the new version of the state water supply plan. Under state law, the plan is supposed to be completed by 2002, but Mr. Tudor said it would probably be about a year late because of the volume of work involved. He said the new plan would be far more detailed than the 1996 version, and would include detailed analyses of each of the state's watersheds.
Critics say Mr. Tudor's deadline is optimistic. David Pringle, campaign director for the New Jersey Environmental Federation, said staff cuts at the Department of Environmental Protection would make it difficult to complete the water plan quickly.
"The reason the department lacks this data is there is a lack of resources," Mr. Pringle said. "That is a direct result of the cuts made by the Whitman administration."
WHETHER the plan takes two years or more, it could not come soon enough for people in North Haledon. The town, west of Newark, has suffered through severe water problems for years, and the mayor says the state has been little help.
Tests have shown that water in North Haledon contains high levels of a suspected cancer-causing chemical called trihalomethane. Town officials temporarily closed the schools last fall after high levels of the chemical were discovered in the drinking fountains.
Trihalomethane is a byproduct of chlorination used to purify the water supply. The Passaic Valley Water Commission, which supplies water to North Haledon, is building a new water plant, which will dramatically reduce the amount of trihalomethane in the town water. The commission has scheduled the plant to open in two years.
But environmentalists say trihalomethane contamination is merely a symptom of greater problems with the water supply. The New Jersey Public Interest Research Group recently started a campaign against trihalomethane contamination, which it said was increasing in the state's water systems.
Mr. Tudor acknowledged there was a problem in North Haledon, but he said there was no evidence the amount of trihalomethane was reaching a dangerous level in other parts of the state. In addition, he said the new water plant would help solve the North Haledon's problem.
For his part, Mayor George said that the water problems had already driven people out of town.
"The problem is, I don't believe the state is taking this that seriously," Mayor George said. "Since water is such a precious commodity, I think they should do whatever it takes."

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 14LI; Column 5; Long Island Weekly Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 135 words

HEADLINE: Keeping Up With the Gatsbys 

 BODY:
 Long Island didn't crack the top 10 in Worth magazine's annual list of the 250 richest communities in America, based on median house prices. But with 36 entries, it had the largest contingent in the New York City area and on the East Coast. 
New Jersey had 19 entries, Westchester 15 and Connecticut 10. But before you brag, consider that Connecticut's 10 communities are home to 142,970 people, according to Worth, while Long Island's 36 entries have a combined population of only 119,120. (The total for Westchester is 134,288 and for New Jersey, 114,373.) 
 The No.1 spot, by the way, is held by Jupiter Island, Fla., where the median house price is $3,937,500. The prices are for single-family homes, Worth says, compiled from 80 real estate specialists around the country.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Lawyers Report an Uptick in Bankruptcy Filings

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
LAST October, the Island Medical Center in Hempstead filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Under a judge's guidance, the hospital's creditors formed a committee to look after their collective interests. The committee installed a new management team that specializes in turning around troubled hospitals. 
 "The first thing we did was eliminate a lot of senior management fat," said David N. Bukstel, the new chief executive of the medical center, which was long known as Hempstead General Hospital. "We've made, and continue to make, significant cost reductions in both non-nursing staff and in our purchasing practices." 
 Bankruptcy laws have traditionally allowed businesses like the Island Medical Center time to reorganize, become more efficient and avoid liquidation. That safety net is threatened, some critics say, by the bankruptcy legislation now before Congress. Both the House and the Senate have passed similar bills that call for changes sought by bankers and other lenders. 
Gary C. Fischoff, a bankruptcy lawyer in Garden City, said the proposed legislation would make filing for bankruptcy more difficult and more expensive. Both House and Senate versions would reduce the time allotted to small business to reorganize, Mr. Fischoff said. Both versions would also restrict eligibility for filing under Chapter 7, a route taken mainly by individuals seeking to protect their homes from lien holders, Mr. Fischoff said, and both would institute requirements, where none currently exist, that at least part of the debts be paid back. 
For their part, business owners and the bill collectors who work for them say that it's getting tougher to collect what's owed them. "Nowadays, we're seeing a new type of debtor," said Gary Sender, the director of credit and collections at the National Credit Group in Babylon. "The person with problems is the guy who has had a viable business for 15 or 20 years and then got very heavily involved with the dot-coms. When they started going out of business, that hurt a lot of people."
Several bankruptcy lawyers said that it was no longer unusual for them to represent people in their early 20's who are carrying credit-card debt of $30,000 or more.
With unpaid bills piling up -- and with concern growing about the anticipated changes in the bankruptcy system -- financially beleaguered business owners and individuals have begun showing up at Long Island lawyers' offices. Three bankruptcy lawyers said that more people were visiting their offices to discuss filing for bankruptcy. 
In April, 781 people filed petitions under Chapter 7 in Federal Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of New York, in Central Islip. That's down slightly from the March total of 816, but well above the average of 452 for the prior three months. Filings under Chapter 11 -- the provision gives businesses protection from creditors while they reorganize -- totaled 9 in March and 29 in February. Last year, the average number of monthly filings was 18, Mr. Fischoff said. 
Supporters of the proposed bankruptcy legislation, including many banks and other lenders, say that it is needed to help them deal with people who abuse the system and skip out on their debts. Opponents say that the proposal would penalize honest people who deserve a fresh start, or at least enough time to get their finances in order.
Ted Berkowitz, the partner in Farrell, Fritz, Caemmerer, Cleary, Barnovsky & Armentano who is in charge of the Uniondale law firm's commercial bankruptcy practice, said the proposal was misguided because the present system was adequate. 
Several bankruptcy lawyers said that for individual debtors, the legislation's major impact would be more stringent requirements for filing petitions under Chapter 7. 
"People who file Chapter 7 are usually individuals who owe money on credit cards and have few assets other than their house," Mr. Fischoff said. "To be allowed to file in this category, you'll have to pass through a means test that would be developed by the Internal Revenue Service."
Stuart I. Gordon, the chairman of the bankruptcy department at Shaw, Licitra, Bohner, Esernio, Schwartz & Pfluger in Garden City, said that those who go this route "benefit from what is basically a liquidation." "It offers a fresh start to people who have been honest borrowers but find themselves in difficult financial situations," he added.
Under Chapter 7 at present, borrowers unable to pay their debts agree to liquidate their assets in order to keep their homes and to pay off some of what they owe. The proposed legislation would limit filings under this provision to people who meet the new means test to be devised by the I.R.S.. Mr. Gordon said the proposal would result in more people filing under Chapter 13, which gives individuals and unincorporated businesses a chance to reorganize. And then when they end up in even more financial trouble, he said, they will finally be eligible under the revised Chapter 7. 
Mr. Gordon says the proposed changes are a departure from the premise behind current bankruptcy law: that the honest debtor deserves another chance.
"The bankruptcy code has always provided consumers with the opportunity to discharge their debts and start fresh," Mr. Gordon said. "I believe there should be such an opportunity for honest consumers. Yes, there are some bad apples out there, but the law should not be written to penalize all consumers because of them."
"The courts are going to be inundated with all kinds of administrative procedures," he predicted. "But the real pain will be on the human level. It's going to make filing for bankruptcy even more expensive and time-consuming."
Bonnie King, who owns the Strategic Personnel staffing agency in Hicksville, said the effects of the bankruptcy bill would be especially painful for small businesses at a time when a sluggish economy is already causing problems of its own. Many are already struggling to deal with clients who have fallen behind in their payments, she said, or have filed for bankruptcy and left behind huge bills. 
Meanwhile, more and more companies are insisting that vendors sign contracts that extend payment terms from weeks into months. "They insist on paying you on a slower schedule, and then they don't even live up to those terms," said Ms. King, who is the president of the Long Island chapter of the New York Association of Temporary Staffing Services. 
Ms. King said that staffing companies have been deeply affected by the bursting of the high-tech bubble. Many dot-coms relied on temporary workers, she said, but as their financing ran out, many staffing agencies were left holding the bag. 
Staffing agencies "end up as lenders, because we put up money for payroll" for client companies, Ms. King said.
"We pay their workers," she continued "and they repay us. There's enormous concern in our industry because if a client goes bankrupt, it's really going to affect us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gary C. Fischoff, a Garden City bankruptcy lawyer, contends that proposed legislation would make it harder to file for bankruptcy. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Kansas City, Kan.; 
A City Builds Its Hopes on New Kansas Speedway

BYLINE:  By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Kan. 

 BODY:
AT the end of September, on a hillside in the western outskirts of this city, the princes of auto racing will take off in a Winston Cup race before 75,000 fans at the $224 million Kansas Speedway, the newest stop on the Nascar circuit. This explosion of horsepower is expected to produce reverberations of economic development in a struggling city. 
 "Imagine a state fair and multiply it a hundred times -- that's what we're bringing here, but more upscale," said Jeff Boerger, vice president and general manager of the Kansas Speedway. "The economic impact will be huge," he added, "like having the Super Bowl and the baseball All-Star Game at the same time and place." 
 But the Winston Cup weekend will happen only once a year. While there will also be other racing events occasionally, city officials and business leaders in this town, the smaller of the two Kansas Citys, decided they wanted more. 
The unified city-county government stepped in and bought a 400-acre tract adjacent to the 1,250-acre speedway grounds and earlier this year announced the first tenants for a planned shopping and commercial development. They predict that residential development will soon follow. 
Incorporated in 1859 by Wyandot Indians displaced from Ohio, Kansas City, Kan., has a colorful history distinct from its Missouri counterpart to the east, across the wide confluence of the Missouri and Kansas rivers.
A refuge for fleeing slaves during the Civil War, it later grew into a center of railroading, milling and meatpacking. Waves of Mexican and East European immigrants were recruited early in the 20th century to operate the railroads and hoist beef carcasses for Armour, Swift and Cudahy.
After the end of World War II, the town, known locally as K.C.K., became increasingly viewed as a blue-collar, minority enclave with a serious crime problem, major social needs, a declining tax base and government by cronyism. Shopping for anything but essentials gradually dried up; the only movie theater in business today is an old drive-in. Residents who prosper tend to move across the county line on the south into the booming Johnson County suburbs or elsewhere in the five-county, bistate metropolitan area. 
While K.C.K. has been almost barren of shopping locales in recent years, the rest of the metropolitan area is saturated with malls, so K.C.K. leaders were looking for something beyond the usual mall fare to draw people. They believe they have found that in Nebraska Furniture Mart, an Omaha store that bills itself as the largest volume furniture dealer in the country, and Cabela's, a supplier of fishing and hunting gear with a cultlike following among many of the 75 million people who receive its catalogs.
ANCHORED by these two stores, the shopping district is expected to be a tourist draw on its own. Coupled with the racetrack, the area is projected to draw five million to six million people a year, not just from around the metropolitan area but from at least six surrounding states. That will help bring back into K.C.K. and its county, Wyandotte, some of the sales-tax revenue that has been soaked up by the surrounding richer communities.
"The vision for what we are calling the Tourism District started four years ago, after the city had won the speedway competition," explained William F. Crandall, vice president the Zimmer Management Company, which will act as the developer for the area adjacent to the speedway. "The mayor and other people concerned concluded that they should capitalize on this icon -- the racetrack -- so they hired a master developer, our company, to look for a way to make this a tourist destination."
Besides Nebraska Furniture and Cabela's, Zimmer has obtained commitments for a 12-screen multiplex by Warren Theaters of Wichita and a 200-seat Applebee's restaurant. It has also reached agreement with a mall developer that will sign smaller tenants. 
Nebraska Furniture Mart, owned by the Berkshire Hathaway Corporation, the company headed by the legendary investor Warren E. Buffett, plans a 450,000-square-foot store and a 130,000-square-foot distribution center. Cabela's, which plans a 175,000-square-foot store, is to start construction this summer and be open in September 2002. Nebraska Furniture Mart and the first part of the shopping mall are to be completed in the fall of 2003. The cost of this first phase of the retail area is an estimated $240 million.
Douglas G. Bach, special projects manager in the county administrator's office, said that despite the overwhelming size of the retail area, the goal is to achieve "a real quality development," using state bonds to create beauty around the asphalt. "We want to create a sense of place," he said. "We'll have a grand boulevard, a pleasant walking area with wonderful landscaping, maybe incorporating native limestone."
All of this is a long way from the heart of K.C.K. on the riverfront. More than 100 blocks stretch west from the decayed center city to the pastoral speedway site. Along the way are residential areas that gradually grow sparse, then give way to rolling farmland where cattle and horses graze.
The effort to attract the speedway began as Carol Marinovich, a former teacher who was elected mayor in 1995, was in a campaign to unify the governments of the city and Wyandotte County. After the unification measure passed in 1997, she was elected mayor and chief executive of the combined government, then re-elected this spring.
The mayor admits she was not a racing fan and had no idea of the growing economic importance of big-time auto racing when she went to the first meeting with representatives of the International Speedway Corporation, the company that, with the opening now of the Kansas Speedway, has 14 tracks around the country. International Speedway was looking for a large site somewhere in the five-county metropolitan area.
Eventually, the site offered by K.C.K. won against a site on the outskirts of Kansas City, Mo. The Kansas group enjoyed strong support from the state government and Gov. Bill Graves, who hopes the raceway will help move Kansas out of the bottom ranks of states as a tourist attraction. 
The incentive package they offered abates property taxes on the speedway for 30 years as well as state and local sales taxes. The Board of Public Utilities added a $3 million grant toward electricity and water costs. 
City officials argue that the potential payoff made the concessions worthwhile and point out that the speedway helped to attract the big anchor stores. For the commercial area, there is no property tax abatement. 
"The 400 acres was bringing in just $15,000 a year in real estate taxes before we bought the land," the mayor said. "After Phase 1 of the commercial area is completed, it will bring in $5 million a year in real estate taxes. That is money that can be used for services throughout the community. If we don't increase our economic viability, we can't put more dollars into services."
The new Kansas Speedway sits at the intersection of two interstate highways: I-70, a major east-west route, and I-435, which circles the greater metropolitan area. Mr. Boerger said this would make it possible to get spectators in and out of the speedway for an event in three and a half hours, even when the grandstand is expanded to its planned eventual size of 150,000 seats.
The grandstand, painted the blue and yellow of the Kansas state flag, overlooks a 1.5-mile tri-oval track -- an oval that has a bowed-out front stretch -- that handles speeds of 180 to 200 miles an hour. There is free parking on grass for 65,000 cars, plus rental space for recreational vehicles. Race drivers have another area in which to park their million-dollar RV's.
There is a large open-air space in which entertainers will perform before races, and a freestanding 5,000-square-foot kitchen is to feed up to 150,000 people. Sixty-eight corporate suites were snapped up at annual lease rates ranging from $29,000 for a 601-square foot suite for 32 guests to $70,000 for a 1,245-square-foot suite for 86 guests. Cabanalike "hospitality chalets" are available for seasonal rental for large parties. The University of Kansas Medical Center will operate a full trauma unit in a separate building a short distance from the track and grandstand. 
Mr. Boerger says this all adds up to "the most fan- and driver-friendly track on the circuit." And the mayor still laughs when she remembers her initial ambivalence about the speedway.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeff Boerger, vice president and general manager of Kansas Speedway, which now seats 75,000 in grandstands that are to be doubled in size. (Don Ipock for The New York Times) Map of Kansas highlighting Kansas City and location of new speedway.

HEADLINE: An American Success Story Stretches From Tashkent to Freeport 

BYLINE:  By PAULA GANZI LICATA 

 BODY:
 IT was a very foggy day," Elina Elnatanova remembered. She was 17, on her way to nursing school in Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan. "I heard the squeals and the noise of the car. Another girl was walking in front of me -- maybe they thought it was me. They grabbed the girl and put her in the car. A few days later in our school they found this girl dead." Ms. Elnatanova looks up. "I got saved by God." 
 She believes she was being followed because her family was planning to immigrate to New York. This was in 1991, a most unsettled period as the Soviet Union fell apart in earnest. "It was a really dangerous time," Ms. Elnatanova said. 
Ms. Elnatanova had aspired to be a doctor, but religion got in the way. "This was one of the main reasons we left," she said. "We couldn't practice our Judaism in Russia. I was specifically told in school that I'm not getting into the medical school because I'm Jewish." So she went to nursing school instead. 
This account of living life looking in the rear-view mirror is difficult to imagine now, seeing Ms. Elnatanova, her sister Irina and their father, Gennadiy, in the bustling offices of Irina Signs, the family-owned business on Merrick Road in Freeport.
Now their biggest problem seems to be not having enough hours in a day, although they appear to make the most of the usual 24. Phones ring relentlessly. The counter is crowded with computers and work orders.
Theirs is an American success story. At 18, Mr. Elnatanov had his own company and went on to own three factories, with contracts from 13 of the 15 Soviet republics. The family lived a middle-class life in Tashkent.
"Whatever my father earned, they took away, so we couldn't go higher than middle class," said Elina Elnatanova, 26. "He knew in America he could grow."
Ms. Elnatanova remembers the day, Aug. 19, 1991, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev was deposed. "The radio and TV were not working," she said. "This is what Communism is -- you don't know what's going on. In 1992, we applied for papers and went on an interview through an American agency in Moscow." Later that year, the family -- Mr. Elnatanov; his wife, Zoya; and Irina, Elina and their sister, Karina, now 16 -- immigrated to the United States.
An aunt had arranged for an apartment, and the New York Association for New Americans gave the family money, food stamps and transit tokens. Friends and family already settled in New York were supportive, but many advised Mr. Elnatanov, now 51, that he was too old to start over. He assumed his assimilated Russian friends, used to American ways, knew best. But as an artist and successful businessman, he found that doing nothing wasn't easy.
In 1993 Mr. Elnatanov and his two older daughters borrowed $50,000 from friends, bought a computer and the next year leased a storefront in Jamaica, Queens. The family's resilience was put to the test. Two days after signing the lease, Mr. Elnatanov fell off a ladder and broke both arms, leaving his daughters to build the office interiors.
"We couldn't hire anybody -- we didn't have any money," Ms. Elnatanova said. "And we had to put a lot of money into advertising to get people to know about us."
It worked. They outgrew the storefront in five years and bought the building in Freeport.
Assistance came in many forms. When they needed a loan to buy a Saber 408 carving machine last December, Ellen Kelly, Freeport's director of community development, suggested that they talk to the Community Development Corporation of Long Island. This nonprofit organization issues loans to small businesses that are unable to borrow from traditional financial institutions. Referring to Trevor Davis, a senior vice president and the chief lending officer, Ms. Elnatanova said, "In one day, he got us approved," and the development corporation provided a $15,000 loan in 48 hours.
Then when the carving machine, which is 9 feet long and 4 feet wide, was delivered to Irina Signs, the Elnatanovs were unable to move it. So their neighbors at Prestige Marble and Tile and Roma Marble Pompeii lent their forklifts. 
Stuart Schrager, an account executive at WHLI-FM (KJOY 98.3), met the Elnatanovs during the Freeport Waterfront Festival last year. When Irina Signs needed more financing, Mr. Schrager lent them $2,000. 
"Maybe he knows we're not baloney guys," Ms. Elnatanova said. "Stuart said, 'I don't know why, but I trust you.' "
After the family arrived in the United States in 1992, Ms. Elnatanova persuaded the owner of a sign company in Long Island City to allow her father to work for nothing, with Ms. Elnatanova as his translator. Soon she learned how to operate the word processor and the engraving machine and had mastered the mechanics of the business. 
Thus inspired, she changed careers and enrolled in math and computer courses at Hunter College, where she graduated in 1997. She is now Irina Signs' manager of graphic design and quality production. 
Her sister Irina, now 28, enrolled at St. John's University and received her degree in math and computer science in 1998. She now spends most of her time out of the office, overseeing jobs and calling on clients and prospective clients, showing them pictures of the family's living room, which their father has transformed with intricately detailed hand-carved moldings. 
Customers seem to like Irina Signs' work. John Spectrum, the owner of the Spectrum Contracting Corporation in Franklin Square, said, "They're the only sign company I use now." 
One of Irina Signs' contracts was to supply signs for renovated storefronts in the Town of Freeport's Church Street project. John Talty, the project's general contractor, said, "They brought the product in on time, on schedule and at the right price."
For his part, Mr. Elnatanov works just as hard in the United States as he did in Uzbekistan, he said in Russian, translated by his daughter Elina. And he still worries about money. "He feels the pressure of the bills," she said. But one thing he no longer worries about is his family's safety. Carefully choosing the English words, he said, "I sleep here better."

A Diverse Island
This series looks beyond the stereotypes that sometimes taint relations between immigrants and native Long Islanders, examining immigrants' lives and how they are being woven -- or not -- into the social and economic fabric.

HEADLINE: More Than a Sewing Fancy 

BYLINE:  By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
OH, the stories buttons tell. Buttons, 15,000 of them, to wear, to flaunt, to dream on -- in brass, glass, hand-painted enamel, cloisonne and ivory. They are the newly acquired makings of a permanent exhibition that opened May 2 at the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury. 
 The kaleidoscopic cache represents a distinctive windfall -- a gift from the Waterbury Companies, a manufacturer that had its own button museum for many years. 
 "When the Waterbury Companies decided to sell the Waterbury Button Company, one of the assets that was kept was the button museum," said Carl Contadini, president of Waterbury Companies Inc.
Rachael E. Guest, an assistant curator of the Mattatuck Museum, said the company considered breaking up the collection and selling it. "But instead they decided the right thing to do was to keep it intact because it is an important part of Waterbury's history," she said. 
The manufacture of buttons, first by hand and then by machine, has been a mainstay of the region's economy since the late 18th century. That story is documented in a community history exhibition on the museum's first floor where several button-making machines are displayed along with pictures, including one of an eagle, fashioned from buttons. 
The Button Museum was originally assembled more than 50 years ago by the man who was then president of the Waterbury Button Company, Warren F. Kaynor. It was created with buttons rich not only in the history of Waterbury and Connecticut but of the world. 
At the Mattatuck Museum 10,000 buttons are on display, and that's not the entire collection. Researchers can make use of of binders of samples of every button made by the Waterbury Button Company.
The buttons are considered to be miniature works of art, reflecting changing artistic influences. Made in a variety of materials -- glass, porcelain, pearl, metal, bone, wood and jade -- they are decorated with motifs that include images of military heroes, feats of engineering and storybook characters. One brass button shows Little Red Riding Hood with a rather docile-looking wolf sitting next to her.
The exhibit includes four engraved bronze buttons, taken from General George Washington's coat. The buttons had been removed and divided among his descendants (remaining in the Washington family until 1930). They are now mounted on a morocco case.
Other eye stoppers include carved cinnabar from Asia, Japanese netsuke and colorful Bakelite buttons from the 1930's, lighthearted symbols of a sail boat, Scottie, ear of corn or a penguin.
There are floral bouquets made of human hair placed under glass, military buttons, black glass and marquisette buttons popularized by Queen Victoria and a case of tiny Jenny Lind portrait buttons. Habitat buttons made in France preserve plant or insects under glass, "some referred to as paperweight buttons because they are made the same way," Ms. Guest said.
"There are buttons here for everyone, buttons that would appeal to men -- uniform, sporting, showing a football player; buttons that appeal to women; and kids love them."
"Everybody grew up with someone in their family who had a box of buttons, so it has a strong tug to family memories," Ms. Guest said, adding, "This is a particularly special button collection because of Waterbury's button-making history. It reaches out to people, representing both the local community as well as the larger community of the world." 
The Mattatuck Museum, 144 West Main Street in Waterbury, is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Sundays noon to 5 p.m. (closed Sundays in July and August.) Information: (203) 753-0381.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
A Study Dares to Question the 401(k)

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AT a time when Congress is considering raising the annual investment limits on 401(k) plans, to $15,000 from $10,500, a new study suggests that many people should invest less, or not at all. For some low- to moderate-income workers, investing in these tax-deferred retirement accounts may actually raise their taxes and reduce the amount of money they have available to spend over their lifetimes.
 My father would have been shocked. When I was in my 20's and in my first job out of college, he preached to me about the benefits of tax-deferred savings. He then asked if I had opened an individual retirement account. 
 "I don't have $2,000," I said, referring to the annual investment limit.
"I'll loan it to you," he said.
"But I'd still have to pay it back," I said.
"Take your time," he said.
For my normally frugal father, this was an extraordinary offer, and I took it. When my employer later offered a 401(k) plan, I had learned my lesson and signed up.
Millions of baby boomers have done the same thing. Of the 39.6 million people invested in 401(k) plans at the end of 1999, the latest year for which numbers were available, 21.5 million, or 54 percent, were held by baby boomers, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington.
But Laurence J. Kotlikoff, an economics professor at Boston University, who wrote this new study with Jagadeesh Gokhale and Todd Neumann, economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, said many households with incomes of $50,000 or less that invest in 401(k) plans could lose the full benefit of the mortgage deduction as the contributions lower their tax bracket. The study, which used theoretical examples, said families would be pushed into a higher bracket when they withdraw money from the plan.
Even worse, he said, the withdrawals will increase their incomes so much that a larger percentage of their Social Security benefits will be taxed by the federal government. (He said richer households do not have that problem because their Social Security benefits are already taxed at the upper limit.)
According to the study, which is expected to be published next month, a married couple earning $50,000 combined at age 25 will indeed do well in a 401(k) if it returns a steady 4 percent a year. Their lifetime taxes will go down; the money they have available to spend will go up. But if the return increases to 6 percent, their taxes increase 1.1 percent and their available money falls by 0.39 percent. With an 8 percent return, taxes rise 6.38 percent and available money falls 1.73 percent.
And that leads to the question: Why get into an investment at all if you have to hope it does not do too well? (The authors also discovered that I.R.A.'s generally do not share the same problems as 401(k)'s, but they will if Congress increases the I.R.A. investment maximum to $5,000, a move it is considering.)
"A lot of people don't take advantage of 401(k) participation," Dr. Kotlikoff said. "They may be smarter than their employers."
He said he and his co-authors were surprised by the findings and ran the numbers again and again in ESPlanner, a personal finance program he and his colleagues created (www.esplanner.com).
"We discovered this by accident," he said. "Then we started scratching our heads wondering if we did something wrong."
Ted Benna, president of the 401(k) Association, a retirement consulting firm in Bellefonte, Pa., and the person who designed the first 401(k) plan 20 years ago, said what was wrong was the idea of discouraging people to save. He said that no matter what the numbers showed, the plans were invaluable not so much for their tax benefits, but for the forced savings they promoted. He said most people would not save outside of a 401(k).
"For 90 percent of the work force, that won't work," Mr. Benna said. "There are too many things that come up to make it easier to spend -- the washing machine blows up, the car breaks down."
MY 401(k) has grown to an amount my father couldn't have imagined all those years ago. I silently thank him every time my monthly statement arrives. I'm glad I started it when I was young and poorer because I wouldn't have saved otherwise. I needed the push; I needed the 401(k).
Dr. Kotlikoff said he realized people need a push, but he said lower-income people shouldn't be penalized in the process. He urges employers to set up non-401(k) investment plans modeled after the Roth I.R.A.'s, which are not taxed at withdrawal. And Washington must step in. "Congress needs to rethink our entire savings incentive strategy," he said. "The current system can be a highly regressive and a bad deal for the poor."

PERSON: Francisco Gil Diaz 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Giving Mexico Its Tax Medicine

BYLINE:  By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY 

 BODY:
TEN years before Francisco Gil Diaz became Mexico's finance minister in December, he was playing the role of tough cop. As the nation's chief tax collector, he and his auditors hunted down hundreds of Mexico's most notorious tax evaders and systematically imprisoned them.
 Today Mr. Gil (pronounced heel) no longer chases bad guys, but he has not forgotten those days. A practicing Catholic, he says that he identifies with Matthew, the tax collector in the New Testament who became an apostle. Mr. Gil, now in charge of protecting Mexico's economic welfare, finds himself preaching a familiar message: thou shalt pay thy taxes. 
 Mexico, as hard as it has tried, has found it nearly impossible to get people to consistently pay what they owe the government. There are gaping loopholes in the system and up to 40 percent of the population may be off the tax rolls. So when Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, took office in December, he made it clear that fiscal reform would be a major part of his economic policy and that Mr. Gil would spearhead the cause. 
Six months later, thanks in part to Mr. Gil, Mexico is weathering the United States economic downturn well. Its currency, the peso, is the strongest it has been in nearly three years. And less than two weeks ago Citigroup made the biggest single foreign investment in Mexico's history, purchasing the Banacci financial group for $12.5 billion.
But it remains unclear whether Mr. Gil can convince lawmakers to enact his tax agenda. Few can challenge Mr. Gil's qualifications to reform Mexico's tax structure. His doctoral dissertation at the University of Chicago was called "Three Essays on the Taxation of Capital." In his 30 years of government service, split between the Finance Ministry and Central Bank, he helped write 10 federal budgets. And in a country where politicians have often abused their power, Mr. Gil earned a reputation for incorruptibility.
When he was under secretary of revenue from 1988 to 1994, two economic analysts said, he audited members of his own family more closely than average citizens. And his legacy is found in Mexico's penal system, where the nearly 500 tax evaders he arrested were known as Gilitos, or Gil's little ones.
Apart from Mr. Gil's disciplinarian qualities, he is regarded -- by himself, among others -- as one of the nation's most influential economic minds. As an economics professor at the Autonomous Technical Institute of Mexico, he influenced a generation of students who became policy makers. His economic philosophy, inherited from the Chicago school of Milton Friedman and Robert Mundell, makes him an ardent, sometimes inflexible, proponent of free-market policies.
"There's no doubt about it. Gil Diaz has a strong character, and is seen as someone who couldn't care what other parties and what other people have to say," Jonathan Heath, the chief economist for Latinsource Mexico, an investment advisory firm, said. "He has all the answers."
In 1997, Mr. Gil's firmness of conviction may have cost him a nomination to become the governor of the Central Bank. At the time he was a member of the bank's board of governors, and following the 1995 peso crisis he promoted a plan that would have eventually locked the peso's value to the dollar. Ernesto Zedillo, then president (and an economist trained at Yale), disagreed strongly. Mr. Zedillo eventually chose Guillermo Ortiz, who was more aligned with Mr. Zedillo's economic philosophy.
Mr. Gil left government and became director general of Avantel, a Mexican telecommunications company partly owned by WorldCom. He fought to gain market share from Telefonos de Mexico, the near-monopolistic telephone company known as Telmex and run by Carlos Slim, Mexico's richest man. Mr. Gil quickly pointed his guns at the government.
At the time, Avantel was paying about 75 percent of its gross revenue to Telmex just to route calls through its network. In a court battle that lasted three years, Mr. Gil sued the government almost on a weekly basis, charging it with not doing enough to enforce competition laws.
In an interview, Mr. Gil said that one day after joining Avantel, he was asked what he felt about the government. "My answer was, 'I already hate bureaucrats.' "
He said many people incorrectly assumed he was fighting Telmex, but noted that Mr. Slim was doing what anyone would have done given that amount of power. "It wasn't Slim's fault; it was the government's fault. The enemy was the government."
Even so, just a few days before Mr. Fox's inauguration as the first president to break seven decades of one-party rule, Mr. Gil was back in government, this time sitting in the Cabinet. Friends say that the decision was not an easy one. Mr. Gil's wife suffered a severe stroke three years ago and her health is fragile. In addition, Mr. Gil, 57, was taking a significant cut in pay from his Avantel position.
So far he has dedicated the bulk of his energy to fiscal reform. For Mr. Gil, that would culminate 30 years of effort to overhaul the nation's tax structure. But politics has been a stumbling block: his legislation contains a proposed 15 percent value-added tax on food and medicine, and though President Fox has placed an enormous amount of his political capital behind it, Congress and the public have shown little enthusiasm. The bill has been shelved until fall.
Some political analysts in Mexico City say the stalled bill is testament to Mr. Gil's lack of political charm.
TAXING food and medicine guarantees that "there is going to be an outcry," he said. "I wouldn't change anything to the fiscal reform proposal, but that doesn't mean it's perfect." But Mr. Gil is in no hurry. He wants the tax reform to be permanent, and Mr. Fox's government has five and a half more years to run.
"He is very convinced of what he's doing," said Manuel Sanchez Ugarte, president of the Federal Antitrust Commission and a friend and former colleague of Mr. Gil's. He said Mr. Gil had returned to government "not because he wants to be powerful, but because he feels his job will make a difference to the country."
Mr. Gil said his goal always has been "to push toward a market economy, work toward having the government perform its functions -- which it doesn't."
"A government that doesn't provide justice," he said, "that doesn't provide defense of property rights, that doesn't provide security, cannot even think of doing something else."

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: CITIES; 
STATE PLAN FOR CAMDEN

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson 

 BODY:
 Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week disclosed the state's latest plan for Camden. By carefully courting local officials and by dangling the prospect of $150 million in new state investment in the city, Mr. 
DiFrancesco succeeded where former Governor Whitman failed in winning support for the plan from city leaders. HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for GORDON E. MOORE; 
Technology Intensifies the Law of Change

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
GORDON E. MOORE and Robert N. Noyce co-founded Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957 and, a decade later, they co-founded the Intel Corporation. In a paper Mr. Moore published in Electronics Magazine in 1965, he articulated the concept that underpins what has become known as Moore's Law: the power of a silicon chip will double every 18 to 24 months, accelerating the pace of technological change.
 Mr. Moore, 72, an "accidental entrepreneur," as he calls himself, is one of the pioneers of Silicon Valley. Since 1997 he has been chairman emeritus at Intel which, under his management, grew into the global leader in computer chip design and manufacturing, with nearly $34 billion in annual revenue. 
 On April 11, Mr. Moore announced he would retire from Intel by the end of this month. In a telephone interview last Wednesday, excerpted below, he spoke about the implications of high-speed technology. MATT RICHTEL

Q.One consequence of the pace of technological change, and perhaps a byproduct of Moore's Law, is that consumers sometimes feel that the moment they buy a computer it becomes obsolete or, at least, no longer a cutting edge product. How do we resolve that frustration?

A. That's a real problem. The industry has established the fact that if you wait a year you can get something that delivers higher performance and lower cost. But by doing that you never take advantage of what's here. I think it's a byproduct that is built into a technology that's changing this fast. The solution is not to make progress and I don't think that's a good answer.

Q. Has the increased pace of technological change driven change in other parts of our lives? Is life moving more quickly, and is that a good thing?

A. Certainly, the exponential nature of change is what Moore's Law is all about. I don't know how to define if it's good or not. It certainly puts a strain on people. The only thing that's constant is change these days. For people who find change something that they're not content with, I could imagine it being a real problem. It probably affects those of us in the tech industry more than anyone else. We've learned to live with it. The collective effect is large and generally positive. If you look at the way a lot of things are influenced by the rapid flow of technology -- learning things faster, our medical systems are greatly improved, automobiles are more reliable -- all of these things are a result of technology's rapid change and positive contributions.

Q. What in your view is the future of Intel, and of your legacy?

A. They're not quite the same. Intel is a major company in a very rapidly moving industry. As long as we can anticipate and make the right moves, we have the opportunity to grow -- but in an industry that does change this fast, you have a lot of opportunity to make mistakes. That's what we have to do: avoid making major mistakes. As to my legacy, as ridiculous as it seems to me now, it's probably going to be Moore's Law.

Q.Do you see troubling side effects from the widespread use of personal computers? For instance, the effect they have at work of physically isolating people? What, if anything, keeps you up at night worrying?

A. What keeps me up at night is doing my own e-mail. I wouldn't say anything keeps me up at night worrying. Anything that changes -- in a dramatic way -- the way we do things, requires us to give up doing things that may have been attractive before. I'm amazed to see how many people working at Intel are sitting at terminals pushing buttons where previously they may have been working together. I guess that does introduce a kind of an isolation but it sure is an effective way to do things, essentially 24 hours a day. It gives a lot of capability for which there is a sacrifice. I'm not sure it sacrifices much more than did the introduction of the automobile assembly line, where employees could see each other but not hear each other. I'm not sure it's a qualitative difference.

Q. What do you see as the most prominent threats to United States economic dominance in the future?

A. I have a concern that we're not training enough of the U.S. population to maintain our technical lead. Our outstanding universities, which are the envy of the world, are training half foreign-born students who are going back to where they came from. I see our tech companies taking advantage of well-trained people in other countries. But we're in danger of exporting a lot of technological advantage because we're not training enough people here. Education, that's our Achilles' heel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gordon E. Moore (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COLUMBUS CIRCLE; 
Bookstore. Rent Increase. Moving Plans. Sound Familiar?

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
The place buzzes with life, reams of it. The books look robust, their spines erect, their pages warm. The people talk and laugh under the rinky-dink yellow letters that say "Coliseum Books." 
 For 27 years, the bookstore, one of the few independents left in Midtown, has stocked its ample shelves at 57th Street and Broadway with everything from classics to cartoons to best sellers to coffee-table books. More than 100,000 volumes go on and on, as if forever. 
 Or maybe just until the end of January, when the bookstore's lease expires.
The building was acquired in 2000 by the Moinian Group. The group's chief executive, Joseph Moinian, wants to more than double the rent, to $250 or $300 a square foot, for the ground floor.
"It's absolutely impossible," said George Leibson, an owner of Coliseum Books. "The rent right now is too high for us. We're losing money."
Jeffrey Roseman, an executive vice president of Newmark New Spectrum Retail, the leasing agent for the building, said, "We'd love to keep Coliseum, but they just can't really pay the rent." 
He added: "Fortunately for him, he has had a fantastic corner that he's had a long-term lease on. Obviously, things change a little bit."
Mr. Roseman said Newmark had offered Coliseum a smaller entryway on the ground floor, and a smaller portion of the space the store occupies on that floor, plus space on the lower level, though its rent would still increase. But Mr. Leibson rejects the offer.
"It's not anywhere close to the value that they're asking for," Mr. Leibson said. "It's not good space." He said he was looking for another location.
"It's a changing economic environment, a changing business environment, a changing real estate environment," he said. "It's no one's fault. It's just the nature of the game. The book business is not a high-margin business. It never has been." ERIKA KINETZ

CORRECTION-DATE: June 24, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on May 27 about the expiration of Coliseum Books' lease misstated the renewal terms offered by Newmark New Spectrum Retail. The rent would not increase; it would decrease by about 20 percent.
