HEADLINE: As Others Abandon Plains, Indians and Bison Come Back 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: FORT YATES, N.D. 

 BODY:
In writing the obituary of the Great Plains, social historians have looked out at the abandoned ranches, collapsed homesteads and dying towns huddled against the wind in a sea of grass and seen an epic failure. 
 And the numbers do tell a compelling story. More than 60 percent of the counties in the Great Plains lost population in the last 10 years. An area equal to the size of the original Louisiana Purchase, nearly 900,000 square miles, now has so few people that it meets the 19th-century Census Bureau definition of frontier, with six people or fewer per square mile. And a large swath of land has slipped even further, to a category the government once defined as vacant. 
 But something else is under way from the Badlands of the Dakotas to the tallgrass fields of Oklahoma: a restoration of lost landscape and forgotten people, suggesting that European agricultural settlement of big parts of the prairie may have been an accident of history, or perhaps only a chapter. 
As the nearly all-white counties of the Great Plains empty out, American Indians are coming home, generating the only significant population gains in a wide stretch of the American midsection. At the same time, the frontier, as it was called when it was assumed that the land would soon be spotted with towns and farms, is actually larger than it has been since the early 20th century. 
These changes have been under way for decades. But they have reached a point -- 108 years after Frederick Jackson Turner suggested that the American frontier was closed, with the buffalo herds wiped out and native populations down to a few tribes -- that there are now more Indians and bison on the Plains than at any time since the late 1870's. 
"What's happening is really quite astonishing," said Patricia Locke, a Lakota and Chippewa elder and a MacArthur Foundation fellow who returned to the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation here several years ago. "It's like an evacuation one way, and a homecoming in the other."
Indians, of course, are still a fraction of the overall Plains population, making up just under 8 percent of the population in the state, Oklahoma, where they have the biggest population, 272,601 people. 
But while many Plains counties lost 20 percent or more of their population, the overall Indian population grew by 20 percent in North Dakota, 23 percent in South Dakota, 18 percent in Montana, 20 percent in Nebraska and 12 percent in Kansas. Some of this can be attributed to better counting and higher birthrates, but tribal officials say there has been steady in-migration dating to the mid-1980's. 
In North Dakota alone, 47 of the 53 counties lost population. Among the handful that gained people were three counties populated primarily by Indians.
In South Dakota, half of the counties lost people. But the second-fastest-growing county, Shannon, is in the heart of Indian country, on the Pine Ridge Reservation, a county that is 94 percent Indian and grew by 26 percent in the last census.
And much of Montana is nearly as open today as it was when Lewis and Clark explored there nearly 200 years ago. All but four of the counties in the flat eastern part of the state lost population; of those with gains, three contain Indian reservations. 
"All of these numbers suggest that the experiment on much of the northern Plains with European agricultural settlement may soon be ending," said Myron Gutmann, a University of Texas professor who is an authority on Plains population trends. 
As Indians have moved home, on or near reservation lands, whites have fled the counties that were opened to homesteading in the last of the great Western land rushes in the early 20th century. 
The whitest county in the nation, Slope County, N.D., is down to 767 people; all but three of its residents are white. By contrast, in 1915, six years after the prairie was opened to ranchers and farmers through the Enlarged Homestead Act, Slope County was bustling, with 4,945 people. Now the county seat, Amidon, has 25 people, and the population density, less than one person per square mile, is well below the 19th-century Census Bureau definition of land that is vacant or wilderness. 
Much of North Dakota has a ghostly feel to it: empty homesteads and occasional schoolhouses litter the land, with caved-in roofs and grass growing where there used to be front porches. The wind blows so hard that a cup of coffee brought outside develops whitecaps. 
Cattle ranching and farming of wheat, barley and corn still prevail, especially on large corporate farms in the middle and southern plains. But in Slope, Hettinger, Adams, Grant, Burke, Divide, Garfield or any of the hundreds of other plains counties that seem to have one foot in the grave, land is being left to the wind and sparse rain. 
In publicly owned prairie land, the native grasses and wildflowers have returned, and species like prairie dogs, black-footed ferrets, burrowing owls and bison have made comebacks. Much of this land will never be plowed again, for a third of the nation's 3.7 million acres of national grassland is designated roadless under a measure started by President Bill Clinton over the objections of many in the region's Congressional delegation. Other parts are managed by private groups like the Nature Conservancy, which has been buying up ranches and homesteads. 
"I'm an old prairie guy, and it does my heart good to see so much of the Plains greening up again with native species," said Greg Schenbeck, a wildlife biologist with the grasslands division of the Forest Service. "And I tell you, people who come to visit are really excited -- they talk about the expansiveness, the openness, the grass stretching to the horizon."
At the turn of the century, only a few hundred buffalo were left in the West. Now there are 300,000, and more than 30 tribes in the northern Plains are controlling large herds on land where bison, unlike cattle, need no help to flourish. A third of the nation's 31 accredited Indian colleges offer bison management. 
"Just having these animals around, knowing what they meant to our ancestors, and bringing kids out to connect to them has been a big plus," said Mike Faith, who manages the bison herd on the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation here, not far from where Sitting Bull was killed.
Indians have the highest rate of diabetes in the nation. Part of the overall restoration of the Plains is an effort to get bison meat, which is low in cholesterol and fat, back into the Indian diet. 
"We're probably one of the few ethnic communities that have been blessed with a God-given creature to help restore us," said Donald Lake, director of the Inter-Tribal Bison Co-operative of Rapid City, S.D., a nonprofit group that works to repopulate Indian country with bison. 
Mr. Lake, a Santee Sioux from Nebraska, has returned to the Plains after living for years in Los Angeles. He likes the slower pace, the connection to other Indians, the low prices. He winces at the description that the historian Turner used to describe frontier land as it became populated with Europeans. It was, Turner wrote, "the place where civilization meets savagery."
Many Indians have moved back to reservations because of jobs in the casinos, the so-called new buffalo, which have been the main economic salvation. On the Standing Rock Reservation, for example, the casino is the county's biggest job provider, employing 376 people, and it has expanded six times since it opened in 1993.
But Indian reservations remain among the poorest places in the nation, with high unemployment, high out-of-wedlock birthrates and chronic drug and alcohol abuse. 
Still, life has improved. Tourism has increased. People come to look at bison, tribal officials say; others pay up to $2,500 for the right to hunt them. People interested in the Plains tribes' history are also drawn to the prairie. 
"Sitting Bull is one of the biggest names in the world, and he still has family here," said Elaine McLaughlin, the Standing Rock tribal secretary. "A lot of people in state government seem surprised when people show up from all over because they want to know more about Indians."
The re-emergence of a Great Plains of Indians and bison was foretold in 1987 by two Rutgers University professors, Frank J. Popper and his wife, Deborah E. Popper. They said white depopulation would accelerate, as it became clear that farming and building towns on the arid Plains was "the largest, longest-running agricultural and environmental miscalculation in American history." 
They proposed a "Buffalo Commons" in the empty counties, an open range populated by the species that once thundered over the land. People throughout the prairie scorned their idea, and the Poppers became the objects of intense hatred. But their idea has been revived of late, with little rancor. 
While the Poppers may ultimately be proved right in several respects, they were wrong in one major sense: In their vision, government would be the driving force, buying land and bringing buffalo back, then turning some of it over to Indians to manage.
Now, in a twist, it is government that keeps the white farming and ranching communities alive, through annual subsidies of more than $20 billion. Many historians have long argued that white settlement, particularly of the northern Plains, was largely government-induced from the start, through subsidies to railroads and homesteaders. 
"If the government ever pulled out, the Buffalo Commons would come on like a storm," Mr. Popper said.
Indians and bison have returned by self-initiative and free enterprise, helped by the success of casinos. 
"The people coming back, they get their degrees and they start their own businesses, or take jobs as teachers here on the reservation," said Anita Blue of the Turtle Mountain Reservation in North Dakota, where the population in the Indian-dominated county grew 7.1 percent. 
The idea of Manifest Destiny in reverse is scoffed at by many people, especially in the dying counties. 
But a sense of irrevocable change pervades the northern Plains. "There is a lot of that Buffalo Commons idea that's probably true," said Gov. John Hoeven of North Dakota, a Republican elected on a pledge to revitalize the state. "It's never going to look like it did before, when all the farms and ranches were healthy."

HEADLINE: Still Uncertain, Budget Surplus Is Gobbled Up 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26 

 BODY:
For the last three years, the federal budget surplus has been a sketch pad for the dreams of politicians, promising progress on an array of initiatives by both parties.
 But substantial portions of the surplus projected have now been set aside, first for reducing the national debt and then for the tax cut that Congress sent to President Bush today. When the price tags of all the additional programs planned by one party or the other or both are tallied, a funny thing turns out to have happened to the surplus: Even before it materializes, it has been largely parceled out. 
 Some doubt remains about whether the windfall will appear as forecast, especially given the shaky state of the economy. But even if it does, it most likely will not cover everything that Democrats and Republicans have on their wish lists. 
So when Congress returns from its Memorial Day recess early next month to start working in earnest on spending bills for next year, it will be heading toward showdowns over how to divide the remainder. 
Members will be debating how to parcel the money among a multitude of priorities, including the military, health care and medical research, education, additional tax cuts and preparing Social Security and Medicare for the aging of the population. 
With Democrats in control of the Senate, the partisan battle over priorities will only be more intense. 
"Starting from the premise that it's all going to be there, it does seem to me that the surplus is overcommitted, at least rhetorically," said Robert L. Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a group that advocates balanced budgets. 
"The tax cut is going to constrain the other choices," Mr. Bixby said.
With Mr. Bush vowing to hold down the growth in government spending, Democrats face a particularly difficult challenge in winning full financing for the programs they favor. But the arithmetic is daunting for both sides. There are Republicans who are as concerned about the availability of money for a Pentagon buildup and assistance to farmers as Democrats are about increases for schools and Medicare.
In some ways, the coming budget battles will be reminiscent of the days, not so long ago, when every decision about taxes and spending had to be considered against the desire not to deepen the budget deficit. Now, in a very different fiscal climate, neither party wants to be blamed for dipping into Social Security or Medicare to pay for additional spending, a restriction that favors Republicans now that they have claimed their share for tax cuts. 
The budget surplus over the next decade is projected by both the White House and the Congressional Budget Office to be $5.6 trillion.
Of that, just under $2.5 trillion would come from excess Social Security revenue. The two parties have pledged to use the Social Security surplus only to reduce the $3.1 trillion national debt or to strengthen the retirement system.
Mr. Bush's tax cut would use up almost $1.7 trillion over the 10-year period -- the $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over a decade starting next year, plus about $370 billion in interest costs from using the surplus for tax cuts rather than to reduce the national debt. The two parties have also agreed to set aside for debt reduction another $400 billion over the next 10 years in excess revenue now being generated by Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund.
Between the tax cut and the Medicare and Social Security money being set aside for debt reduction, the $5.6 trillion surplus has been reduced by $4.6 trillion, leaving about $1 trillion unallocated.
By conservative estimates, a handful of the major campaign promises and policy initiatives set out by the two parties in the last few years would bump right up against the $1 trillion.
There is bipartisan agreement that providing prescription drug coverage for retirees and overhauling Medicare would cost at least $300 billion over a decade. Mr. Bush's plan to modernize and upgrade the armed forces is expected to cost a minimum of $250 billion. 
Extending a long series of tax breaks that are routinely reauthorized would eat up $100 billion. Addressing a looming technical problem in the tax code -- the inadvertent extension of the alternative minimum tax to middle and upper-middle income taxpayers -- would cost another $100 billion. The education bills making their way through Congress could increase spending by $150 billion over the next decade.
Those estimates alone add up to $900 billion, or at least $1 trillion when the interest cost is included. But the cost of many of the programs could be considerably higher.
The costs of establishing a comprehensive prescription drug benefit for retirees, for example, could be hundreds of billions of dollars more than the $300 billion set aside by Congress, health care analysts say. There is still no estimate of what it would cost to develop and deploy a national missile defense of the type sought by Mr. Bush. Earlier this year, the Senate voted for a budget plan that included more than $300 billion for additional education spending over 10 years.
Republicans are already pressing for further tax cuts, some of which have bipartisan support. Emergencies, from wars to droughts and floods, typically claim billions of dollars a year. And there are many other programs that will no doubt be allocated a portion of the surplus, especially aid to farmers, benefits for veterans and federally financed medical research.
Democrats said something will have to give. "There will not be any money available to do what people are promising in education once this tax cut goes through," said Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York. 
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, who will become chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee when the Democrats assume control of the Senate, said the tax cut and other budget decisions already made this year "have soaked up scarce dollars that are needed for education, Social Security, Medicare, a prescription drug benefit and the many other important priorities of the American people."
The concern is not wholly partisan. Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, said the tax cut could make it difficult for the administration to make good on its promise to provide more money to the Pentagon. "In the wake of large tax cuts, nondefense spending initiatives and uncertain surplus projections," Mr. McCain said, "we cannot be sure how much money will remain for such defense priorities as national missile defense, force modernization, spare parts, flight hours, overdue facility maintenance, training programs and the care of our service members." 
Other Republicans in Congress and administration officials say there is plenty of money, especially if the government re-examines whether the money it is already spending is being put to good use.
"There's a trillion dollars in the next decade, uncommitted," said Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget. "That ought to be more than enough to meet the nation's legitimate needs over that time period. Someone intent on spending much more than that ought to examine the fairness of that view to Americans who are paying the highest income taxes in history." 
Democrats said that while total government revenue as a percentage of the nation's economic output is near historical highs, income taxes for most people are low by historical standards. They said that by pushing for a large a tax cut, the administration and Republicans in Congress are in effect trying to starve spending programs far into the future as a means to the ideological end of reducing the size and influence of the federal government.
"There's no sense of the historical consequences," said Thomas S. Kahn, staff director for Democrats on the House Budget Committee. "They're reshaping the agenda for a decade or longer."
Exactly, said conservative Republicans. "If we don't cut taxes," said Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, "they'll spend every doggone dime of it."

In coming weeks, Congress will go to work on dividing up what is left, and may find itself short of what it needs to do everything the two parties have proposed. HEADLINE: Business; 
And Now, a Case for the Forensic Accountant

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
SOMETHING struck Paul Morsen as odd about a trash hauler's request that the Central Contra Costa Sanitary District approve higher rates for customers to keep it out of bankruptcy.
 After all, just weeks earlier, this trash hauler, Orinda-Moraga Disposal Service Inc., said it could lower the cost of collecting garbage for customers. 
 "Both those things can't be true," because no rational company offers to cut prices when it is losing money, said Mr. Morsen, who at the time -- the summer of 1996 -- was deputy general manager of the Sanitary District.
So he called in a forensic accountant, Dan W. Ray. Mr. Ray's profession is a bit of an oxymoron. The very word forensic sounds glamorous and perhaps a little scary -- forensic psychology seems to crop up in conversations about Thomas Harris's fictional cannibalistic shrink, Hannibal Lecter; forensic pathologists helped identify the deceased victims of violence in Argentina and the former Yugoslavia. 
At the same time, accounting is renowned for being, well, a snore. Not this kind. As the economic climate has worsened and investors have started prowling restlessly for evidence of past corporate sins -- overstated costs or revenue, for example, or understated inventory -- forensic accounting is in demand. 
It is difficult to tell how great the demand is, though -- clients of forensic accountants do not usually want to advertise that they lost track of money they now have to find. But, to name just a few recent cases, Xerox is using accountants to investigate its finances and Cendant hired Arthur Andersen to sort out possible accounting irregularities in the wake of fraud accusations that surfaced last year. 
Forensic accounting experts are also hired by defendants in fraud cases. Lawyers for Albert J. Dunlap, the former Sunbeam Corporation chairman and chief executive accused this month by the Securities and Exchange Commission of accounting fraud, hired forensic accounting experts at PricewaterhouseCoopers to examine Sunbeam's books.
"It is a growth industry," said John Warren, associate general counsel of the Association of Certified Fraud Examiners, an organization in Austin, Tex. The group has added nearly 3,300 accountants to its membership rolls in the last 10 years and plans to add an additional 1,500 this year. "It has a lot to do with organizations being more aware of the threat of white-collar crime."
STRICTLY speaking, forensic accounting is audit work performed to help in litigation, but it usually refers to the investigation of an individual's or a corporation's finances to find missing money. The practice is not limited to big accounting firms like PricewaterhouseCoopers and Deloitte & Touche, though they are expanding their business. Many small firms and solo practitioners are out there, too. 
There is no typical case of fraud, but the Contra Costa trash story illustrates how forensic accountants work. The first thing Mr. Ray did was check a database to see whether William D. Lomow, the owner of the trash hauler, owned other California companies that could be involved in any scheme. It turned out that he did.
So early in the investigation, which was allowed by the terms of the contract between the sanitary authority and the trash company, Mr. Ray asked Mr. Lomow whether he owned any other companies.
"He said no, and that was the wrong answer," Mr. Ray recalled. "It told me I was dealing with someone who wasn't truthful. I describe it as my 'litmus test of management integrity.' And he failed."
Alerted that the owner was probably hiding something, the accountants reviewed payments the company made, and found a check payable to a Bay Area company deposited in a bank in Boise, Idaho, where Mr. Lomow had a personal account. 
Mr. Ray checked the name of the owner of the company that made the deposit and found that the same person -- who, it turned out, did not exist -- owned other companies. All were recipients of checks from the trash company, all were founded on the same day, and all had fictitious business addresses, such as a Mailboxes Etc. outlet in Berkeley, Calif., a vacant building, or a Post Office drop box, Mr. Ray said.
It turned out that the other companies, supposedly providing maintenance services for garbage trucks, were dummy corporations established by Mr. Lomow to siphon money from the trash company, Mr. Ray said. Mr. Lomow overstated costs to justify rate increases, and then the payments made by the company went straight into bank accounts under his control, Mr. Ray said.
The Sanitary District took the paper trail that Mr. Ray's team had uncovered and used it in a civil lawsuit against Mr. Lomow and his associate, Robert M. Sliepka. The district obtained a $9 million judgment, and at least part of the money recovered will be repaid to customers. 
Mr. Lomow and Mr. Sliepka were convicted in criminal proceedings. The failure of outside auditors to discover the fraud led to a malpractice lawsuit against the Sanitary District's outside accountants, too, Mr. Ray said. 
"It certainly had a great outcome," said Mr. Ray. He expects to see an increase in dot-com related cases soon, because his firm is near Silicon Valley. 
The trash case is unusual in that most of the details became public. Usually the clients of forensic accountants prefer to keep all information secret, so they do not publicize their vulnerability to fraud. Many of the stories that the accountants tell are therefore vague. For example, Howard M. Fielstein, a partner at Margolin, Winer & Evens in New York, tells of the management of a scrap metal reseller that kept running out of metal to sell, though its inventory records showed that all orders should have been met easily. 
"It turned out that over the weekend, trucks were coming in and just loading it up" to sell elsewhere, Mr. Fielstein said. That case was broken by surveillance of the building where the scrap metal was stored, he added.
Mr. Fielstein's formula for conducting a forensic accounting investigation draws heavily on interviews, first of the potential client. "They should be 100 percent upfront," he said. Otherwise, Mr. Fielstein said, his own reputation could be damaged.
The next step is to review what documentation there is, and then to interview those people who might know what caused a discrepancy in a company's finances. Not just the chief financial officer, either, Mr. Fielstein emphasizes.
"You can learn a lot from not only talking to the upper levels but also to the guy who walks the floor," he said.
Some forensic accountants are actually much closer to private investigators. Kroll, the risk-management company, for example, offers to vet potential employees, advises companies on how to protect secrets and performs miscellaneous other services intended to reduce the risks clients face.
The work can get dangerous, said James R. Murray, senior managing director for Kroll in New York. "We're constantly assessing that," he said. "Most of the time you don't have too many concerns. White-collar criminals are usually not violent."
Forensic accountants often get called in to help with more mundane matters, like divorces. Wealthy spouses often go to extraordinary lengths to hide assets so they are not consumed by alimony payments, and accountants may have to pore over bank and real estate records to find them. 
When a publicly held company is involved, or the case receives significant attention, it is sometimes important to the client to send a message that cooking the books will be punished. In order to do that, the victim of fraud may turn over all the information uncovered by a forensic accountant to prosecutors, who may bring criminal proceedings against the culprit, as in the Contra Costa trash case.
XEROX has said that the lawyers for its audit committee have retained PricewaterhouseCoopers to review their books, for example, in the wake of an S.E.C. investigation of some Xerox accounting practices.
Forensic accounting work is not necessarily more lucrative than more traditional audit work, but its practitioners, all of them certified public accountants, say they much prefer the challenges of their current work to reviewing corporations' books.
"It causes you to use more of your imagination," Mr. Fielstein said, because every scam is unique. "There's always something different out there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dan W. Ray, a forensic accountant in San Francisco, is hired by corporations and government agencies to detect evidence of fraud. (Stephanie Diani for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hindsight and the Eye of the Beholder 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

 BODY:
WHEN pundits or professors talk about political courage, they often mean some politician has taken a chance with the voters for something the commentator believes in. Consider, for example, the praise heaped on Senator James M. Jeffords by writers who endorsed Democrats last fall. In this case, the risk is not severe. Vermonters seem to like his independence.
 When former President Gerald R. Ford was honored with an award on Monday at the John F. Kennedy Library, it fulfilled the tradition Kennedy celebrated in 1956 in his book "Profiles in Courage," of praising a politician who bucked constituents for what he thought was the greater good. 
 But another condition -- that hindsight or history (or in this case, a majority of the awards committee) eventually came to think that the unpopular decision was correct -- also applied. Often, there is no real conversion. When white southerners were hailed for opposing segregation, their historian-champions agreed with them all along, whatever southern white voters thought.
Mr. Ford's case was different on that score. Mr. Ford, in pardoning his predecessor, Richard M. Nixon, did what he thought was good for the nation, knowing the nation would not think so. And most of the people who now praise Mr. Ford's decision were dubious -- or downright hostile -- when he made it. Sixty percent of the public as polled by Harris disapproved. 
Among them were two who joined in the ceremony. Caroline Kennedy, who as a 16-year-old high school senior opposed the pardon, presented the award, lauding Mr. Ford's "controversial decision of conscience." Her uncle Ted, who at the time of the pardon said it had "led many Americans to believe it was the culmination of the Watergate cover-up," said it helped heal the nation.
But the more typical vindication comes -- considering that most historians are liberals -- when a tough decision looked right at the time to the same sort of people now weighing in. When 66 percent of the public in a 1951 Gallup Poll said they thought it was wrong for President Truman to fire General Douglas MacArthur, they did not include Eleanor Roosevelt, Walter Reuther, William O. Douglas, Walter Lippmann or the editorial writers of The New York Times, The Washington Post or The St. Louis Post-Dispatch. And today, even some of the press critics of the time, like Time magazine and The Chicago Tribune, would join most historians in approval.
Politicians revel in saying they are doing the courageous thing. On at least eight occasions, President Nixon announced that he was avoiding the "easy way" in decisions on educational standards, welfare, inflation and, repeatedly, Vietnam. In Vietnam, he said in 1971, the easy way would be "just get out and let the Communists take over." Ultimately, of course, United States troops got out, and the Communists took over. If Mr. Nixon had chosen the easy way, historians might be praising his courage on Vietnam just as they praise him for opening relations with Communist China.
Politicians also worry a lot. Representative John J. Flynt Jr., a crusty Georgia Democrat, told me in the summer of 1974 that if he had to vote for Mr. Nixon's impeachment, it would cost him his seat. But he said that was how he would vote if the Judiciary Committee recommended it. 
Then he proudly pulled out of his pocket an excerpt from Edmund Burke's 1774 address to the Electors of Bristol, in which the Irish statesman proclaimed, "Your representative owes you, not his industry only, but his judgment; and he betrays instead of serving you if he sacrifices it to your opinion." 
As it happened, the House did not vote on impeachment, and Mr. Flynt defeated a young Georgia professor named Newt Gingrich, who campaigned on the environment and got 49 percent of the vote. 
But sometimes a decision made in the face of public opinion stays unpopular. In 1937, Franklin D. Roosevelt proposed adding Supreme Court justices so that he could overcome the majority that was killing his New Deal measures. Aides told him it was wrong and would be unpopular, said Joseph J. Ellis, professor of history at Mount Holyoke College. He described the reaction: "On both sides of the aisle and both sides of the political spectrum, this was regarded as a monarchical act, a blatant repudiation of the separation of powers."
The court-packing scheme was rejected by the Senate and remains unpopular today. It is perhaps the most prominent exception to the aphorism of Professor Joel Silbey, a Cornell historian who has not been won over to support of the Nixon pardon: "Time makes everybody look better -- particularly if you really landed on them at the time."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Musical Chairs; 
Democrats Take Their Turn In the Hot Seat

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHEN the quake set off by Senator James M. Jeffords's departure Thursday from the Republican Party stopped, no one was left standing in the same place or on the same ground.
 In a nation and a Congress split right down the middle politically, the power of just one vote can be extraordinary, and the senator's decision may prove as momentous as the 5-4 United States Supreme Court ruling that gave George W. Bush the presidency last December. 
 As dazed Republicans try to figure out their next move, Senate Democrats, who began the week unable to hold their ranks against a $1.35 trillion tax cut, have been catapulted into majority status, with all the possibilities that offers.
"The question is, can the Democrats seize the moment?" said Bill Curry, a former adviser to President Clinton. Mr. Curry wryly notes that it was a quiet Republican who delivered a stingingly effective critique of Republicans and Mr. Bush, as no longer standing for "moderation, tolerance, fiscal responsibility." 
"Along comes this 67-year-old life-long Republican moderate who made his peace with Reaganism to say -- with much to lose and little to gain -- that he can't live with the extremism of the Bush agenda," said Mr. Curry. "By his action, he has done more than the Democrats have been able to do in four months to focus the American people on the fine points of the Bush agenda."
Democrats, in fact, had been largely on the defensive at the moment Mr. Jeffords made his move. Though they had begun to attack the president effectively on issues like the environment, they had been unable to articulate a forceful, overriding reason to oppose his tax cut, descending instead into a cacophony of different arguments. Nor were they able to stop their conservatives from making swift compromises with Republicans to speed toward Mr. Bush's desk the tax cut that was the centerpiece of his agenda.
But now, Democrats say, they have what they need: control of one of Washington's levers of power. And make no mistake, it does matter that Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota is now not only the Democrats' indisputable leader, but also the Senate's agenda setter and possibly the front runner for the next presidential nomination, to boot.
So intense is the spotlight that comes with this new power and authority that when the relentlessly low-key Mr. Daschle walked down the long staircase of the Capitol's East Front Thursday to herald the new political day, the scene had an electricity reminiscent of Newt Gingrich's first days as speaker of the House. Television cameras rolled, tourists gawked and teenagers even climbed into a tree to get a better look.
MR. DASCHLE, eschewing Newt-onian triumphalism, vowed to "work for principled compromise," but he has his work cut out for him. Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, calls the moment "filled with opportunities and perils" for his party. "There's the chance to promote our agenda, but also to raise expectations too high," he said, "and to attempt to do so much that we cause our own fractures."
The Democratic majority -- like that of the Republicans -- will be a tenuous one. As Mr. Daschle himself reminded reporters, "This is still one of the most closely divided Senates in all of our history."
Moreover, Mr. Daschle presides over a divided caucus that stretches from liberals like Barbara Boxer of California to conservatives like Zel Miller of Georgia, who often votes with the Republicans. And the party's activist base, still furious over Mr. Bush's disputed election, may demand something more militant than the sort of conciliation that led the Democrats, on the eve of taking power, to give up their fight against the appointment of Theodore B. Olson as solicitor general.
The last time the division of power in the Senate was so tight was during the Eisenhower administration. Because of deaths during the 83rd Congress between 1953 and 1955, the Democrats at times had more senators than the Republicans. But they never tried to take control of the chamber, uncertain that there was advantage in such responsibility.
IN 1954, Senator William Knowland of California, the Republican majority leader, mourned on the floor "that I have the responsibility of being majority leader in this body without a majority."
Democratic Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas retorted, "If anyone has more problems than a majority leader with a minority, it is a minority leader with a majority."
Until Mr. Jeffords bolted, Mr. Daschle was a minority leader who was almost at parity. And in the past few months his Democrats had just begun to agree on how to fight the new president. Through a series of failed amendments to the tax bill they set down the arguments they will be able to make, if the economy turns sour, to assert that they had been right. They jumped on Mr. Bush's environmental rollbacks to portray him as threatening the nation's quality of life. And they have used the California energy crisis to accuse him of favoring oil and gas companies over consumers.
These positions are designed to make the Republicans look extreme, a tactic that the Democrats found easier against Mr. Gingrich than against Mr. Bush. 
"You've got to be a tough moderate," said Kevin Phillips, a political analyst, "which means you're always pointing out how the other side goes too far, or is extreme or is working for the oil companies and the fat cats."
With the Senate in hand, the Democrats will now have the opportunity to change the terms of the nation's policy debate by using committee chairmen to hold hearings on Mr. Bush's foreign policy, his energy plan and his approach to Social Security. They are bound to be far more critical of the president than the Republican-led committees ever were.
Mr. Daschle will also be able to place on the Senate floor a competing agenda to Mr. Bush's, with an eye to the 2002 and 2004 elections. He said his first move after the Senate completes the education bill would be to bring to the floor legislation to regulate managed health care. It is a popular issue and the kind that will put pressure on moderate Republicans in the battle for the political center. Indeed, none other than Senator John McCain, the maverick Arizona Republican, is co-sponsoring the managed care bill with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat -- a bill opposed by Mr. Bush and most Republicans.
Some other tried-and-true issues, on which polls show the voters tend to prefer Democratic positions over Republican ones, will follow. Medicare prescription drug benefits and an increase in the minimum wage will be among them. Democrats also want to promote electoral reform and an energy package that relies more on conservation and efficiency than Mr. Bush's.
It takes 60 votes to end a Senate filibuster and the excruciatingly close arithmetic of the Senate has not changed. So the Republicans, if they adamantly oppose Mr. Daschle, could keep him from passing any of these measures. "The numbers will still be very close on a lot of issues that are going to be difficult issues," said Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat.
But in politics one can sometimes win by losing. A major goal of the Democrats is to portray themselves as centrists, closer to the American public than Mr. Bush and the Congressional Republicans, and to maintain and amplify Mr. Jeffords's charge that his longtime party is no longer one of moderation. 
"On most of these issues we're moving into Democratic turf," says Marshall Wittmann, a Congressional analyst with the Hudson Institute. "It will be very difficult for the House to kill these without seeming obstructionist."
The risk for Mr. Daschle is that enough Democrats will desert him on big issues that Republicans will be able to label Mr. Bush the centrist and the Democrats left-leaning radicals.
AND with liberals clamoring for their party to stop Mr. Bush in his tracks -- from his judicial nominations to his plans to drill in the Alaskan wilderness for oil and gas -- Mr. Daschle must also take care that he does not come across as Dr. No, who does nothing but obstruct the president. Republicans are already beginning to make this case.
On Thursday, Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority whip from Texas, said of Mr. Daschle: "Blocking legislation is one thing. Running the Senate efficiently is quite another. We'll see if he can get results, not just throw up roadblocks."
But Mr. Daschle is shrewd and Democrats are trusting him to be adroit about when to compromise and when to confront. "As long as Daschle keeps his eye on occupying the center ground," said Al From, the head of the Democratic Leadership Council, "we'll do fine."'

HEADLINE: Sizing Up a Changed Capital 

 BODY:
At first, the changed world due to arrive in Washington with a Democratic-controlled Senate may not look very different from the old. Senator Tom Daschle, soon to be majority leader, is sensibly cautioning against dramatic changes. Slowly and over time, however, the Senate's altered balance of power could bring significant progress in several areas if Democrats are selective in their fights and President Bush and the Republican Congressional leaders moderate their own positions. They should try for progress on increased school spending, energy, patients' rights and prescription drugs for the elderly, steps that could even lead to new attempts to reform Social Security and Medicare.
 As a result of Senator James Jeffords's defection from the Republican Party, the Senate is now a hodgepodge of potential alliances on various issues. In practical terms, there has always been a centrist core of lawmakers ready to advance certain economic and social causes, but in recent years that majority vote was thwarted by Senator Trent Lott, who ran the Senate with deference to conservatives. The party's hard right wields similar power in the House, though a moderate bipartisan majority has broken the leadership's hammerlock on issues like campaign finance reform. 
 Hanging over the new landscape, unfortunately, is a $1.35 trillion tax cut (which is actually more than $1.5 trillion if it is calculated without the budgetary sleight of hand approved this weekend) emerging like some kind of monster out of tough negotiations behind the scenes. But with the Senate in Democratic hands, one of the primary defects of the tax cut could turn out to be a virtue. Its most regressive features -- the lowering of taxes on the super-rich and the elimination of the estate tax -- will not be phased in until several years down the road, skewing the cost in future years. Irresponsible as that is, it also means that these parts of the tax cut can and ought to be abrogated if the surpluses on which they are based fail to materialize or are used up by spending for which there is bipartisan support.
President Bush, for example, has signaled that he will soon propose a major military buildup, including financing for a national missile defense. He also wants to privatize part of Social Security and introduce more free-market competition into Medicare, steps that are likely to cost large amounts of money. The Democrats and many moderate Republicans, on the other hand, cannot and should not live with the budget cuts embodied in the nonbinding budget resolution rammed through Congress earlier this month. Lawmakers are certain to adopt more spending than is allowed in the resolution for schools, the environment, law enforcement and other areas. The parts of the tax cut that do not take effect for many years should be considered part of any negotiation on increased spending. No additional tax cuts should even be considered without an agreement to rescind some of the earlier cuts.
The Democratic-controlled Senate can wield influence in other areas. If the House passes a campaign finance bill acceptable to the Senate, Mr. Daschle can swiftly schedule a vote on that bill and send it to President Bush. Mr. Lott would never have done that. As for judgeships, the Judiciary Committee, using information from the American Bar Association, can now ensure that proper consideration is given to Mr. Bush's choices. The days of forcing the Senate to vote prematurely on an appointment, as Mr. Lott did last week for Solicitor General Theodore Olson, must not be repeated. Democrats should use their new power to block ideologically skewed appointments, but they should rely, whenever possible, on building coalitions rather than the bellicose partisanship advocated by James Carville and Paul Begala on today's Op-Ed page.
The Senate's enormous power to set the agenda and hold hearings can change the climate in Washington if it is used judiciously. Under the Republicans, Senate committees properly investigated the influence of campaign contributions on various Clinton administration policies. The lobbying on Bush administration energy and environment policy might be one field for a bipartisan inquiry to examine. But the Republicans showed that overweening zeal in investigating a president can backfire. In this area and in others, the Democrats must avoid payback politics once they control the Senate for the first time since 1994. It will not be easy to reinstill an atmosphere of cooperation in Washington, but it is what the public wants and what Mr. Jeffords has now made a little more possible.

HEADLINE: Bush's Tax Cut Triumph Is a Political Bouquet, Complete With Thorns 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26 

 BODY:
Taken on its own, the passage today of a sweeping tax cut close in size and similar in spirit to the one President Bush proposed was a resounding victory for him and his new administration.
 It affirmed his powers of persuasion. It validated his ability to govern with an ambiguous mandate. It fixed him, at least for now, as a man of his word, a leader wedded to principles he had long espoused and was committed to pursuing even in the face of evidence that they were not overwhelmingly popular. 
 But that was not the whole story, nor was it the final chapter. The president's success -- and even Democrats were compelled to label it as such -- came with costs already incurred and dangers yet to be confronted. It was qualified by the president's evolving image, fed by his unwavering crusade for the first big tax cut in two decades, as a conservative more concerned about his fans on the political right than the skeptics in the political center.
"This is a short-term victory that carries with it a steep long-term price," said Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster. "He at least has gotten one big thing done; that's more than is true of some presidents."
But, Mr. Garin said: "The tax bill more than anything else was the cause of strong feelings of partisanship to reemerge almost from the beginning of the administration. The way that he did this will make it much harder for him to get the next victories."
Unmentioned but unmistakably present in Mr. Garin's assessment was the other big political news of the week: the defection of Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont from the Republican Party, which put the Senate under Democratic control. With Democrats in charge of the traffic of legislation in the Senate, Mr. Bush may find the political going much rougher than he did in the first four months of his administration.
Mr. Jeffords voted for the tax legislation, tweaked and tailored in ways that accommodated concerns that he, other Northeastern Republicans and moderate Democrats shared. In the end, all but 2 of the Senate Republicans who voted today -- Senators John McCain of Arizona and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island -- supported the bill, as did 12 Democrats, giving Mr. Bush at least the patina of a bipartisan consensus.
But some Republican strategists said the administration's wrangling with Mr. Jeffords over the tax bill, coupled with the attention the bill drew to the more conservative elements of Mr. Bush's agenda, was among the triggers for Mr. Jeffords's departure.
That move leaves the White House with a legislative arithmetic and a climate on Capitol Hill potentially less favorable to the achievement of its goals. It gives more power to any Republican who might decide to be a spoiler -- to mavericks like Mr. McCain and Mr. Chafee, both of whom flexed their independence with their votes today.
The passage of the tax bill also leaves the White House with another, perhaps equally significant problem. Because Mr. Bush framed tax reductions as a panacea for everything from economic to energy woes, the enactment of tax cuts sets Mr. Bush up to take responsibility -- blame as well as credit -- for the extent to which the situation on any of these fronts does or does not improve.
"It does put all of these issues now clearly on the back of the president," said John Weaver, a Republican strategist who worked for Mr. McCain's presidential campaign. That was especially true, Mr. Weaver said, in terms of the economy.
"It becomes his," Mr. Weaver said. "It was bound to happen sooner or later. At least it comes with a victory." He said that it was, indeed, "a big victory."
The significance of that accomplishment is unequivocal. When Mr. Bush began pushing his tax cut on the campaign trail a year and a half ago, most Democrats argued that it was about a trillion dollars too generous. Public opinion polls suggested extremely soft support for the measure. The election returns, in which Mr. Bush lost the popular vote, suggested a profound ambivalence about the wisdom of his ways.
"I just remember so clearly, right after the election, people said: 'Doesn't the president have to change his agenda? Shouldn't he give up on the ideas he planned?' " said Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary. 
The president did not and, in the end, he had to shave only a few hundred billion dollars from his dream and managed to convert many Democrats to his cause. Even more remarkably, he reached his destination with considerable speed. It took President Ronald Reagan more than two months longer to win passage of a tax cut in his first year in office.
Mr. Bush was helped mightily by forecasts of increasingly robust surpluses that made his plan seem more affordable. But administration officials, their supporters and several Republican strategists said Mr. Bush also proved his tenacity as a salesman, a quality they said bodes well for his ability to exert his will on issues like education reform, a patients' bill of rights and the modernization of the military.
"I'm fairly impressed," said Greg Mueller, a Republican strategist. "The president and the administration didn't back off. They were very, very focused. They just never let up on the Hill and never let up publicly. I think, in many ways, they've set the table for some good legislation and some good governance down the pike here."
But the pike looks indisputably different than it once did: bumpier, possibly slower, best navigated with a delicacy that the Bush administration sometimes lacked. Mr. Bush may have passed one milestone only to encounter more formidable obstacles down the road.

HEADLINE: The Fresh Air Fund; 
Teenagers Ponder Futures on a Weekend Away

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN CARROLL 

DATELINE: FISHKILL, N.Y. 

 BODY:
Geese and deer seemed unconcerned by the recent migration to Beaver Lake of a rare species -- the adolescent city slickers of the PreOccupations Club.
 Cabins around the lake hummed with activity. One cabin, nestled among fragrant honeysuckle bushes, housed a group of teenagers discussing grown-up decisions and consequences. 
 "In my life, 'can't' isn't part of my vocabulary," declared Jared Hunte, 17, of Harlem. 
"But there may be some things you can't do when you're young; you need to plan ahead and choose your experiences in order to handle life pressures," said Jaqueline White, a counselor.
The group mulled this over and discussed different possibilities for careers and families. But Jared maintained that sometimes the call of adventure can bedevil the most solid, sensible plans. 
"Hey -- curiosity killed the cat!" he said.
Smiling, Mrs. White shot back, "O.K., so what do you plan on doing, if you're a cat?"
Teenagers and counselors broke out in laughter before returning to the topic at hand.
In another cabin, teenagers played a board game called Success. The object was to attain job stability and economic satisfaction, while dodging penalty cards with messages such as: "You ran out of money and must quit a special two-year training program to go to work." 
Jermaine Toney, 16, of the Bronx, said the game "helps with decisions about life."
Meanwhile, in a third cabin, teams of nacho makers were having a cook-off. They crowded around an oven, loudly boasting about their meat-to-cheese ratios and bemoaning the complexity of properly flavoring guacamole on a budget.
Planning ahead, thinking critically, working in teams and choosing your battles: these are some of the life lessons encouraged by the PreOccupations Club. At a recent weekend retreat, 41 teenagers in the club visited Camp Mariah in Fishkill. The camp is one of five run by the Fresh Air Fund, a nonprofit agency that has provided free vacations in the country for 1.7 million disadvantaged children from New York City since 1877. Camp Mariah, opened in 1994, is named for the pop singer Mariah Carey, who has supported the camp financially. 
Teenagers join the PreOccupations Club after completing the Fresh Air Fund's three-year Career Awareness Program for middle-school students. The program brings youths aged 12 to 14 to Camp Mariah for three-week summer vacations, during which they publish newspapers, put on plays, design clothing and take classes in music and science, said Miriam Seidenfeld, the program's director.
"We teach them to dream about the future," she said.
During high school, the PreOccupations Club helps build reality into those dreams. Once each month, members meet to discuss resume writing; go on field trips to businesses like Clinique Laboratories and NBC; and attend tutoring sessions for standardized tests. Twice a year, the group meets at Camp Mariah for weekends filled with camaraderie and lessons in what the club calls "life skills."
The club was created to encourage teenagers to take control of their futures, Ms. Seidenfeld said. "The point is that things don't happen to them; they make things happen."
The fertile, placid environment -- Camp Mariah is at the end of a winding, leafy road far from the sounds of the city -- encourages reflection and self-reliance. "I always work on the things in myself I'm lacking here," said Natkhia Varner, 15, of Harlem. "It's all about learning to be independent."
For Merlinda David, 17, of the Bronx, summers at Camp Mariah have offered a break from the pressures of city living. "Where I live, it's not that bad, but it's all about what's in and what's out. Here, you have to deal more with other people. You're away from other influences."
She continued, "Being here, out in the middle of nowhere, you have to get out of the way of thinking: I'm in the city, I can't do anything else but what I see around me. You have to get out of that mind-set to get into yourself, to find out what you want to do with your life."
Last year, about 10,000 children aged 6 to 18 took part in Fresh Air programs. About 3,000 attended camps in Fishkill, and about 6,000 vacationed with host families in rural and suburban communities, known as Friendly Towns, in 13 states and Canada. Another 1,000 participated in year-round camping activities.
Families that would like to become hosts or those who would like to register their children for a Fresh Air summer vacation can call (800) 367-0003. Those wishing to make a tax-deductible contribution can send a check to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y., 10017, or visit the agency's Web site at www.freshair.org.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Camp Mariah, from left, Jared Hunte, Ismael Mercado, Aaron Williams, Jermell White and Ileana Ruperti. (Susan Markisz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Congress Passes Tax Cut, With Rebates This Summer 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26 

 BODY:
Congress gave final approval today to the biggest tax cut in a generation, voting to reduce all income tax rates over the next five years and to give the weakened economy a quick jolt by sending rebates to taxpayers this summer.
 After days of intense negotiations over how to apportion the tax cut of $1.35 trillion in the next decade -- and a final round of brief but bitter partisan debate during an unusual Saturday morning session -- Republican leaders moved the bill quickly through both House and Senate. 
 The bill passed the House by a vote of 240 to 154, with 28 Democrats and an independent joining all Republicans in voting yes. The Senate then passed it by a vote of 58 to 33. 
Twelve Democrats joined 46 Republicans in support of the bill in the Senate. Two Republicans -- John McCain of Arizona and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island -- voted against it on a day when some members of Congress had already left town for the holiday weekend. 
Among those voting in favor of the bill was Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont. Mr. Jeffords's decision this week to leave the Republican Party following completion of the tax bill gives Democrats control of the Senate starting next month, when Congress returns from its Memorial Day recess. 
The bill now goes to President Bush, who made a big tax cut the centerpiece of his economic agenda and his first legislative priority. The plan approved today by Congress was slightly smaller than the $1.6 trillion plan proposed by Mr. Bush, but the president made clear that he would sign it with enthusiasm.
"Tax relief was the right thing to do, and it is the responsible thing to do, for the American people and for our economy," Mr. Bush said at the White House after the vote. "This is significant -- and this is only the beginning."
Republicans said cutting taxes when the government was running a substantial surplus was nothing more than returning an overcharge to the people who earned it and was the best way of checking a relentless rise in government spending.
"The addicts are going to have to take the cure," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. "We're no longer going to get stoned on other people's money." 
But even as final passage neared, Democrats said the bill was unfairly tilted to the wealthy, left too little money for other purposes and risked putting the nation back in a fiscal hole just as it confronted the costs of paying retirement and health benefits to an aging population.
"We think this is good short-term politics," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who will become majority leader when the Democrats formally take control of the Senate. "It is disastrous long-term policy."
Congress, Mr. Daschle predicted, would ultimately have to come back to "make corrections" in tax policy.
The benefits of the bill will begin flowing this summer in the form of rebate checks -- $300 for single people and $600 for couples who file joint returns. (Those who earn less than $6,000 in taxable income, $12,000 for couples, would not get the full rebate.) 
But nearly all of the bill's provisions are phased in gradually, and some of them do not take effect at all until the middle or end of the decade.
The bulk of the tax cuts come in the form of reductions in personal income tax rates. In addition to reducing income tax rates, the bill gradually doubles the child credit and applies it to many low-income families who cannot currently claim the credit. 
The legislation gradually reduces the federal estate tax, and then repeals it in 2010. Married couples get a tax break. Contribution limits to 401(k) and individual retirement account programs are increased. The bill creates a deduction for college tuition expenses.
The bill includes nearly all the elements sought by Mr. Bush and Republican leaders. But to fit them within the amount of money available, Congress had to resort to a financial and political gimmick: it provided that all the tax cuts would be rescinded by 2011, the last year in the planning horizon used to calculate the legislation's cost.
Republicans said they assumed future Congresses would vote to extend the tax cuts. Democrats said the maneuver was a ploy to hide the fact that the real cost of the bill was at least $1.6 trillion -- the level Mr. Bush had sought -- if all the provisions were left in place in 2011. 
The bill would provide a married couple with two children and income of $100,000 with a tax cut of $911 this year and $2,790 a year once fully phased in, according to calculations by Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm. A single person with no children who earns $60,000 a year would get a tax cut this year of $375, and $802 once the bill is fully phased in.
In general, the provisions benefiting low-income people take effect faster than those that benefit only wealthier people. Moreover, the bill did little to deal with the alternative minimum tax, which by later in the decade will force many middle- and upper-income Americans to pay higher tax bills than the legislation promises. 
Republicans said they would have to pass another bill at some point to reduce the alternative minimum tax, which was originally passed to ensure that wealthy taxpayers did not escape taxation through clever use of deductions and credits.
Today's action was the culmination of years of debate over whether the nation could afford a substantial tax cut at a time of large and growing federal budget surpluses. It was a clear victory for Mr. Bush, who campaigned on the issue, and for Republicans in Congress, who had been thwarted in their tax-cutting efforts while Bill Clinton was in the White House.
It also continued an even longer debate over fairness -- whether cuts should go primarily to the people who pay the most taxes, the wealthy, or to those who most need the help, those in the lower and middle ranges of the income spectrum.
While the final bill largely hewed to the Republican philosophy of "tax cuts for taxpayers," it also acknowledged the liberal demand that lower-income people benefit in a tangible way. The main mechanism for doing so was to allow low-income working families who do not have a federal income tax liability to claim a portion of the child credit, in effect giving them a cash payment each year.
"The people who pay the most taxes in the country get relief," said Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, one of the Democrats who voted for the bill. "That's important. But people who need the most help in this country also get help."
Up to the end, the debate also centered on whether it was fiscally responsible to be allocating a big part of the projected surplus before it materialized.
Republicans said that if the money was not returned to taxpayers, it would be spent on ever-larger and wasteful government programs.
"America, this is your money, and you know how to spend it best," said Representative Thomas M. Reynolds, Republican of New York.
Democrats said the United States would come to rue the day the legislation was enacted because it risked a return to the kinds of budget deficits that built up after the last big tax cut, in 1981.
"This is a sad day, as was 1981," said Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland. "It will result in profound dislocation in days ahead."
The votes came against the backdrop of the impending change in control of the Senate. Given the opposition of Mr. Daschle and other Democratic leaders in the Senate to the bill, the change is sure to make it more difficult for Republicans to follow through on their plan to enact further tax cuts this year.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, threw his considerable influence behind a tax cut, though his caution that the cuts should be tied to the surplus actually materializing was ignored.
Most of all, Mr. Bush was able to sell the tax cut as a way to shore up the economy, which slowed abruptly toward the end of last year. Indeed, Mr. Bush pivoted from casting the tax cut as a matter of returning to people their own money to marketing it as antirecession insurance. 
Putting money into people's pockets, he said, will stimulate spending, help people pay credit card bills and offset rising gasoline prices.
The bill immediately creates a new bottom tax rate of 10 percent that applies to the first $6,000 of taxable income for single people and $12,000 for married couples filing jointly. The change is retroactive to the first of the year, and it is this part of the tax cut that will lead to the mailing of rebate checks in the coming months. The current 15 percent rate would remain in place for income levels above those covered by the new 10 percent rate.
The legislation then reduces all income tax rates above the current 15 percent rate by one percentage point as of July 1. The other rates are currently 28 percent, 31 percent, 36 percent and 39.6 percent.
Over the next five years, those rates will fall further. The current 28 percent rate will eventually reach 25 percent, the 31 percent rate will reach 28 percent, the 36 percent rate will reach 33 percent, and the 39.6 percent rate will reach 35 percent.
The child credit will increase to $1,000 from $500 in a series of steps over nine years, starting with an increase to $600 this year. Families whose incomes are above $10,000 but not enough to pay federal income taxes could claim a cash credit of 10 percent of their earnings, rising eventually to 15 percent. 
Making the child credit available to low-income families was a provision that moderates in both parties fought hard to include in the bill. Conservatives were equally intent on repealing the estate tax.
The bill provides for estate tax rates to be reduced and for the amount of an estate exempt from taxation to be increased, from $675,000 currently to $1 million next year and eventually to $3.5 million in 2009. In 2010, the tax will be repealed entirely.
The bill addresses the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that leads many two-income couples to pay higher tax bills than they would if they remained single. 
But the main marriage penalty provisions would not begin kicking in until 2005. Starting then, the bill would gradually increase the standard deduction for couples so that it becomes twice the level for single people. And it would expand the 15 percent tax bracket for couples so that it covers twice the income level that the bracket covers for single filers.
Contribution limits for 401(k)-type plans gradually rise to $15,000 from $10,500 under current law. Limits for contributions to individual retirement accounts rise to $5,000 from $2,000.
The bill allows up to $4,000 in college expenses to be deducted, subject to income limits. That deduction, however, would disappear after 2006 if a future Congress did not extend it.
The bill also removes limits on the deductibility of student loan interest, and increases the contribution limit for tax-advantaged education savings accounts to $2,000 a year from $500.
The legislators who wrote the bill phased in some provisions and made others expire early so that the bill's cost would not outrun the projected surpluses in any of the next 10 years. 
The bill's annual costs do not exceed $100 billion a year until 2004, the end of Mr. Bush's term. The cost in 2007 reaches $150 billion, and it peaks in 2010 at $187 billion.

HEADLINE: Political Briefing; 
G.O.P. Makes Gains In Democratic Hawaii

BYLINE:  By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Democrats have had a vise lock on Hawaii's politics for 40 years. Hardly any state is more Democratic.
 But in 1998, when Hawaii was one of the few states not enjoying the nation's economic boom, a Republican, Linda Lingle, mayor of Maui, came within 5,000 votes of denying Gov. 
Benjamin J. Cayetano a second term. She contended that he had failed to shore up the Hawaiian economy after its traditional underpinnings -- tourism, agriculture and military spending -- began to crumble because of changing buying habits and national priorities. 
 Hawaii is still not entirely back economically, and in last fall's elections Republicans picked up seven seats in the State House (there are now 32 Democrats and 19 Republicans) and one seat in the State Senate (now 22 Democrats and 3 Republicans). What is more, come next year, Ms. Lingle, now chairwoman of the Hawaii Republican Party, plans to run for governor. (Mr. Cayetano may not run because of term limits.)
And she is pumped.
"We're on the verge of making history," Ms. Lingle told cheering delegates last weekend at a state party convention. "We want the governorship, and we want a majority in the State House. It's realistic. Doable. But very, very difficult."
Democrats have not yet picked a candidate. But not to worry, Mr. Cayetano said last week.
"In the end," he predicted, "Democrats will hold the governorship."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Taxes: Can't Live With 'Em, Can't Live Without 'Em

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
CONGRESS agreed last week to cut taxes by $1.35 trillion over the next 11 years, and President Bush could hardly wait to put his signature on the legislation.
 But don't go out and spend the money quite yet. 
 Although most taxpayers can count on reducing their tax bills by hundreds of dollars this year and next, much of the tax cut will not take effect until the middle of the decade, when the projected budget surplus grows big enough to cover it. 
One big provision -- the repeal of the federal tax on large inheritances -- is put off until 2010. 
The issue is not just patience. Politics, the economy and the government's fiscal outlook could change substantially over the coming 5 or 10 years, raising the possibility that the tax cut could be put on hold before it is fully phased in. 
Of course, voting to raise taxes carries enough electoral peril that both parties strive to avoid doing it. History nonetheless suggests that big tax cuts are often followed by periods in which taxes are increased.
"The historical precedent is to shave back some of the tax cuts in future years," said Stephen Moore, president of the Club for Growth, a political action committee that supports tax cuts. "This has been one of our worries all along."
Take the tax cut of 1981, which Republicans to this day credit with renewing the nation's economic strength. As it became clear that the tax cut was making the federal budget deficit worse, Congress quickly reversed course, even though both parties were under intense pressure at the time from anti-tax forces.
Although it initially left in place the personal income tax rate reductions at the heart of the 1981 plan, Congress raised other taxes in each of the subsequent four years of Ronald Reagan's presidency. It then raised income taxes in 1990, with George Bush in the White House, and raised them yet again on upper-income people in 1993, this time at the behest of President Bill Clinton. 
Analogies between the current situation and the 1980's are imperfect, of course. The budget deficits of 20 years ago have given way to large and growing surpluses, providing a lot more room for error should the economy continue to deteriorate and the fiscal outlook darken. 
But the tax cut of 2001 could still prove vulnerable, if only because it takes more than a decade to become fully effective. 
"I can't think of any time in the nation's history where we delayed permanent changes in the tax code for that long," said C. Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute who was a Treasury Department official during the Reagan administration. 
Mr. Steuerle said the size of the projected surplus makes it likely that the main provisions in the current legislation will be enacted. But he said the certainty of political shifts -- a subject much on the minds of Washington's political class during a week in which the defection of a single senator to the Democratic party cost Republicans control of the Senate -- will create regular opportunities over the next decade to reopen the debate about taxes.
"To think that the politics are going to remain the same is silly," Mr. Steuerle said. "A totally different set of actors will be trying to decide what to do."
There is little doubt that many Democrats will continue to look for ways to limit the tax reduction for upper income people included in the legislation. And if they have the chance, they would no doubt like to pare back the overall size of the package to make room for what they say is vital spending on education, health care, the military and the environment.
ANOTHER issue that could ultimately force a rethinking of long-term tax policy is the strain on the government's finances likely to be caused by the aging of the population over the next few decades. 
As the baby-boom generation retires, the tab for Social Security and Medicare benefits will shoot up, even as relatively fewer people of working age will be paying the taxes that support those programs.
While the tax cut just passed by Congress is valued at $1.35 trillion from now through 2011, it would lead to a revenue loss to the government in the subsequent decade, after it has been fully phased in, of something approaching $4 trillion.
"We do not believe it was fiscally responsible," said Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota. "It explodes in the out-years in cost, at the very time the baby-boomers start to retire."
More immediately, should the current economic sluggishness worsen and lead to a shortfall in the projected surplus, all bets on tax cuts could quickly be called off. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is among those calling for a trigger that would suspend further tax cuts if the surplus does not materialize on time.
Advocates of tax cuts are well aware of the forces that could lead to a reversal in policy, and their strategy has been to promote support for further tax cuts, as quickly as possible. 
Republicans in Congress and groups supporting them are already making plans to push this year for a reduction in the capital gains tax and other tax cuts. Their rationale is that the weakened economy needs more stimulus than provided for in the bill just passed.
The Bush administration, too, is laying the groundwork for more tax cuts.
"This is the first tax bill and not the last tax bill," said Paul H. O'Neill, the treasury secretary.
But with Democrats now in control of the Senate the odds of that prophecy bearing fruit have dimmed.
