HEADLINE: A Battle Plan for the Democrats 

BYLINE:  By James Carville and Paul Begala; James Carville and Paul Begala were political advisers to President Clinton. They are currently writing a book on political strategy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
It's striking and for us Democrats, embarrassing -- that it took a Republican to unmask the Bush agenda. When Jim Jeffords quit the G.O.P., he spoke powerful truths about the truly radical nature of what President Bush is trying to achieve. Too many in our party have been sleepwalking as George W. Bush has audaciously sought to deny the federal government the money and the power to have a positive effect on people's lives.
 Senator Jeffords, a lifelong Republican who had stuck it out through the Reagan and Gingrich revolutions, said he quit the G.O.P. because he disagrees with the president "on very fundamental issues -- the issues of choice, the direction of the judiciary, tax and spending decisions, missile defense, energy and the environment, and a host of other issues, large and small." Democrats should use their new majority status to speak -- and act -- against the right-wing agenda Mr. Jeffords was protesting. 
 Without the moral authority of a clear electoral mandate, Mr. Bush is hardly in a position to dictate the sort of sweeping program he has been pushing. Here's a battle plan for stopping him, emphasizing three tactics. 
First, call a radical a radical. Mr. Bush's agenda is neither compassionate nor conservative; it's radical and it's dangerous, and Democrats should say so. Mr. Bush is proposing a diminution of the government's ability to protect its citizens that is breathtaking in its scope.
His environmental agenda would put more arsenic in the water and more pollutants in the air. His Social Security plan will cost $1 trillion to implement and will hand over Americans' retirement benefits to the vagaries of the stock market. And his missile defense system will cost untold billions, alienate our allies and, even according to its proponents, may not work.
With the complicity of a dozen Democratic senators, Mr. Bush has already pushed through a tax cut that will cost the federal treasury at least $4 trillion over the next two decades (despite being advertised at only $1.35 trillion) and will put the United States in a fiscal straitjacket for a generation or more. And that's just for starters. In an interview in The Financial Times last week, Mr. Bush's Treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, called for the total elimination of all taxes on all corporations, to be replaced by higher taxes on individuals. Mr. O'Neill said he favors an end to the federal commitment to Social Security and Medicare. The Financial Times -- hardly a left-wing bastion -- called his ideas "radical."
But where were the Democrats? If a Democratic Treasury secretary had called for a comparably radical left-wing agenda -- say, nationalizing the oil companies -- the Republicans would have called for his resignation.
Democrats must speak out. Every element of the Bush agenda, from the tax cuts to the judicial appointments to the regulatory retreat, would minimize the federal government's help for people while maximizing corporate influence. Everything the federal government does that helps people, from helping to put police officers on the street to financing Medicare, is at risk in this revolution.
Second, the Democrats must work to spend and shrink: spend the money and shrink the tax cut. Since most of the Bush tax cut's more onerous provisions don't take effect for years, there is plenty of time to fix things. If Republicans can propose repealing years of health and environmental laws, Democrats can propose repealing the most damaging aspects of the Bush tax cut.
Fully fund a prescription drug benefit for the elderly. Commit the country to reducing school class sizes by hiring 100,000 new teachers. Finance school construction and renovation. Increase military pay and benefits. Extend health care coverage to millions of Americans. Fund the priorities Democrats would have funded if there were no tax cut, and pay for it by trimming the more outrageous giveaways in the Bush tax cut. Force Congress and the country to come to grips with the real-world trade-offs that were ignored or glossed over in the rush to cut taxes.
Democrats ought to continue to raise alternative tax cuts: refundable credits for the working poor, reductions in the Social Security payroll tax, a repeal of the "pre-death tax" that requires middle-class elderly people to impoverish themselves in order to qualify for long-term care -- these tax cuts for the poor and middle class should be offered as replacements for the Bush tax cuts for the rich. Even if they don't pass, proposing them and fighting for them will offer the public a stark choice -- the kind of distinctions on which elections are won. If Republicans want to run for re-election as the party that killed middle-class benefits in order to preserve tax breaks for the wealthy, Democrats can emerge with a healthy majority, and then we can defuse the time bomb of the Bush tax cut. But we have to wage the battle in order to win it.
The Democrats should realize that their political future and the national interest in expanding education, health care and retirement security are one and the same. Speaking about the surplus, Senator Phil Gramm, a Republican, was candid enough to admit, "If the Democrats could spend it all, they could be the majority party for another 50 years." 
There is enormous risk in this strategy: if Republicans pass the spending programs but defeat attempts to reduce the tax cut, we will be plunged back into deficits. But better the risk of deficits than the reality of an emaciated and emasculated national government for decades. When forced to choose, the American people will demand that the savage inequalities of the Bush tax cut for the rich be tamed in order to fund important priorities for the middle class.
Third, when push comes to shove, the Democrats should obstruct. They should push a positive agenda, passing a patients' bill of rights, an increase in the minimum wage and campaign finance reform -- filling Mr. Bush's desk with progressive legislation and defying him to veto it. But if Mr. Bush continues to push his radical agenda, offering right-wing judicial nominees and environmental policies that threaten our air and water, Senate Democrats may have no option other than to obstruct. They should not shrink from that duty. Stop signs save lives.
We don't believe the spin that stopping Mr. Bush's assault on middle-class programs will hurt Democrats with voters. Bob Dole helped lead his party to victory in 1994 by stopping everything he could -- from Bill Clinton's economic stimulus package to his health care plan -- and Mr. Clinton's proposals were far more popular than Mr. Bush's are. If Democrats are seen as the people who save America from Mr. Bush's right-wing agenda, they will be regarded as principled, courageous and effective.
Accommodation with the radical Bush agenda -- offering a kinder, gentler Mr. Bush, as it were -- is a prescription for policy failure and political defeat. But if Democrats follow Jim Jeffords's lead and speak with candor and conviction about George W. Bush's misdirected plans, if they stiffen their spines and use their power to stand up for the majority of Americans, who rejected the Bush agenda in the November election, they will be worthy of the majority status Jim Jeffords has given them.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
In Brazil, Phone Service for All?

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 27 

 BODY:
It seemed like the perfect marriage of a new technology and an underserved market. Last year, a company called Vesper started advertising a type of wireless residential telephone service that could be installed much faster than could traditional phone lines and would be cheaper to use than mobile cellular phones would be. People like Rosa Marta, a 31-year-old housekeeper, jumped at the chance.
 "I had a phone in my house in three days," said Ms. Marta, recalling the installation, which was made last September. She had been waiting years for a conventional phone from the local telephone company. "I sold my cellular phone, and now I spend only about 70 reais about $30 on my phone bill," she said, noting that her cell phone bill had been about 200 reais, or $85, a month. "I think it's wonderful." 
 Vesper's rollout is the world's biggest yet for a technology called wireless local loop -- also known as fixed wireless because the phones are not mobile, as cell phones are. Each household has a wireless transmitter-receiver, small enough to sit on a desktop, that communicates with a wireless network antenna. 
Such systems have been held out as a way for countries with nonexistent or inadequate networks to provide universal phone service in places where copper wire does not or may never reach. 
Certainly, for Ms. Marta, who lives with her three children in the low-income neighborhood of Itapecerica da Serra, about 20 miles southwest of the center of Sao Paulo, Vesper's system seemed to provide a relatively affordable type of phone service.
But fixed wireless is not proving to be the answer to universal telephone service in Brazil, where there are only about 23 working telephones for every 100 people -- compared with 65 per 100 in the United States. Revenue from the service tends to be low, because low-income customers do not typically run up large phone bills.
And with the current investment climate so menacing, Vesper, which is closely held, is loath to continue expanding in poor areas. So it has announced that it will put less emphasis on low-income consumers -- which now make up about 75 percent of its clients -- and focus on wealthier households and businesses.
The new strategy may help push Vesper to profitability by the end of the year, but as the company has forecast, the retrenchment raises doubts about technology's ability, alone, to create universal phone service in countries with large low-income populations. 
"In the 90's, this idea of creating a national wireless network as a way of leap-frogging previous levels of commitment and woefully underdeveloped infrastructure was widely, widely embraced," said Dan Schiller, a professor of communication at the University of California at San Diego and an expert on international telecommunications. But the Vesper example demonstrates the limits to that ideal when "the whole process is one of market-based development, rather than social responsibility."
The Brazilian government, in fact, had hoped that a market-based approach would solve the chronic telephone shortage in this nation, where people often spend years on an official waiting list for service.
In 1998, to privatize the state-owned telephone holding company, Telebras, the government divided the country into three regions and promised to license quickly a second service provider in each region to spur competition and to help meet the pent-up demand.
By the time the Brazilian government auctioned the licenses the following January, though, the Russian debt default had scared investors away from the emerging-economy markets like Brazil. Only one of the three licenses was sold, for the Rio de Janeiro region, for the minimum price of about $45 million. The winner, which later called itself Vesper, was a consortium made up of Velocom, a telecommunications start-up company based in Denver, with 49.4 percent; Bell Canada International, with 34.4 percent; and Qualcomm, the American wireless-technology company, with 16.2 percent.
After a series of postponements, the Brazilian government reauctioned the remaining licenses in April 1999, and the Velocom group also won the bid for the Sao Paulo region for the minimum price of about $41 million. The group quickly put together financing, raising $255 million in private equity. According to its agreement with the Brazilian government, the company then had about six months to install service in 42 cities in 17 states.
But while Vesper was rushing to meet that requirement by January of last year, the landscape started to change. The incumbent telephone companies had already been investing heavily for 18 months to increase the number of lines in wealthier urban centers like Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro.
"By the time Vesper was able to get to market, significant chunks of pent-up demand had already been taken care of," said Andy Castonguay, a consultant in Rio de Janeiro. "And since they committed themselves to a very aggressive strategy of meeting coverage needs, they were less focused on the business community, which, in hindsight, was probably shortsighted." 
To make matters worse, the technology itself was limiting. Additional services that have recently become available on cell phones, like Internet access, were not immediately available at competitive data speeds on Vesper's fixed-wireless phones. Such limitations made the phones less attractive for Brazil's middle- and upper-income consumers, as well as business clients, whose larger phone bills could have propped up Vesper's revenues from the start.
Analysts say that weak initial marketing, as well as pricing plans that many low-income customers consider too expensive, also limited Vesper's reach. By the end of 2000, the company had signed up only about 250,000 customers in the state of Sao Paulo, and an additional 250,000 in the area that included Rio de Janeiro. By contrast, Vesper's telephone company competitors in those regions each had some 12 million subscriber lines. 
Vesper argues that its client base has grown the fastest among companies of its kind -- including the American company XO Communications, formerly Nextlink, which has taken some three years to install 130,000 lines in the United States. But Brazilian consumers and the news media, which had been led to believe during the privatization process that Vesper would provide a virtually instant alternative to the traditional telephone companies, have been critical of the company. 
"People seem to have forgotten that the Telebras system took 22 years to install 11 million lines," said Renato Navarro Guerreiro, the president of Brazil's telecommunications regulator, Anatel. "How could you create a mirror that could, on the next day, have a quantity of lines that is sufficient to compare with a competitor that has had a base installed for almost 30 years?"
Velocom acknowledges, though, that the investment and construction pace slowed after Bell Canada International decided that it wanted out of Vesper to focus on Americas Telecom, a Latin American venture with Telefonos de Mexico and the American company SBC Communications. Last September, Velocom agreed to buy Bell Canada's 34.4 percent stake in Vesper for $875 million, but by then the market was starting to turn against telecommunications companies of all stripes. Velocom, after shelving plans for a private stock offering, found that it could not raise the money to buy out Bell Canada. 
Hoping to lure a new partner, Vesper decided to take the company to the financial break-even point this year, 12 months earlier than management had planned. Under the the interim president and chief executive Barry Rowan, who is also the chief financial officer of Velocom, the company scaled back and reorganized its business plan, announcing the layoffs of 1,300 of its 4,000 workers in February. (Two weeks ago, Vesper ended the interim arrangement by naming a Brazilian businessman, Luiz Kaufmann, president and chief executive. Mr. Rowan retains his position at Velocom.)
The company reduced its residential target this year to a total of 800,000 customers, from 1.2 million previously, and began to focus on higher-income households that want a second line -- as many as one million in the state of Sao Paulo, according to the Yankee Group research firm -- and on businesses interested in integrated voice and data services. The company also bought an Internet service provider and started to lay fiber optic cable.
"When we built the network, we didn't know exactly where the customers would be coming from and what the nature of the customers would be," Mr. Rowan said. "Now we are moving from taking orders to selling services, where we can look at the most attractive areas economically, based on where the customers are and where we have capacity, and target directly the kinds of customers that we would like to have on the network."

HEADLINE: An Artist's Novel Take on History: He Lets the Walls Talk 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
Walking into a space designed by James Casebere can be an unsettling experience. Mr. Casebere has based his architectural work on the Berlin sewer system, West African slave quarters, maximum-security prisons and Jefferson's Monticello (by design, Mr. Casebere's Monticello is ankle-deep in water).
 That is, if you could walk into these spaces. 
 Mr. Casebere, a New York artist, designs and builds the work as models, photographs them, then blows the photographs up into large-scale prints, typically six by eight feet, that give the impression of reality. But the uneasy realm of caverns, parlors and cells, inhabited by unspoken intent, can be visited in the mind's eye only, like the architecture in dreams.
An exhibition of 10 of his photographs is on view at the new Sean Kelly gallery in Chelsea through June 16. A monograph, "James Casebere: The Spatial Unconscious," is being published next month. An exhibition at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia, which includes work by Mr. Casebere and Glen Seator, opened earlier this month, on view through July 29.
Mr. Casebere, 47, who wanted to be an architect as a child, grew up outside Detroit, the son of a high school principal who designed two schools. He recalled poring over blueprints with his father. In 1975, while an undergraduate at the Minneapolis College of Art and Design, he began taking photographs of things he had built. He graduated in 1976.
"There were a lot of interesting conceptual artists -- Vito Acconci, Siah Armajani, Mary Miss -- who began working with architecture in the 70's," Mr. Casebere said last week, sitting in a dusty leather lounge chair in his East Village studio. 
The tenement apartment, crowded to its corners with the parts of houses and sets of interior spaces, looks like the bedroom of a child who enjoys blowing up his toys. Mr. Casebere has recently moved residence to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, with his companion, Lorna Simpson, an artist, and their daughter, Zora.
"Robert Venturi became very important to me after I got out of school," he said, speaking of the architect and author of "Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture," a seminal book on postmodernism published in 1966. "To think about architecture as a system of visual signs. His terminology was borrowed by critics like Douglas Krimp and applied to people like Cindy Sherman: art that used popular conventions of picture making like photography, and used historical pastiche."
Mr. Casebere first exhibited his photographs in New York at Artists Space in 1977. Unlike his contemporaries Ms. Sherman, who took center stage in movielike locations for her "Film Stills," or Laurie Simmons, who staged dramatic scenes with dolls against backgrounds of miniature rooms and houses, Mr. Casebere created spaces without figures, based on architectural archetypes, which were themselves the subject of his work. If these walls could speak, as he intends them to, with visual eloquence, they might tell the tales that were responsible for the building genres Mr. Casebere chooses to represent. 
As an artist he is interested in architecture because of its ability to resonate visually with a version of history that might not be otherwise recorded, an unofficial witness to events. Interior space, like a kind of unconsciousness, can be an "inside story," a place that harbors the truth.
After a visit to Germany in 1998 Mr. Casebere designed and constructed an arched model in half-inch foamcore, painted to look like stone, that recalled the sewers of Berlin. For the photograph, the set was lighted as if for a manhunt: white shots into the dark, like the search for Peter Lorre in "M" or Orson Welles in "The Third Man."
Mr. Casebere, speaking of the extensive new construction in Berlin, explained: "In the German mind it's the future of Germany and the center of Europe and the economic community. But the underground is sort of more about the horrible German past." The depiction, he said, was a "kind of a psychohistory."
Commissioned in 2000 by Metropolis, a design magazine, to document an actual maximum-security prison in Texas, Mr. Casebere returned to his studio and built and photographed his own abstract version of the building, "Wichita Falls," as a physical resonance of his experience.
"It was just horrifying," he said. "The screams that I heard, the extreme hostility to the guards. One inmate was in a standing cage, 7 feet tall by 3 feet square, in the center of the block, naked, while they searched his cell. In protests, the inmates would all stop up the toilets and repeatedly flush them. From the second level, all the cells would flood and the water would rush over the balconies, like a waterfall."
The still photograph seems as quiet as death. 
There is also water in the picture. Mr. Casebere uses E-Z Water, an artists' resin that dries to a fluid-looking surface, to 'flood' models, a device frequent in his work since 1998. For now Mr. Casebere is the art world's James Cameron; like Mr. Cameron, the director of "Titanic," everything he builds, he floods.
"Overflowing water took on significance as life in the pictures, a kind of abundance," he said, acknowledging at the same time that to most people water to the ankles or water to the waist is an unambiguous threat: a swift, uncontrollable overture to panic. This year Mr. Casebere "flooded" Monticello. The photographs of the founding father's iconically American home, again reproduced to scale in a cut-and-pasted model, feature a rising tide of resin in the entry hall, below the famous cannonball clock, like a spreading stain upon history and Jefferson's legacy as an enlightened man.
"He was a flamboyant Virginian aristocrat who at times emulated the French style of opulence," Mr. Casebere said, standing beside his Monticello, which looked like an assembled craft kit of Arcadia. "Though it's become a symbol for a uniquely American culture, this house is a symbol of excess, as well as taste and ingenuity. For me, it was about taking the idealized father of the country, and bringing him down to size." In Mr. Casebere's model, two feet square, to be exact.
Life is now imitating art. Mr. Casebere, who is working with Deborah Burke, an architect, on the renovation of his Brooklyn house and a new studio, said that he would like to try his luck with architecture and interior design, including an addition to his house in upstate New York.
"I think about building real things that I don't have to photograph for a change, that don't get torn up," Mr. Casebere said.
Just wait until he has his first flood.

HEADLINE: BALLET THEATER REVIEWS; 
For the Good Of the Nation, The Widow Should Wed

BYLINE:  By ANNA KISSELGOFF 

 BODY:
It is the economy after all, stupid. That is the theme of "The Merry Widow," Ronald Hynd's witty ballet version of Franz Lehar's operetta of the same name.
 When Irina Dvorovenko, in an unscheduled, dazzling debut, and Julio Bocca, hilarious and explosive in his dancing, led American Ballet Theater's "Widow" on Saturday afternoon, they made its story line more than clear: a rich widow must be persuaded to marry a dashing count so that her money will replenish the empty coffers of their country, Ponteverdo. 
 "The Merry Widow" is grand spectacle, happy entertainment and also a fragile ballet. It has gorgeous scenery and costumes by Desmond Heeley, Lehar music arranged by John Lanchbery that will send you humming into the street, and a plot and subplot full of enough farcical encounters to give the boulevard theaters of Paris a run for their francs.
Yet it takes a fabulous all-around comic performance grounded in brilliant technique to bring out the choreography's sometimes hidden virtues. No one should miss Mr. Bocca's Count Danilo, bounding into the air in a "drunk" solo. No one should miss Ms. Dvorovenko's haughty and truly merry widow, Hanna, including her entrance on a ballroom staircase. Mr. Bocca pulls out all the stops in a Latin-lover act. Ms. Dvorovenko is a portrait in fin de siecle presence. She knows how to carry a fan.
Mr. Hynd, a product of Britain's Royal Ballet, has couched his choreography in the refined style of English classicism. (The work was originally done for the Australian Ballet.) Power in dancing would seem antithetical to this reserved style. Yet since 1997, Ballet Theater and Mr. Bocca in particular have shown how bravura technique can transform an operetta without words into a sparkling entertainment on its own terms.
Casting makes some difference. On Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, Julie Kent, replacing Susan Jaffe, was a lyrical mischievous and sophisticated widow. Robert Hill, understated in his dancing, was nonetheless an officer and a gentleman as Danilo. Ashley Tuttle, exquisite as always, and Angel Corella, stunning in his own virtuosity and wide-eyed comedy, were the lovers in the subplot.
But Mr. Bocca, temperamental and uninhibited, raised the energy level of the entire cast on Saturday. Ms. Dvorovenko, dancing the widow for the first time in New York and replacing Alessandra Ferri, met him on the same ground of brilliant technique and hilarity.
In the subplot Maxim Belotserkovsky was witty with Xiomara Reyes, in a debut as Valencienne, the young wife of an elderly baron, poignantly acted by Victor Barbee. Ms. Reyes is waiflike, but she has an amazingly strong technique.
As the baron's secretary Vladislav Kalinin was more than superb. Virtuosity in an ersatz folk solo came from Herman Cornejo on Friday and Joaquin De Luz on Saturday. David LaMarche conducted with brio.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Can-can girls, right, in American Ballet Theater's "Merry Widow" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Below, Irina Dvorovenko, in her debut as Hanna, the widow, and Julio Bocca, at far left, as Count Danilo, her suitor. (Photographs by Richard Termine for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SUBJECT: BALLET (92%); DANCE (90%); THEATER (90%); DANCE COMPANIES (90%); CHOREOGRAPHY (89%); OPERA (89%); MUSIC (78%) DANCING; REVIEWS 

ORGANIZATION: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER (93%) AMERICAN BALLET THEATER

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
Chasing Comets No Longer Pie in the Sky

BYLINE:  By FRANK LITSKY 

 BODY:
Like most 5-year-olds, the Women's National Basketball Association is fairly healthy and full of energy. For the next two and a half months, it will fill half the seats in 16 otherwise vacant N.B.A. arenas. The season of 32 games for each team begins today with the perennial champion Houston Comets playing host to their potential successors, the Los Angeles Sparks.
 It is a time for optimism. Houston has lost its two most glamorous players -- Sheryl Swoopes is out for the season with a torn knee ligament and 38-year-old Cynthia Cooper retired and is now coaching the Phoenix Mercury -- so the league should be more competitive. Most of the weaker teams have improved their talent. 
 Last year, Houston and the Liberty won the conference titles and reached the league finals. Houston won the championship, as it did in every previous season of the W.N.B.A.'s existence. The Comets play in the tougher Western Conference, and the loss of Swoopes and Cooper this year opens the door for the Sparks, the Sacramento Monarchs and maybe an outsider. Still, Houston Coach Van Chancellor said, "Don't count out the defending champions."
The Eastern Conference was so soft last year that only two of the eight teams finished above .500, and the Washington Mystics made the playoffs despite a 14-18 record. Now the Liberty, with depth to spare, again looks to be the best in the East, especially if Rebecca Lobo can keep her knees healthy.
Competitive balance is important because, as the XFL and so many other would-be major leagues have learned, the battles for ticket sales, television ratings and sponsor dollars are unending. And even when the positives hold their own against the negatives, fine-tuning may be needed.
For example, in a state of the league report last week, Val Ackerman, the W.N.B.A.'s president, cited many positives: 2,322,822 tickets sold last year, national television on three networks, 2.5 million to 3 million television viewers a week, 150,000 visitors to the league's Web site on this year's draft day. But there are caveats, too.
The main reason for last year's attendance rise of 19 percent was the addition of expansion teams in Indiana, Miami, Seattle and Portland, Ore. But average attendance dropped 11 percent to 9,074, its lowest in league history, partly because the season started two weeks earlier and overlapped too much of the N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs. The purpose of the early start was to allow 30 or so W.N.B.A players more time to prepare for the Sydney Olympics.
Television ratings, while modest, are holding. NBC and ESPN will continue to televise games of the week, and ESPN2 will take over Lifetime's game of the week. The league's marketing partners include American Express, AOL Time Warner, Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola, Gatorade, General Motors, Nike and Sears. Ackerman said that last year's sponsor spending for all women's sports reached $1 billion for the first time.
With all that, the W.N.B.A., which is owned collectively by the N.B.A.'s 29 teams, is losing money.
"We are not profitable as a league," Ackerman said. "Teams have separate economics and most are unprofitable. It's expensive to start a sports league. A lot of costs have to be paid out of a league pot.
"The N.B.A. has television that pays $2 billion over four years, and we have to pay production costs to get our games on television. We have to share our revenue with our network partners. But we have long-term goals to be profitable."
Ackerman said the W.N.B.A.'s fan base was 75 percent female and its television viewers were mostly women. "We have attracted a new fan with the W.N.B.A.," Ackerman said. She added that the league is proud of the diversity of its fan base, which includes the lesbian community, youth groups, religious groups, professional women and the American Indian community. 
There is more diversity on the court as well this season. Ackerman said that of the 110 players from the W.N.B.A.'s first season, only 30 remain. She said 25 percent of today's players come from other countries, and as Chancellor, the Houston coach, said, "Great players are coming into this league, and they are so much better."
In this year's draft, 15 non-Americans were taken, including three Australians in the first round. The Seattle Storm made one of those Australians, the 6-foot-5, 20-year-old Lauren Jackson, the first choice. Jackson, mainly a post player, is so mobile and talented that she sank five 3-point shots in a preseason game.
The rookie crop is rich with prospects, notably Ruth Riley, the Notre Dame center, at Miami; Kelly Miller, the Georgia guard, at Charlotte; and Jackie Stiles, the Southwest Missouri State guard, at Portland. Injuries have slowed other rookies like Tamika Catchings, the Tennessee forward, at Indiana; Svetlana Abrosimova, the Connecticut forward, at Minnesota; and Shea Ralph, the Connecticut guard, at Utah.
Five teams have new head coaches. They include the Indiana Fever, where Nell Fortner takes over after coaching the United States to an Olympic gold medal in Sydney, and the Phoenix Mercury, where Cooper takes charge because Cheryl Miller wanted to concentrate on her duties as an N.B.A. television sideline reporter. Tom Maher, from Australia, takes over for Nancy Darsch in Washington, becoming the league's first foreign coach.

HEADLINE: Tax Rebate Draws a Mixed Response 

BYLINE:  By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27 

 BODY:
With a bonus check from the I.R.S. practically in the mail, taxpayers around the country were already talking today about how they would spend the tax cut that Congress passed on Saturday. But some of them were unenthusiastic about what the new law says about the federal government's fiscal priorities.
 The law will pay anyone who earned at least $6,000 in taxable income last year a rebate of $300 in September; couples who earned $12,000 or more will get $600. In later years, tax rates will decline, new deductions and credits will emerge, and the estate tax will wither away, all at a net cost to the Treasury of $1.35 trillion by the year 2010. 
 It looks like a good deal to Curtis Breit, 32, an electrical engineer who rode his motorcycle into the capital today from nearby Silver Spring, Md., for an annual bikers' rally in support of the missing-in-action from the Vietnam War. He had been eagerly awaiting passage of the tax cut. Once the new law is fully phased in, his calculations predict a tax cut of $300 a month, money he plans to put toward building a new house. "I look at it as if I'm getting a raise," he said.
But some people seemed to prefer more federal spending over tax cuts as a way to use the surplus.
Peter Stickley, a farm manager for a private school in Vermont, said he was "skeptical" that the full amount promised by the tax cut would materialize in the years ahead, since that would reduce the federal budget surplus. Mr. Stickley and his wife, Patty, a psychologist, are in the 28 percent tax bracket, a middle-class bracket. They have three children, ages 19, 12 and 9.
He was not impressed to hear that someone in his situation would get a $600 rebate check in September and might expect the family's taxes to decline about $800 next April 15 and $1,700, or 30 percent, when the bill takes full effect in a few years.
"I'm not interested in the check," he said. "I don't have a problem with my federal income taxes."
Instead, he said, his problem is "skyrocketing" property taxes in the town of Saxtons River, where he lives, to pay for special education programs and other local school costs. For those reasons, he said, he supported James M. Jeffords, the Vermont senator who left the Republican Party last week after opposing President Bush's full tax proposal and demanding more federal spending on special education programs.
Other people also pointed to federal spending programs that they would rather see financed generously instead of getting a big tax cut.
Lillian Brown, a retired business owner in New Haven, called the tax cut "one big joke they've foisted on the American people." She and her husband, now in the prosperous 36 percent tax bracket, "don't want it and don't need it," she said, adding that the surplus should have been earmarked for "important things" like a prescription drug benefit.
"What am I going to do with my $600 check and my 1 percent tax cut?" Mrs. Brown asked.
In fact, beyond the $600 rebate this year, the tax rates for someone in her bracket would decline one percentage point every two years, reaching 33 percent in 2006. By the time the bill is fully phased in, the Browns would likely see their income taxes go down by several thousand dollars a year.
Kim Miller, 32, a graduate student who lives in Los Angeles, also said the tax cut was not needed. But she said she and her husband, Glen Hirshberg, 35, who teaches high school, would make use of the expanded tax benefits for educational savings accounts. They are in the 28 percent tax bracket and have a 2-year-old son. "It doesn't matter that it doesn't take effect right away," she said of the education benefit.
Marcie Brogan, the managing partner of a small advertising agency in Detroit, said she was delighted with the tax legislation and planned to check on Tuesday whether she could increase her contributions to her 401(k) retirement plan. 
"I have cheerfully paid my taxes for years and will cheerfully take a rebate," said Ms. Brogan, who lives in Birmingham, Mich., a wealthy Detroit suburb, with her husband, Michael, also an advertising agency executive. "I'm just thrilled by this; I couldn't be happier, and I do not believe the government will go broke or that we will not have enough money for key spending programs."
Ms. Brogan, 55, said she and her husband paid the highest income tax rate, 39.6 percent, which applies to couples earning over $288,350.
Ms. Brogan said she had split her ballot last November, voting for George W. Bush for president but supporting Democrats for other offices. "My wallet is Republican, my conscience is Democratic," said Ms. Brogan, who commutes 40 miles each day to and from her office in a red, 6,500-pound Hummer sport utility vehicle that she bought used a few years ago for about $70,000.
Ann Chandler, who came to Washington from Oakland, Calif., this weekend to attend her daughter's graduation from law school, said she feared the tax cut would lead to cuts in government programs that are important to her, like child services and education. 
Ms. Chandler, 59, said a recent increase in financing for the Alameda County Public Health Department, where she is the laboratory director, might disappear if federal spending declines because of the tax cut. "We are finally seeing the rewards of the strong economy," she said, "but now we might lose that funding."
But at the resort town of Duck, N.C., several vacationers said the bill's passage had only brightened their day a bit more. "You get taxed enough on so many things already, it's better to get something back," said Chris Martin, 37, an air-conditioner repairman from Richmond, Va. Then he went back to nursing his beer in the 80-degree heat.

HEADLINE: In the War on AIDS, a U.N. Official Accents Prevention as a Battle Plan Takes Shape 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 25 

 BODY:
Peter Piot, the epidemiologist who has been coordinating an international campaign against AIDS since 1995, is spending less time worrying about the price of drugs and more about the shortage of condoms.
 Dr. Piot said he feared that attention had shifted from the front lines of the fight, the thousands of communities where the most basic means of prevention are still beyond the reach of the poor and vulnerable. 
 "We feel strongly that the response to AIDS has to be a balanced one: prevention and treatment," he said. "In the current climate, people forget that. I'm really getting tired of the fact that a terribly complex problem of treatment and care for people having H.I.V. is reduced to the price of anti-retroviral drugs." 
Those are fighting words to his critics. As the United Nations prepares for a special General Assembly session on AIDS from June 25 to June 27, the first session ever held to discuss a disease, a coalition demanding that access to treatment be declared a basic right is planning to demonstrate in New York that week. 
The coalition, the Global Treatment Access Campaign, will demand a war chest of $16 billion to fight AIDS, a cancellation of third world debt and an end to American efforts to protect drug companies from patent challenges in poor countries.
Secretary General Kofi Annan has asked countries to create a fund of $7 billion to $10 billion above the current money available for AIDS, which is now approaching $1 billion. 
Dr. Piot, a Belgian and an expert on Africa who was among those who first identified the ebola virus and later saw some of the first effects of AIDS in Congo, said that before money on that scale could be spent in the poorest countries -- if indeed it can be raised -- more effective prevention, testing and delivery systems must be put in place.
A strategy on how to use the global fund has now been devised and will be presented to the Unaids board by the beginning of June, he said. The fund, to fight not only AIDS but also tuberculosis and malaria, will be collected and distributed through a venture involving United Nations agencies, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, he said. 
But all decisions about how the money should be spent will be left to experts within the recipient countries, and the headquarters office will deliberately be kept very small, with no more than 10 administrators, Dr. Piot said.
Under the plan to be presented to the Unaids board, he said, the World Bank, part of the United Nations system, will hold the money but not control it or attach conditions to it. 
Recently, Joseph Kabila, the president of Congo, a country struggling to emerge from civil war, went to the Unaids office in Geneva to ask for help in starting an AIDS program, Dr. Piot said. "The Caribbean, the second most-affected region, is now waking up," he added, and he has moved on to planning campaigns for the next epicenters, Eastern Europe and South Asia, particularly India.
For some countries that means persuading governments to recognize vulnerable groups often kept in the shadows, among them gay men and sex workers. 
An anti-establishment protester in his youth, Dr. Piot now argues for maintaining good relations with pharmaceutical companies. "We work with everybody who's part of the problem to find a solution," he said. "I think that very soon the issue of the price of anti-retroviral drugs will be off the table." 
Then, Dr. Piot said, "We start with the real problem: building the infrastructure." Expensive health care systems are not necessarily the first or only priority. "For AIDS you need more than health care, you need the school system, you need all the communications," he said. 
"The government sets policy," Dr. Piot continued, "makes sure there are resources and all that, but it's not government that's going to promote condoms in gay bars at night -- nowhere in the world. To promote condoms you don't need doctors. You use commercial outlets, all these kiosks with women selling soap, beer, cigarettes -- that's where people go for condoms, not to a clinic." 
At the grass roots, where many will never have access to anti-retroviral drugs, condoms are also in short supply. 
"Not only male condoms but female condoms as well," Dr. Piot said, adding that very conservative views about women block the development and distribution of female condoms. "This seems to me -- and maybe this is too strong of a statement -- a really sexist approach, not thinking that women need something also that's under their control. Let's make sure that we increase the options for women to protect themselves -- and increasing means from zero to one option."

HEADLINE: Some Upset by Twist on Pearl Harbor 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, May 27 

 BODY:
On a perfect beach day, 84 shining degrees, the lines to see the solemn U.S.S. Arizona Memorial at Pearl Harbor were long all day long, and the lines to see the $140 million movie "Pearl Harbor" were even longer.
 Both Pearl Harbor, the Navy base that changed the history of World War II, and "Pearl Harbor," the movie that changes history as it sees fit, are big news here, in part because of the Memorial Day weekend, and in no doubt greater part because of the movie's pre-opening publicity and its $5 million splashy premiere party. Even local residents, usually loath to mingle with tourists, are braving the movie crowds. James Takane, who was 11 when the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor 60 years ago and remembers it well, dipped into the multiplex in Waikiki to check out the Hollywood version. 
 But like many other locals, he left the theater disappointed. "It doesn't tell the true story," said Mr. Takane, who had brothers who joined the Army in World War II. "A lot of us were standing outside watching the planes flying overhead. But you don't see Japanese-Americans or other Hawaiians in the film. Maybe it was just the base they were showing? It's hard to tell. But it doesn't show us."
For many Hawaiians, "Pearl Harbor" the movie is a decidedly mixed blessing. Its shooting on location here created hundreds of jobs, albeit temporary ones, and poured millions of dollars into a stalling economy. More significantly, the enormous publicity, high-profile premiere and expected success of the film virtually guarantee that thousands upon thousands of new visitors will want to see the real Pearl Harbor, bolstering tourism, Hawaii's most important industry. But such attention comes at a price. Many here see the film as the latest, perhaps most egregious example of Hollywood's habit of using Hawaii as a gorgeous backdrop curiously empty of Hawaiians. 
Not that anyone expects a popcorn blockbuster to aspire to precise historical accuracy. As David Takamiya, a 49-year-old native who has grown up with Pearl Harbor stories put it after seeing the film, "It's really a story about two people -- or three people -- in love."
But to others, it is grating that the movie spends 40 minutes on the Japanese attack without showing that the Japanese not only bombed battleships, killing more than 2,000 sailors, but also bombed and strafed all over Oahu, this island where Pearl Harbor is situated, causing fires and reducing buildings to rubble. And the movie does not give even a glancing reference to the scores of Hawaiian civilians -- the youngest a 3-month-old girl -- who were killed in the attack, most of them from friendly fire as antiaircraft rounds missed their targets and landed several miles away in Honolulu. 
"Were there any Hawaiians or other local people on Oahu on Dec. 7, 1941?" asked Ed Rampell, writing in the local alternative newspaper, The Honolulu Weekly. "Natives and other locals are Ralph Ellison-like invisible people in a story script set in their home."
Dan Martinez, the historian for the National Park Service's U.S.S. Arizona Memorial, who served as an unpaid script consultant for the film, said viewers should see it as "fiction aided by fact." 
At the visitor center, where guests take a ferry to the memorial -- a white bridge that stands over but does not touch the remains of the sunken ship where 1,177 sailors were entombed -- visitors do learn that civilians were killed. An exhibit with news clips mentions the civilian casualties, and plaques naming 48 who died (other official tallies list the casualties as 68) sit on a memorial on the lawn.
But for Hawaiians who believe that their state is used as a stage set and that their culture is overshadowed by the larger one of the United States, "Pearl Harbor" commits the same mistake as smaller productions in keeping Hawaiians -- people of Asian, mixed and Pacific Island ancestry -- off camera.
"Hawaii is not Minnesota," said John Nagala, a senior at the University of Hawaii. "I find it kind of funny in a sick way that the theaters aired the first showing at 7:55 to commemorate the time of the attack 60 years ago, but no one could figure out a way to show more than a split second's worth of local Hawaiians."
Mr. Nagala's friend Sandra Hirohito said: "Of course we realize it's quote unquote just a movie, and we realize that it was the worst attack on American soil in history. But would it have been so hard, given the budget of the film, to stick in a few more Hawaiian faces?"
Lulu Toluao, a longtime resident who comes from Samoa, was less critical. "It was just like every other movie in what it did to Hawaii," she said, "but I didn't mind it."
Japanese-Americans like Mr. Takane, who is 70, seem to be most concerned about the movie. (On June 2, the Japanese Cultural Center in Honolulu will present a forum, "the other side of the story.") For Mr. Takane, what was most striking after the real bombing was seeing Japanese-American families in Oahu thrown into internment camps as punishment for their ancestry. He said they were treated as spies and subjected to resentment for Pearl Harbor "that continues to this day."
"For me, it's very important to talk about this," Mr. Takane said. "I come from a family of six boys, and our father had us all volunteer for the military. I was in the Army for the Korean War and served in Vietnam as well, leaving as a lieutenant colonel.
"In Vietnam, everyone called me the Jap colonel," he said. "That was a leftover from Pearl Harbor."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lulu Toluao, also of Hawaii, said she "didn't mind" the movie.; "It doesn't show us," said James Takane, who lives in Hawaii. (Photographs by John Titchen for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Changing Nueva York 

 BODY:
One of the more dramatic findings of the 2000 census was the extent to which immigration has arrested, and in many cases reversed, population decline in America's major cities. New York is no exception. Without the arrival of a million foreigners in the 1990's, the city's population would have declined in the last decade, instead of surpassing the eight million mark. Forty percent of New Yorkers are foreign-born, the most since 1910, and they are responsible for revitalizing many of the city's neighborhoods. 
 Latin Americans and Asians accounted for much of the inflow. These recent arrivals, hailing from a growing number of countries, contributed not only to the city's diversity, but also to the diversity of their own ethnic communities. Puerto Ricans and Chinese are no longer overwhelming majorities within the Hispanic and Asian populations, as immigrants from places like Mexico, Colombia, India and Korea have increasingly made their way to the city. 
 The demographic shift is especially pronounced among Hispanics, the largest minority group in the city, numbering 2.1 million people and accounting for 27 percent of the population. This is the largest Hispanic community of any American city, and an increasingly diverse one. Puerto Ricans, who in 1990 were a majority, are now 36 percent of the total. Their raw numbers actually declined by 12 percent in the 1990's, as retirees returned to Puerto Rico. Meanwhile, immigration from Latin America soared -- the number of Mexicans in the city tripled, to become the third-largest Latino group, behind Puerto Ricans and Dominicans. 
Though statistics are useful in defining existing population patterns, the reasons behind the various demographic shifts in the last decade are hard to quantify. Immigration has long been a mysteriously informal and deeply personal saga, and so it remains today. Hundreds of thousands of Mexicans came to New York in the 1990's, for example, because they heard, typically from a neighbor or a cousin back in the old country, that there were opportunities to be had here. A few adventurous immigrants from the southern Mexican state of Puebla came two decades ago, did well and started the flow. 
To this day, more than half the city's Mexican population is believed to come from Puebla, and there are small towns in the depressed, indigenous Mixteca region of that state whose economies are fed almost entirely by dollars being sent home from New York. More recent immigrants come from the central states of Michoacan and Jalisco, and Mexico City, too, and many of them have settled in Westchester County. 
As in the Asian community, the increasing diversity of the city's Hispanic population should help challenge dated notions. One is that minorities are monoliths. There is a strong cultural and linguistic bond between Mexicans, Dominicans and Puerto Ricans, to be sure, but New Yorkers must now stop thinking of "Hispanic" and "Puerto Rican" as interchangeable terms. 
This, in turn, requires city and state agencies to make it a higher priority to address the pressing social problems affecting immigrants, such as strained school systems and the abusive treatment of undocumented workers by employers. The Puerto Rican political establishment, for its part, is beginning to adjust to the changing reality. Citizenship is one obvious gulf that has traditionally separated Puerto Ricans from many other Hispanic groups in New York. But in taking a greater interest in immigration and other issues affecting the broader Hispanic population, Puerto Rican politicians have an opportunity to help forge a pan-Latino political identity, and to capitalize on it.

HEADLINE: Essay; 
What To Remember

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: HARPERS FERRY, W. Va. 

 BODY:
We best honor fallen heroes by recalling the causes for which they fought, and -- eschewing all smug triumphalism -- counting the current blessings of American freedoms.
 First, we remember the victory that ensures government only by consent of the governed. Here we are fretting about the unvoted switch in power in the Senate, wondering who will now "set the agenda" and if the two parties will conflict or compromise. 
 But in the recent election, the electorate split down the middle. No ideology won, yet all three branches -- Congress, the White House, the Supreme Court -- were in conservative hands by the narrowest of margins. Although that was constitutionally legitimate, the one-sided result of the photo-finish race struck many as out of whack. 
What better reflection of the consent of the undecided governed than what we have now -- closely divided government? As a result, the three branches now have a choice: paralysis through media blame-casting or progress through political horse-trading. 
Because voters next year will punish incumbents of both parties for partisan gridlock, public officials have every incentive to perfect the art of the deal. Because "compromise or else" is the order of the day, the principled struggles will be within each party to choose what to fight for and what to sacrifice. And because we the governed are demonstrably uncertain, we are getting only what we consented to. Go find a more ingenious system.
The next blessing is an economic philosophy that has produced prosperity that is the wonder of the world. Communism and socialism turned out to be wavelets of the past; fascism and its corporate state failed as well -- though their vestiges persist under benighted and authoritarian regimes. The hidden hands of free-market economics applaud the American locomotive that is pulling the world forward.
The capitalist system, which most raises the standard of living, has won the worldwide competition. But because the business cycle is part of it, as natural as breathing, any temporary downturn or short-term shortage brings cries to veer off into a command economy. Hence the demagogic call for energy "price caps," always politically satisfying at first -- populist interference with the market's self-correction that would lead to worse shortages and rationing, to inflation and wage control. 
High prices invite fresh supply and restrict demand, which then lowers prices; government can ameliorate the pain of transition and enforce fair competition, but it is the unshackled working of the enterprise system that best balances supply and demand. It has proved to be the most practical system known to humanity, with the most personal freedom built into it; we should be grateful that America is its exemplar. Our emphasis on economic freedom is the source of our military strength and made it possible for us to lead the fight to save democracy.
That strength, when coupled with our long-held vision of human rights, blesses our foreign policy with a moral force. The worthy mission to preserve and defend freedom wherever it is in our national interest -- and sometimes quite selflessly -- is why flowers of remembrance are being laid on American graves around the world on this Memorial Day. 
Our zeal for the rights of human beings to be free is now scorned by some Europeans who do not like to be reminded who saved them from enslavement. In France, where Thomas Paine wrote "The Rights of Man," a polemic soon vindicated for both men and women by England's Mary Wollstonecraft, our outspoken espousal of human rights is now seen to be a manifestation of hegemony by an unwelcome "hyperpower." 
Now that they are safe and healthy, nations freed from Nazism and saved from Communism are, in F.D.R.'s words about post-Depression Republicans, "throwing their crutches at the doctor." 
Here comes the obligatory to-be-sure graph: "Consent of the governed" often leaves a dissenting minority unsatisfied. The free-market system needs protection for competition, privacy, public health and a safety net for people who cannot compete. And we are not the only nation to stand up for human rights.
But in decorating the resting places of America's fighters, remember the legacy of freedoms they charge us to keep. This is a day to pay personal respects and to take national pride.

HEADLINE: Camden Journal; 
Air Is Heavy With Pollution, and Resentment

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J. 

 BODY:
Barbara Williams was in front of the Sacred Heart School in Camden's heavily industrial Waterfront South when she noticed something unusual about the air: it was breathable. 
 Ms. Williams, the principal at Sacred Heart and an asthma patient, said that most days the air was so filled with dust and other pollutants from trucks and smokestacks that many of the school's 260 students, most of whom are black and Hispanic, needed inhalers after recess. At times, she added, the stench from the nearby sewage treatment plant is so bad that students would rather not go outside to play. 
 One particularly bad air day, "they had been well behaved at lunch," Ms. Williams recalled. "And I said, 'Now you get to go outside.' And one child said: 'Ms. Williams, I thought you said we've been good. Why do we have to go outside?' " 
Sandwiched between Route 676 and the Delaware River opposite Philadelphia, Waterfront South has 2,100 residents living in a neighborhood of less than a square mile crammed with a power plant, a trash incinerator, a sewage plant, a scrap yard, an auto wrecker and boarded-up factories. 
"All them buildings stink, and them trucks going by, the smoke is bad," said Danny Vazquez, 18, a cook at a McDonald's a mile away from his house on Arlington Street, where backyards run up against the Welsbach/General Gas Mantle federal Superfund site -- and the traces of radioactive thorium that have outlived the production of gas lanterns there.
Most of the whites who once made up Waterfront South and worked in places like the Howland Croft & Company factory, which closed long ago but whose cracking brick walls still boast in faded lettering of "Fine Worsted Yarns," are gone. Most of the residents now are members of minorities, many them poor and sick, who can find relatively few jobs in factories that are highly automated.
Some of the residents believe their neighborhood carries an unfair burden of industry, and their fight has made Waterfront South a battleground in the emerging legal field of environmental justice, which involves the recognition of poor minority communities as society's repositories for industry and its pollutants.
In February, public interest lawyers from San Francisco, Philadelphia and Camden filed a suit in Federal District Court in Camden on behalf of 10 residents to block the opening of a $50 million plant that will grind slag into a fine powder additive to cement.
The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection insists the plant meets all air pollution standards, but the residents charged that by permitting the plant, the state violated Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits racial discrimination by agencies that receive federal funds. Until the matter is resolved, a judge stopped the plant's opening.
Legal experts say that if successful, the residents of Waterfront South could establish a precedent for private citizens in civil rights suits. 
One of the plaintiffs, Bonnie Sanders, 54, said her granddaughter Najsia Taylor, 3, had developed asthma, and her foster child, Lashonda Midgett, 4, had begun coughing since they came to live with her last year. "I wake up every morning at 3 a.m. coughing and gagging," Ms. Sanders said. "We don't live a normal life around here like you would in Cherry Hill," she added, referring to Camden's wealthy suburban neighbor. 
Michael Davis, the amiable manager of the cement additive plant, said that he appreciated residents' concerns about the health effects of breathing the dust. But the dust, he said, is the plant's product -- not a mere byproduct -- and it is in the company's economic interest to keep it from escaping into the air. 
The plant would provide 15 jobs directly, plus work for truckers and longshoremen. Its owner, St. Lawrence Concrete Group of Montreal, would also pay an estimated $1.8 million annually in a 45-year lease with the South Jersey Port Corporation, the state agency that owns the 14-acre plant site. Some fear that if the plant is kept closed, other potential employers will stay away.
And that would be bad news to Pearl Panichella, one of the few whites remaining in Waterfront South. To Ms. Panichella, 62, an unemployed barmaid, there is too little industry left, not too much.
"A lot of factories closed down," she said. "Bars closed down, too -- lost my job."

HEADLINE: In New Jersey Race, Statistics Too Good to Let Truth Get in the Way 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 27 

 BODY:
It is hardly unusual when politicians in the heat of a campaign sling numbers like mud. But with less than a month until the New Jersey primary for governor, the three candidates are doing little else.
 Bret D. Schundler raised taxes 79 percent! screams Bob Franks, his rival in the Republican primary. 
 Bob Franks voted with former Gov. Jim Florio 90 percent of the time! shouts Mr. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City. 
James E. McGreevey raised taxes by 71 percent! cry Mr. Franks and Mr. Schundler in unison, about the mayor of Woodbridge, who is unopposed for the Democratic nomination.
Each of these cartoonish-sounding claims is, on its own terms, accurate. But if statistics don't lie, they certainly don't necessarily convey the whole truth.
"If I was voting in New Jersey, I would want to be really careful," said Joel Best, author of the new book "Damned Lies and Statistics: Untangling Numbers from the Media, Politicians and Activists" (University of California Press). "But most of us don't have the energy to dissect what we hear in a campaign ad."
To do just such a dissection, however, reveals something about each of the contenders and his record -- far more than a mere number stripped from its context, blown up beyond recognition and wielded like a cudgel. It also sheds light on the tactics of each of the three, and on the peculiar ethics of hardball campaigning.
Mr. McGreevey, who has never really stopped running for governor since narrowly losing to Gov. Christie Whitman in 1997, was the first to begin lobbing statistics.
As this year's race drew near, his chief Republican rival appeared to be Donald T. DiFrancesco, the State Senate president since 1992. So Mr. McGreevey engineered his campaign to hold Mr. DiFrancesco accountable for what he called the Whitman administration's failings. And at the top of Mr. McGreevey's list was the state's growing long-term debt burden.
Debt had more than doubled on Mrs. Whitman's watch, he said at every opportunity. And it had, technically, to $15.7 billion a year ago from $5.7 billion in 1993.
But a closer look lessens the impact of those numbers. The 1993 debt figure Mr. McGreevey used excluded $4.5 billion in liabilities that were not recognized until later. Those included things like sick pay for state workers, as well as the state's liability for future pension payments, which was converted to debt in 1997 in a controversial $2.8 billion bond issue that treasury officials insist will save billions in the long run.
The upshot? To be fair, Mr. McGreevey should compare the current debt with $10.2 billion, which was the actual and unrecognized debt in 1993, state officials say. By that measure, debt had risen by 54 percent since then -- still a large increase, and nearly one and a half times the rate at which the state budget grew.
Once it became clear that Mr. Schundler was going to mount a primary challenge, he came under attack -- first by Mr. DiFrancesco, the acting governor, and then by Mr. Franks, who replaced Mr. DiFrancesco in the race last month -- for having raised taxes by 79 percent in Jersey City.
In a radio debate on Wednesday, Mr. Schundler called this "absolutely, positively, indisputably a lie." It was not a lie. But it was misleading.
To arrive at 79 percent, Mr. Franks had to compare the Jersey City tax rate last year -- $2.02 per $100 of assessed property value -- with the 1994 tax rate, $1.13 per $100.
But Mr. Schundler took office in 1992. That year, taxes were $1.70 per $100. In fact, one of Mr. Schundler's first acts as mayor was to arrange for the sale to Wall Street investors of uncollected tax liens. That produced $25 million in cash and allowed a five-month tax holiday in 1994. Thus the low tax rate that year.
Compared with 1992, property taxes in Jersey City actually rose 18.9 percent, or an average of 2.4 percent a year, which Mr. Schundler notes is less than the regional rate of inflation, an average of 2.7 percent during the same period.
Mr. Franks sticks to his guns. "If I moved to the city in 1994, my property taxes went up 79 percent," said Charlie Smith, his campaign manager. He adds that Mr. Schundler's desire to adjust tax rates for inflation is asking too much.
"I don't adjust what I spend at the grocery store for inflation," Mr. Smith said. "I spend more. That's less money available to me because of inflation. You can't say property taxpayers are getting a break because of inflation. If that were the case, then the price of bread is the same as it was 50 years ago."
He also notes that Mr. Schundler had no trouble attacking Mr. McGreevey for raising taxes by 71 percent in Woodbridge -- a calculation rooted in the same methodology as Mr. Franks's attack on Mr. Schundler.
But then, in the heat of a campaign, it is not about consistency, it is about making sure the sun does not set on an unrequited attack. And turnabout is fair play, no matter how unfair it seems at the time.
For example, Mr. Schundler deftly turned the tables on Mr. Franks by attacking his voting record as a state assemblyman. One of Mr. Franks's claims to fame among Republicans is that he helped the party win control of the State House after Governor Florio's tax increases in 1990. But a researcher hired by Mr. Schundler reported that Mr. Franks's voting record on bills that Mr. Florio, a Democrat, signed or vetoed showed that they agreed 90 percent of the time.
Mr. Franks, in a radio debate on Wednesday, called that figure "grossly misleading." 
Legislators vote on so many things, many of them inconsequential, many others only after bipartisan accords, that it is not uncommon for people at opposite ends of the political spectrum to have eerily similar voting records, said David P. Rebovich, a professor at Rider University who studies state politics.
"The votes don't get to the table until the stuff is worked out," he said. "There are understandings between the majority party and the governor's office. And not for nothing, but when you're a member of the minority party, you frequently end up voting with the majority, because you don't want to be accused of not supporting education, or programs for seniors, and so on -- much like the Democrats voted for Whitman's income tax cut. Because they knew they'd get killed in an election if they were against it."
Of course, for Mr. Franks to call the 90 percent figure misleading is itself fraught with irony. Mr. Schundler's researcher, Christopher Lyon, actually came up with the figure while working for Mr. Franks in the 2000 Senate primary. Mr. Lyon said he was commissioned to analyze the voting record of a rival Republican, State Senator William L. Gormley. Mr. Gormley voted with Mr. Florio 93 percent of the time, Mr. Lyon found; he said he did the same analysis on Mr. Franks and argued unsuccessfully that it would be unfair, and also unwise, to use the number in the campaign because it could blow up in Mr. Franks's face.
That, as it happened, took a year.
To bring this round robin of muddy math full circle, both Mr. Franks and Mr. Schundler have piggybacked on state Republican claims that Mr. McGreevey, the Democrat who awaits in the November election, sharply raised both property taxes and debt as mayor of Woodbridge after taking office in 1992.
The tax rate in Woodbridge was 62.7 cents per $100 of property value in 1991. It rose to $1.06 per $100 in 2001, an increase of 71 percent, and at more than twice the rate of inflation.
But Mr. McGreevey argues that the 1991 rate was abnormally low, because his predecessor, Joseph DeMarino, cut taxes by 20 percent in what Mr. McGreevey called an election-year ploy. Mr. DeMarino also emptied surplus accounts, overestimated revenues and failed to budget enough money for a costly labor deal and pending tax appeals, Mr. McGreevey says.
Adjusting the 1991 budget for all those items produces a true tax rate of 87 cents per $100, according to an audit the following year. Or, Mr. McGreevey says, one should go back to 1990, when the tax rate was 83 cents per $100.
Either way, the increase between then and now would be well below the rate of inflation.
In the same way, Mr. McGreevey blames Mr. DeMarino for most of the increase in Woodbridge's debt. Mr. McGreevey borrowed $34 million in 1992 to plug a $24.5 million budget gap he said he inherited, and to shift the town's fiscal year.
Excluding those borrowings, Mr. McGreevey accepts responsibility for only $5.6 million in additional debt -- an increase of just 5.3 percent in 10 years, less than one-fifth the rate of inflation.
Whether Mr. McGreevey will get away with that, of course, will be up to his opponents, and to the voters in November.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: A Starchy Old Sport Gets a Youthful Swing; 
Fresh Crop of Magazines Recasts Golf With Mix of Celebrities, Gonzo and Sex

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Cocktails to lubricate the advertisers are nothing new in the magazine world. So it was not extraordinary for the editor of a golf magazine to play host at a party for executives of advertising agencies and manufacturers last Tuesday night in Chicago.
 But this instance of ritual wooing, held by Maximum Golf magazine, had its own new twists. It took place on a rooftop overlooking Wrigley Field, and guests were challenged to down Cuervo shooters and then test their skill on an elaborate putting green installed just for the party. While people putted for the grand prize -- a $5,000 golf trip to Myrtle Beach -- and the Cubs and Reds played baseball far below, a guest said the tequila-fueled conversation occasionally turned to the high art of topless caddying. 
 Michael Caruso, Maximum Golf's 39-year-old editor, was jubilant. 
"Golf was never a cool sport when I was growing up," Mr. Caruso said over a lunchtime strip steak in Midtown Manhattan last week. "You used to have to back-slap with a bunch of geezers in white belts at the country club. It was fat cats. It was oil barons. Now it has thrown off its uncool shackles. Even chicks play it." 
In the last five years -- aided by Tiger Woods, advances in golf equipment, the once-booming economy and a quirky postmodern pop-cultural obsession with the game -- golf has been transformed from a sport for the Sansabelt set to a sexy pastime that has acquired a rock 'n' roll appeal for younger men and -- as Mr. Caruso might put it -- chicks. 
The magazines that have long been the standard bearers for the golfing community have themselves changed radically the last year, shifting ownership, recruiting editors from different fields, radically redesigning and expanding with new titles. The golf magazine marketplace is now also a battlefield of generations, a test of the old fogies versus the young fogies. 
With advertising revenue sinking across the magazine industry, the granddads of the field, Golf and Golf Digest, now find themselves also competing with the three-year-old American Express Publishing's Travel & Leisure Golf, and with brash start-ups like Maximum Golf, Fringe Golf and Schwing!, which was co-founded by Adrian Young, a member of the rock band No Doubt. The new, sometimes salacious publications have treated readers to photographs of nude women in bathtubs full of golf balls along with articles about extreme golf, glacier golf, midnight golf, nude golf, golfing nuns, golfing strippers, golf in Cambodia and the First Annual Pamela Anderson Bikini Golf Open, to be held next month in Mexico.
The upstart competition is relatively small in terms of circulation. Mr. Caruso said that Maximum Golf's circulation was 350,000, a figure he has submitted to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, compared with 1.6 million for Golf Digest and 1.4 million for Golf Magazine. But the newcomers have sent a signal to the rest of the field, which is experiencing significant corporate change while gingerly experimenting with newer editorial sensibilities. 
The two giants changed hands this year. In January, Times Mirror sold its magazine group, which included Golf, to AOL Time Warner's Time Inc. division. 
The next month, The New York Times Company sold Golf Digest and its owner, the Golf Digest Companies, to Advance Publications. Advance, of course, owns Conde Nast and Fairchild Publications, purveyors of frothier titles like Vanity Fair, W, Vogue and GQ and Conde Nast Traveler. And last year, Travel & Leisure Golf hired an editor in chief from a men's magazine who favors cover subjects like Martin Sheen and Michael Jordan over golf stars like Phil Mickelson. 
And the companies have not even reached the ninth-hole water station yet. Last week, the Golf Digest Companies bought Golf for Women from Meredith Publishing. Mitchell B. Fox, the company's chief executive, said that he would work to find synergies with "our brother and sister magazines" at Advance's Conde Nast and Fairchild Publications. He also announced a partnership with Business Week to publish special supplements -- on subjects like buying homes in golf communities -- that will be circulated to high-income readers of Business Week.
Richard S. Alfano, president of Golf Magazine Properties, betrayed no fears of his big rival's latest moves. He said that being part of AOL Time Warner gave his magazine resources available to no other golf publisher. 
"We can now align ourselves with the strongest weekly in the golf world, Sports Illustrated Golf Plus," Mr. Alfano said, as well as the cable channel CNN Sports Illustrated and the Web site golfonline.com. 
"Golf Digest is now part of a women's company," he said of his competitor. "We're more sports oriented."
George Peper, the editor in chief of Golf for the last 23 years, said the transition to AOL Time Warner had been a chance for growth and that the magazine had been radically redesigned. Its April cover -- which featured a brilliant red background, bold type and provocative headline -- looked spiritually akin to Maximum Golf, and the editor's letter suggested that the new magazine was doing "a creditable job of massaging your erogenous golf zones."
If it seems odd that venerable Golf Magazine would address erogenous zones, Mr. Peper said it was an effort to address readers' changing tastes. 
"Readers wanted things faster paced," Mr. Peper said. "There was also a desire for more golf courses they could afford. And we thought, well, we need to appeal to younger people too."
But Mr. Caruso of Maximum Golf would have none of it.
"You know they are all changing because of us," he said. "Look at Golf's redesign. The big fat letters, the big fat numbers, the cover. Man, somebody looked at our magazine when they were doing that redesign. 
"We are the only ones capturing the true spirit of golf," Mr. Caruso continued. Golf Digest and Golf "are so boring, they're like Sominex." 
Mr. Peper of Golf Magazine said he paid no mind to Mr. Caruso's jibes. As soon as Maximum Golf's readers "begin to take the game of golf seriously," he said, "they will abandon that magazine." 
And Mr. Fox of Golf Digest was dismissive. "Maximum Golf," he said, "is one of hundreds of little golf magazines out there scratching and scraping for nickels and dimes."
But in fact, Maximum Golf has a significant backer. Two years ago, Mr. Caruso persuaded Rupert Murdoch and the News Corporation to invest in his golf magazine, the only magazine -- now a year old -- published by Mr. Murdoch in the United States. And rather than scraping for nickels and dimes, Maximum Golf's ad revenue has held steady since the first issue in June 2000, according to its publisher, Terry Russell.
Most of the rest of the field is down. Golf Digest's ad pages this year through April were down 15 percent, from 505 pages last year to 429 pages this year, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Golf Magazine is off by 14 percent, from 569 to 486 pages. The one exception is Travel & Leisure Golf, published every two months, whose ad pages are up by 1.4 percent, from 162 to 164.
But ad executives predict that the golf magazines will quickly rebound. Gene DeWitt, chief executive of Optimedia International U.S., an advertising services agency in New York, said that advertisers cling to golf magazines because the readers tend be not only affluent, but fanatic.
"They have an obsessive quality," said Mr. DeWitt, who is not a golfer. "Forget about golf itself, which is the dumbest thing since I don't know what. But these people actually enjoy watching it on television, and you can't even see the ball. So you know that with golfers, their obsession is total. Show them a club or a ball that will get them another meter on a drive, and they will sell their first born. And that is great for advertisers."
Under pressure from advertisers, however, Mr. Caruso has toned down the magazine. The first issue featured Donald Trump's girlfriend, Melania Knauss, nude, luxuriating in a bathtub of strategically placed golf balls. There was also a centerfold feature, "Cart Girl of the Month." 
Such features and flourishes have been dropped. "It was partly because of advertisers, and also an editorial evolution," the publisher, Mr. Russell, said.
But the rest of the golf magazines -- even as they add spice to their pages -- insist that Maximum Golf's offbeat approach cannot sustain a magazine for the long run. John Atwood, the editor in chief of Travel & Leisure Golf -- who was hired last year from Men's Journal -- predicted that Maximum Golf would not last, simply because there were not enough gonzo golfers. 
"Golf is still a very traditional sport, " he said. "Tiger Woods works for Buick and American Express -- established companies that have a lot of respect for tradition and the history of the game, and so do we. Golf is not about a bunch of yahoos racing around on their carts drinking beer with their caps on backwards." 
But even T & L Golf is changing. Mr. Atwood said that soon he would for the first time feature "some beautiful women on the cover." (The volleyball player and model Gabrielle Reece will be the cover model for the July issue.)
Mr. Caruso said that he might further shift Maximum Golf by adding features for women. 
"Everybody wigs out when there is a woman on the golf course," he said. "Some women are out there playing, but not enough of them. It's basically one big prison movie out there. It is a great way to meet guys, but it is not a great way to meet girls." 
He paused and a reporter could practically hear the light bulb start to buzz above his head. 
"Who knows, maybe we could be a part of changing that," he said.
